Police were ordered to block the initial student marches but failed, sometimes offering only token resistance. Some uniformed police flashed V-for-victory signs to show support. The government finally called the army into Beijing's Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, causing hundreds of deaths. The 135-member Standing Committee, which concluded a nine-day session today, meets between annual sessions of the full 2,700-delegate National People's Congress. Xinhua said the new drug law approved by the committee specifies sentences ranging from 15 years in prison to the death sentence for ringleaders of drug smuggling gangs and those linked to international rings. It also calls for sentences of seven years to life for possession of 2.2 pounds of opium or 1.75 ounces of heroin. Drug abuse in China, while still far below Western levels, has increased in recent years along with income levels. A growing problem is the shipment of drugs from Southeast Asia through China to Hong Kong. The committee mandated life imprisonment or execution for ``serious cases'' of producing or selling pornographic materials, but Xinhua did not say what would constitute a serious case. ``Theresolution is aimed at safeguarding social order and promoting advanced socialist culture,'' Xinhua said. China already allows judges to hand down the death penalty for virtually any crime if they deem the circumstances serious enough, and hundreds are executed annually, based on media reports alone. Official totals are never released. Also today, Zheng Tuobin, 66, minister of foreign economic relations and trade since 1985, resigned and was replaced by his vice minister, Li Lanqing, Xinhua said. No reason was given. Western diplomats, however, said they were told earlier in the year that Zheng was ill. He was not believed to be in political trouble. The diplomats described his successor, Li, 58, as a pragmatist who worked in the auto industry and has experience in administering state loans and foreign investment. He speaks English and Russian.

DOC.HEAD: France Restores Credit For Projects in China
DOC.TEXT: France will restore official lines of credit for French-managed projects in China broken off last year after the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, an official said today. An Economics Ministry official said a protocol signed last week by China and France will free loans of $260 million to finance telecommunications and water treatment projects. The official said France's move is in accordance with a decision taken by the 12-nation European Community in November to normalize economic relations with Communist China. The funds will be the first official transfer from France to China since the Beijing government ordered the harsh crackdown on pro-democracy activists June 4, 1989 at Tiananmen Square. The French official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said several subsidiaries of France's Cie Generale d'Electricite, including Alcatel NV, were among the major contractors for the projects suspended last year.

DOC.HEAD: Parent of Patient at Nancy Cruzan's Hospital Wants to Remove Feeding Tube
With PM-Cruzan Funeral
DOC.TEXT: The father of a brain-damaged patient at the hospital where Nancy Cruzan died this week wants to move his daughter to another state and remove her feeding tube. ``I'm not going to let my kid stay like that,'' Pete Busalacchi said of his 20-year-old daughter, Christine, who has been in a persistent vegetative state since a 1987 car accident in St. Louis. ``If she knows what's going on, it's pure torture. If she doesn't, it's not worth going on.'' Busalacchi, 43, of St. Charles, declined to say what other facilities or states he was considering. ``It might happen real soon,'' he said. Ms. Cruzan died at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center early Wednesday, 12 days after a judge ruled that her parents had convincing evidence that she would want to die and allowed doctors to remove her feeding tube. She had been in a persistent vegetative state since a 1983 car crash. Busalacchi said he wants to move his daughter to a state with less strict regulations because he does not have the evidence required to meet the Missouri law and also hopes to avoid the publicity that surrounded the Cruzan case. While Ms. Cruzan starved and dehydrated, anti-euthanasia protesters held a vigil outside the southwestern Missouri state hospital. Nineteen protesters were arrested when they tried to enter her room. The protesters said they feared the case would turn the rehabilitation center into a mecca for people seeking euthanasia for family members. Ms. Cruzan's parents' legal battle led to the first U.S. Supreme Court ruling in a right-to-die case. The court said states can require ``clear and convincing'' evidence that the patient would want to die. Busalacchi has not taken his daughter's case to court. He said several doctors have told him his daughter is not likely to recover, but that some hospital staff members said she has shown improvement. Administrator Don Lamkins said the center would not try to prevent Busalacchi from moving his daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Four Convicted in Multimillion-Dollar Laundering Scheme
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT amount of money allegedly laundered to $350 million sted $1 billion; INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf pvs, `Federal prosecutors...', to add that $1 billion figure was cited earlier. CORRECTS spelling of Colombian throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Two Argentine nationals and two local jewelry dealers have been convicted of laundering $350 million in Colombian drug profits through jewelry markets. It was the biggest money-laundering case ever tried in this country, prosecutors said. Raul Vivas, 38, of Argentina and jewelry dealers Nazareth and Vahe Andonian of Los Angeles each were convicted Wednesday of 25 felony counts of money laundering and one count of conspiracy to launder money. Juan Carlos Seresi, also from Argentina, was convicted of 20 felony money laundering counts and a conspiracy count. Each money laundering count carries a maximum 20-year prison term. The conspiracy count carries a maximum prison term of five years. Federal court jurors said they were unable to reach verdicts on narcotics conspiracy counts against the four defendants. The panel also failed to reach verdicts on 27 counts against Ruben Saini, another Argentine, accused of helping to destroy evidence. U.S. District Judge William Keller ordered jurors Thursday to resume deliberations on those counts. Federal prosecutors claimed Vivas created a laundering operation dubbed ``La Mina,'' or ``the mine,'' that was based on a triangular trade of drugs, gold and cash by Colombian drug traders. Though the amount cited by prosecutors in the trial was $350 million, in the past, investigators have said the amount laundered by ``La Mina'' could total $1 billion in Los Angeles and other cities including New York and Miami. The network used drug profits to buy gold through jewelers for Colombian cocaine traffickers, prosecutors said. Officials of Wells Fargo Bank in Los Angeles told federal officials the Andonians, who operated Andonian Brothers Jewelry in Los Angeles, had deposited $25 million in cash during a three-month period. Earlier this month, the jury acquitted four jewelry company employees charged with playing lesser roles in the organization.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi's Remarks Anger Secular Israelis, Holocaust Survivors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 7-8, `Earlier this...' with 2 grafs to CORRECT sequence of coalition building, source of demand for Orthodox laws. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `The Knesset...'
DOC.TEXT: An ultra-Orthodox rabbi considered to be a political kingmaker has enraged religious and secular Israelis by saying the Holocaust was God's punishment for sins such as violating the Sabbath and eating pork. ``Not for a long time has any single remark caused such an emotional reaction,'' said Razi Barkai, host of a radio talk show that was flooded with hundreds of calls Thursday over the remarks of Rabbi Eliezer Schach. Barkai said calls ran about 3-to-2 against the 97-year-old rabbi, who said another disaster may befall Jews for violating traditional religious tenets. ``The last time he brought destruction, it was the Holocaust ... Because of the sins, the Almighty may bring another Holocaust upon us, and it may already be tomorrow,'' Schach told Jewish seminary students earlier this week. About 6 million Jews died in the Nazi genocide during World War II, and tens of thousands of survivors live in Israel. Five percent of Israel's Jewish residents are ultra-Orthodox, while 70 percent define themselves as secular. ``Rabbi Schach today is one of the most powerful men in Israeli politics and each one of his words creates a lot of noise,'' said sociologist Menachem Friedman, an expert on religious communities. Earlier this year, Schach helped Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir form a government by ordering his followers to join Shamir's coalition. The support of two factions loyal to Schach gave Shamir 60 votes in the 120-member parliament. Shamir also had a promise of support from the two-seat ultra-rightist Moledet faction, which stayed outside the coalition. In exchange for the support of another ultra-Orthodox faction, Agudat Israel, the government party asked for a series of reform laws, including a ban on sexually suggestive ads and sale of pork, forbidden by Jewish dietary laws. The Knesset, or parliament, earlier this month outlawed outdoor advertising that features scantily clad people. It is expected to take up some of the other proposals soon. The proposed laws have angered many secular Israelis, who claim the ultra-Orthodox minority carries too much influence. Schach's comments on the Holocaust was simply repeating a theme common in the Bible: of divine retribution against the Jewish people for straying from the path of their religious law. But on another level, many took his remarks to mean that the Jews somehow were to blame for the Nazis' behavior. ``The Almighty keeps a balance sheet of the world, and when the sins become too many, he brings destruction. We don't know how long his patience holds out, sometimes 20 years, sometimes 10 and sometimes only a year,'' Schach said. Schach's chief rival, Brooklyn-based Rabbi Menachem Schneersohn, told supporters Thursday the Jews who died in the Holocaust were ``pure and holy.'' ``Heaven forbid someone should say that the Jews sinned in some way and God settled accounts with them and imposed on them the most terrible sentence of the past generation,'' said Schneersohn, the politically influential leader of the Hasidic Habad movement. Some of Schach's sharpest critics were Holocaust survivors. Menahem Russak, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp and a former commander of the Israeli police unit investigating Nazi war crimes, said Schach ``shamed and humiliated'' millions of Holocaust victims. His voice shaking, Russak told listeners that Schach ``not only exonerated the Nazi murderers, but turned them into messengers of God who were sent to punish the people of Israel for not observing the Torah.'' But another caller, an ultra-Orthodox woman who lost relatives in the Holocaust, defended the rabbi. ``With al the pain I have, I can understand his words. We believe in the link between sin and punishment,'' said the woman, who did not give her name. Friedman said Schach's views reflect ultra-Orthodox thinking prevalent since the 1950s. But secular Israelis only began listening after the ultra-Orthodox left their self-chosen isolation and entered Israeli politics in the 1980s, Friedman said. The secular public tends to stereotype ultra-Orthodox Jews like Schach as throwbacks to the Jews' ghetto years who never embraced the Zionist cause. For one thing, they speak Yiddish, the language of the ghetto in Europe, rather than Hebrew.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Says Philippines Can Meet Swiss Deadline on Marcos Money
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino said today her government would meet conditions set by a Swiss court for the return of $350 million deposited in Switzerland by the late President Ferdinand Marcos. In a decision made public Thursday, the Swiss Supreme Court ruled the money must be returned as soon as a competent Philippine criminal court has issued a ``legally binding'' verdict in a case against Marcos and his wife, Imelda. The money has been frozen in several Swiss banks since March 1986. The order set a one-year deadline for the Philippine government to complete legal proceedings. It said that if no verdict is returned within that period, Swiss banks would end their seizure of the assets. ``The decision of Switzerland's Federal Supreme Court should be hailed as a victory for the Filipino people,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement. ``For our part, we are confident that we will be able to fulfill the conditions within the time frame available.'' Neither Marcos, who died in September 1989, nor his widow, Imelda, has ever been charged with a criminal offense in the Philippines because the government feared they would demand their right to return from exile and face trial. But David Castro, chairman of the Presidential Commission on Good Government, said the government did not have to file criminal charges against the Marcoses to meet the terms of the Swiss order. Castro said a guilty verdict in civil suits for embezzlement against the Marcoses handed down by an anti-graft court would satisfy the Swiss Supreme Court requirement. Castro said the Philippine Supreme Court has ruled in the past that a civil suit whose penalty is forfeiture of assets was ``penal in nature'' as in a criminal case. He said the government's Swiss lawyers assured him that this formula would satisfy the Swiss Supreme Court. The government has filed 35 civil cases against the Marcoses and their close associates in the anti-graft court. In Bern, however, Justice Ministry spokesman Joerg Kistler said the Swiss government has ``no reason to doubt that the Philippines will open criminal proceedings'' in the case. He said it was ``clear that criminal proceedings have to be conducted and that the accused will have to be granted all the rights of defense provided for by the federal constitution and the European Human Rights Convention.'' Marcos and his family fled to Hawaii after a popular revolt toppled his 20-year rule and swept Mrs. Aquino to the presidency. Mrs. Aquino banned the return of the Marcos family, citing security threats. The Aquino government claims Marcos and his associates embezzled up to $10 billion but has offered little evidence to substantiate that figure. In the four years since Marcos' ouster, the government has managed to retrieve only $400 million, mostly from Marcos' associates. Castro said the government expects to find more of Marcos' ``hidden wealth'' after it obtains seized bank records, which under the Swiss Supreme Court ruling can be handed over to the Philippine government.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Commission Honors 16 For Heroism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `I thought...', to DELETE incorrect reference to phone interview being done from his home, add what he does for a living. SUBS 20th graf, `-Robert W...', to add that both men listed in that graf are from Ojai.
DOC.TEXT: A Georgia man who rushed from his bed to save a woman from drowning was among 16 people honored for heroism, including four people who died trying to help others. The awards were announced Thursday by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission, based in Pittsburgh. Andrew ``Skeet'' Moss, honored for saving Kelley Gibbs after her car was swept off a flooded street last March, recalled how he wasn't sure what was going on when the woman's screams awakened him. ``I thought it was a cat screaming and finally, my wife said, `Get up! Get up! There's a woman screaming,' '' Moss, an air traffic controller from McDonough, Ga., said Thursday in a telephone interview. He threw on a pair of jeans and rushed outside to find the 19-year-old in the creek at the edge of his yard. He waded in, braced himself against a tree and pulled her to safety. ``I was scared to death the whole time. The current was real strong and I wasn't exactly sure where I was,'' he said. ``I just didn't want to do the wrong thing.'' Moss, 30, and the other heroes or their survivors each will receive a Carnegie Medal and $2,500. The commission presents awards about every two months to people who risk their lives to help others. Industrialist Andrew Carnegie founded the panel in 1904 after a mine accident near Pittsburgh killed 178 people, including some who tried to save others. Thursday's awards bring to 106 the number of people recognized in 1990 and to 7,511 those honored in the United States and Canada since the commission was established. Also honored Thursday were: -Jonathon E.J. Swenson, 9, Sumner, Wash., who died after trying to save his aunt and two cousins from a burning house Feb. 4, 1989. When the house caught fire, he ran upstairs to alert the others. He was overcome by smoke and died two days later. -Jessie R. Moore, 29, Rocky Mount, N.C., a laborer who died Aug. 5, 1989, trying to save an 8-year-old girl from drowning in the Atlantic Ocean at Beaufort, N.C. The girl, who could not swim and had fallen off an inner tube, survived. -Clayton M. Cutter, 31, a forestry technician who died trying to save three teen-age campers and a counselor from drowning Feb. 19, 1990, at Mammoth Lakes, Calif. The campers, their counselor, another counselor and a firefighter also drowned in the icy lake. -Rickey Lee Dewey, 27, Lexington, Neb., a farm hand who died Aug. 6, 1989, trying to save his 19-year-old cousin from drowning. The younger man, who could not swim, had fallen into a canal from a bridge. -John A. McDaniel, 26, Summerville, Ga., a cotton-mill laborer who saved an 11-year-old boy from drowning June 11, 1989, in a river in Fort Payne, Ala. McDaniel entered the river and grabbed the boy and held him at the brink of 60-foot-high falls until the two were pulled from the water by others. -Kurt Ernst, 31, Rochester, N.Y., a meter reader who saved a 2-year-old boy and his 6-month-old sister from burning Dec. 2, 1989. Ernst saw the flames as he was driving past the family's apartment. He crawled through a window, found the boy and handed him to another person outside. Ernst returned to find the girl and her mother on the floor. He carried the infant to the window and arriving firefighters saved the mother and another child. -Darryl W. Lastiwka, 29, Thorold, Ontario, a carpenter who rescued a 21-year-old woman from her burning apartment Nov. 30, 1989. Lastiwka, a neighbor, crawled on the floor under smoke, found the unconscious woman on the kitchen floor and carried her to safety. -Patrick M. Maloney, 27, Chicago, a paramedic who saved a man from being assaulted with a knife by an enraged motorist at the scene of an auto accident Dec. 31, 1988. -John E. Moore, 43, Dunn, N.C., and Ronnie Gene Woodall, 36, Benson, N.C., who helped rescue a 26-year-old woman from a burning car Dec. 5, 1989, after a highway accident. -Robert W. Lemon, 40, and Timothy L. Donoghue, 43, both of Ojai, Calif., who pulled a semiconscious woman from a burning car after a highway accident Feb. 5, 1990. -Dwayne E. Hofus, 24, Youngstown, Ohio, who saved a 2-year-old girl and her 3-year-old sister from the second floor of their burning house June 10, 1989. -Lewis Dale Collins, 46, Lawrenceville, Ga., an electrical worker who rescued an 18-year-old woman who was trapped in a burning car following a March 2, 1990, highway accident. -Jeffrey Allen Quigley, 28, Hampton, Va., a service station attendant who pulled an 83-year-old man from his burning house April 19, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Sends Desert Shield Reinforcements
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The Roosevelt...', to correct that carriers all in Mideast waters, but not all near Saudi Arabia.
DOC.TEXT: About 16,000 sailors and Marines began leaving today for the Middle East as the Navy beefs up its Operation Desert Shield forces. The deployments of 17 ships from East Coast ports, including eight from the huge Norfolk Naval Base, involved a rare same-day departure for two aircraft carriers, the USS America and the USS Theodore Roosevelt. Several dozen tearful relatives lined the piers in a brisk breeze and drizzle as the destroyer USS Caron, one of the earliest ships to leave, pulled out about 8 a.m. Joseph Leyes, whose son, Louis, is an ensign aboard the Caron, said he felt a mixture of emotions: ``sad, excited, supportive, frightened.'' ``They're going to go out there; they're going to do a job; they're going to come back,'' he said. Donna Beckum, whose husband, Larry, also is a Caron crewman, said her main concern was ``just how long they're going to be gone.'' The Roosevelt and America, which were to sail early in the afternoon, will join three other carriers - the USS Kennedy, USS Saratoga and USS Ranger - already operating in the Middle East, where thousands of U.S. forces have been sent since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The deployment of such a large number of U.S. warships to one part of the world is unprecedented since the Vietnam war. Capt. Charles S. Abbot, commanding officer of the Roosevelt, said his crew was prepared, though not eager, to leave home so soon after the holiday. ``There's really no discontent that I've observed,'' said Abbot, whose ship's last deployment was almost 18 months ago. Still, Christmas was bittersweet for those shipping out and their families. ``I'm happy he was here for Christmas, but I'm upset he's leaving and not knowing when he's coming back,'' said Carmen Kubala, whose husband, Dan, is an electrician aboard the America. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the U.N. has set a Jan. 15 deadline for it to withdraw or face possible military action. Navy officials said the carriers will take about two weeks to get to their destination.

DOC.HEAD: Court Finds 63 People Guilty For Taking Part in Riots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with 63 people found guilty of rioting, separate investigatory commission formed by human rights advocates. Pickup 9th pvs, `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: A court found 63 people guilty today for taking part in nationwide rioting two weeks ago that left at least five people dead. The rioting Dec. 14-15 broke out in several cities in this North African country during a general strike by the nation's two largest labor unions. Two human rights groups today formed an independent commission to determine who fired during clashes between rioters and security forces in Fez that led to the deaths. The panel will also determine how many peopl died. The government said five people were killed, but the trade unions say about 30 died. Parliament on Thursday created a separate commission of 25 legislators to investigate the disturbances. The court in Kenitra, near Rabat, today found 63 people guilty of rioting. Eleven people were sentenced to two years in prison and 22 to one year. The remaining rioters received terms ranging from one to three months. The sentences come a day after officials announced that 87 people had received stiff jail sentences - some as long as seven years - for taking part in disturbances in Fez, Meknes and Tangiers. Fez, the country's spiritual and intellectual capital, was the site of the most extensive violence. Soldiers and police intervened as rioters attacked hotels, post offices and a police station. The government is negotiating this week with unions and employers on ``priority measures'' promised after the disturbances. Among the measures under consideration are increases in minimum wages and in social allocations.

DOC.HEAD: More Snow For the Pacific Northwest; Warmer in South, Midwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 24 grafs to UPDATE with power outage in Washington, snow accumulation in New York, morning road conditions in West Virginia, commuter delays in Pennsylvania; quotes. DELETES outdates material. Picks up 15th graf pvs: `In San ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Cold-Citrus, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Snow returned to the normally rainy Pacific Northwest today, making roads treacherous and knocking out power, and several inches fell in the East a few days after many cities recorded their warmest Christmas ever. Forecasters said a second ``Yukon Express'' air mass could send the mercury plummeting again in California, where record cold devastated citrus crops last week. Temperatures could dip into the low 20s in some valley locations tonight even before the second arctic blast arrives. Cold and stormy weather have been blamed for more than 80 deaths nationwide in the past 10 days. Seattle, known for rain, got heavy snow for the second time in a week. Washington state residents stocked up on tire chains, flashlights and candles. ``We are pretty much prepared this time,'' said Jeanne Grijalva, emergency management coordinator for Kitsap County. ``It won't catch everyone off guard like it did last week. That was one of the worst storms people in this county had seen for years.'' Some 6 inches of snow fell on hills east of the Seattle metropolitan area, the weather service said. Three inches hit downtown Everett, but little of the snow that fell on Seattle stuck. At least 34,000 customers were without electricity today because of downed power lines, said Teri Van Duine, spokeswoman for Puget Power, the region's largest utility. Strong winds in central Oregon caused trees to tumble, damaging automobiles and power lines. A Bend fireman was seriously injured by a falling tree while helping clear debris on a roadway, sheriff's deputies said. In New York City, 7 inches of snow fell by 6 a.m. today in Central Park, just a few days after record warm weather saw temperatures rise into the 60s. By late morning, the snow had changed to freezing rain. The city mobilized hundreds of salt-spreading trucks and snowplows. Motorists were urged to leave their cars at home. Bob Lavner, a spokesman for the Automobile Association of America, said the timing of the storm would hold down traffic problems and reduce calls for emergency service. ``It's a Friday at the end of a holiday week. The volume of cars on the road is going to be down and people are going to stay home because of the snowfall,'' Lavner said. The winter's first major snowstorm slowed commuter traffic in Pennsylvania's metropolitan areas, but few problems were reported. ``Everything appears to be under control and (today's) rain will make everything slushy, and should pretty much melt all this away,'' said Deborah Weisberg, a spokeswoman for the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation in Pittsburgh. Delays of 10 to 20 minutes were reported during the morning rush on some regional rail and bus routes in the Philadelphia area. Martinsburg, W.Va., was buried under at least 10 inches of snow and freezing rain turned West Virginia's highways into skating rinks, authorities said today. ``We don't have any roads shut down per se. But they're bad, real bad,'' Berkeley County emergency services dispatcher Robin Taylor said. ``They're just full of snow.'' ``The cars are all over the place. They're a mess.'' Ohio's first major storm of the winter dumped 8 inches of snow on Cincinnati and other southwestern cities Thursday, but the precipitation changed to rain this morning. Highs in the 40s were forecast, and the much of the snow was expected to melt. In Hedgesville, W.Va., four members of one family died and two were missing when their car plunged off a bridge into a creek on Wednesday, authorities said. Recent rain and snow swelled the creek to twice its normal 4-foot depth, and water covered the bridge. Rescuers today resumed their search for two boys who were still missing. In Indianapolis, a homeless woman was found dead outside an abandoned service station, and authorities said she probably died of hypothermia when the thermometer plunged into the single digits Wednesday night. Warmer temperatures were expected today in Indiana, where icy roads and accumulations of 6 or more inches of snow forced hundreds of holiday travelers to check into motels Thursday. Police reported hundreds of accidents, but no traffic deaths. A blizzard in North Dakota dropped visibility to near zero in some areas Thursday night and forecasters said wind chills could drop to 40 to 60 below in the western and central part of the state today. ``It could be close to impossible to travel,'' said Bob Nordland, a forecaster at the National Weather Service in Fargo. Temperatures were expected to reach the 50s by the weekend. In San Francisco, the record cold wave drove ants indoors in search of warmth and food. ``People are frantic, some hysterical,'' said Ann McDonald, whose husband, Rich, owns a pest control company. One of McDonald's customers in Sausalito left half a cake out Christmas night. When she got up the next morning she found ``the ants had taken over.'' ``They were all over everything,'' Dorothy McLaird said. The counters and cupboards were alive with what McDonald estimated as 30,000 ants.

DOC.HEAD: Two Escapees Shoot Themselves When Cornered
LaserPhotos TOK7,9
DOC.TEXT: Two escaped prisoners killed themselves with a revolver today rather than surrender to police approaching their lakeside hideout in helicopters and rubber boats. The shootings ended a 36-hour chase for three convicted murderers who broke out of their jail early Thursday by sawing through bars in their cell, police said. Hundreds of police were mobilized for the manhunt. One escapee was caught near the rural lake outside the provincial city of Taejon. When police found him, he surrendered peacefully and asked for food, police said. The other two - Park Bong-sun, 30, and Shin Kwang-jae, 21 - crossed the lake aboard a stolen boat but were trapped by a dozen sharpshooters on the shore. Civilians, including news photographers, witnessed the dramatic lakeside standoff. The two rejected repeated calls to surrender, with Park holding the revolver to his head and threatening to shoot himself. As police approached in helicopters and rubber boats, Park fired a bullet into his head. Shin then took the gun and fired a bullet into his chest. He died on the way to a hospital. The revolver had been stolen from a policemen earlier today, when the escapees, armed with a knife, had been stopped for questioning at a bus terminal in Taejon, 100 miles south of Seoul. A police officer was stabbed in his neck and seriously injured during that confrontation.

DOC.HEAD: Millions of Dollars in Drug Grants Go Unspent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 2-3 pvs, `States have ... policy office,' with 3 grafs to Clarify that Carnes released the figures but they weren't included in a report; SUBS 13th graf pvs bgng, `The drug,' with 1 graf to show arguments against giving money directly to cities came from the report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Drug Grants-States
DOC.TEXT: Millions of dollars in federal funds provided to the states to fight the war against drugs are going unspent, the Office of National Drug Control Policy says. States have been spending just two-thirds of their federal grants aimed at fighting drugs over the last four years, the White House agency said Thursday. The situation is most striking for law enforcement grants, where states have spent only 40 percent of the federal money they have received, said Bruce Carnes, director of planning, budget and administration for the drug policy office. ``I think what's bringing the spending level down is the law enforcement grant, because there were such enormous increases in that in the last two years,'' said Carnes, who released the figures as his office issued a report on block grants given to states over the past few years. Anti-drug block grants issued by the Justice Department dropped from $178 million in the 1987 fiscal year to a low of $56 million in 1988. They jumped back to $119 million in 1989 before zooming to $395 million in fiscal 1990, which ended Sept. 30. They climb to $423 million this year. ``There's going to be a huge wave of money,'' Carnes said. ``It started to descend on them in '89 and '90, and it's going to keep going up this year.'' Carnes said states spent 82 percent of their drug treatment and prevention grants, 46 percent of their drug education grants and 40 percent of their law enforcement grants. Overall, the three block grant programs sent $5 billion to the states from October 1986 through June 1990. Only $3.4 billion, or 68 percent, of that amount was distributed during that time by state and territorial governments to anti-drug programs, the figures show. ``Obviously I'd like to see it higher, but I'm not prepared to say they're not doing their jobs,'' Carnes said. Among the states, top-ranked Arizona spent 83.4 percent of the $77.7 million it received. Second was Nevada, spending 79 percent of $26.7 million, followed by the U.S. territories, which spent 77 percent of $63.3 million. Trailing the list, Puerto Rico spent only 34.2 percent of the $31.7 million it received, Hawaii spent 52 percent of $27.4 million and Wyoming 55 percent of $14.1 million. Hawaii Attorney General Warren Price said county prosecutors and police departments in the state use county funds for anti-drug efforts and later seek reimbursement from the federal grants. He said this sets up a time lag that makes it look as if the federal funds aren't being spent quickly. The drug policy office said in the report that it opposes giving such grants directly to cities on grounds that doing so would place too heavy a paperwork and administrative burden on the federal government. ``Instead of speeding up the process, the time required at the federal level to review thousands of applications from local governments would almost certainly slow it down,'' it said in the report. States ``are closer to the problem than federal administrators and can more quickly react to changes in local requirements,'' it added. Governors oppose giving the money directly to cities, but mayors complain that the states fail to send the money to the places that need it the most. Former New York City police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said mayors believe that while recreational users in the suburbs may be driving the drug problem, the most severe crisis is elsewhere. ``The worst problems - the murder and violence among the kids who get into the traffic and the delays for treatment for low-income people who don't have health insurance - are in the cities,'' said Murphy, who directs the U.S. Conference of Mayors' police policy board.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in the Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: --- These are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: --- About 16,000 sailors and Marines were to begin leaving U.S. ports Friday for the gulf aboard 17 ships, including the aircraft carriers America and Theodore Roosevelt from the Norfolk Naval Base in Virginia. Three aircraft carriers are already in the Middle East. The deployment of so many U.S. warships to one part of the world is unprecedented since the Vietnam War. --- The Pentagon was reportedly planning inoculations for troops against biological warfare. The New York Times reported Friday that the inoculations could begin ``within a matter of weeks.'' Army Lt. Col. Steve Roy, a spokesman for the Department of Defense, refused to comment on the report, which quoted unidentified administration officials. --- Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu urged U.S. officials on Friday to hold talks with Iraq to avert a war, Kyodo News Service reported. Kaifu made a similar request in a letter to Saddam Hussein on Wednesday, in which he also called for the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. --- More than 250 Soviets left Iraq for home, and Soviet Deputy Premier Igor Belousov met with Iraqi leaders in Baghdad seeking an agreement to terminate Soviet companies' contracts with Iraq, officials reported. The Soviets left on an Aeroflot airliner shortly after midnight. About 1,000 others will be airlifted by Soviet and Iraqi airliners by Jan. 10.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops To Be Inoculated Against Germ Warfare
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said today it plans to begin vaccinating U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf against possible germ warfare. The vaccinations are part of a plan to protect U.S. troops against the possibility that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may use chemical or biological weapons if war breaks out. ``We are committed to providing maximum protection for our troops, including protection against chemical and biological weapons,'' said a brief Pentagon statement. ``We expect to begin a program of inoculations soon,'' it said. The statement did not provide further details, and a spokeswoman said more may be available later in the day. The New York Times reported in its Friday editions that senior administration officials recommended the inoculations as part of a broader plan that also includes the use of masks and other protective garments. CIA Director William Webster said recently that Iraq has a large stockpile of biological weapons. Saddam has repeatedly denied it. Iraq used chemical weapons against some rebellious Kurds in its own country and against Iran during its war with that country. As a result, U.S. troops in the Gulf have been given protective clothing and have undergone training on how to protect themselves against an attack of poison gas. The Times said it was unclear how many troops might be vaccinated. The administration plans to deploy more than 400,000 troops in the region, and all are expected to be in place within several weeks. The Times said the inoculations could begin ``in a matter of weeks.'' Biological weapons are based on living agents like viruses and bacteria, and they cause diseases such as typhoid and cholera.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Follows Requests by Military Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Shankar, Cabinet presenting resignations to parliament. Pickup 8th pvs, `The 13-nation...'
DOC.TEXT: President Ramsewak Shankar and his Cabinet have presented their resignations to parliament, which is expected to name a new president and vice president by Saturday. As the country's elected parliamentarians somberly sat in silence Thursday night, Vice President Henck Arron handed the resignations to National Assembly President Jaggernath Lachmon. Arron said the Cabinet had already resigned. The armed forces of this nation in northern South America overthrew Shankar without bloodshed on Monday and urged the parliament to elect new chief executives and hold national elections within 100 days. Lachman asked Shankar and Arron to remain in office until their resignations were formally accepted, which is expected Saturday despite domestic and international condemnation of the military overthrow. Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst, the acting army chief, claimed on Thursday that the military's overthrow of Shankar allowed by the constitution. He denied the takeover was a military coup. The new chief executive will appoint a Cabinet and set a date for national elections to be held within three months, military leaders said. Guido Grooscors, Venezuela's ambassador to the Organization of American States, whose members include Suriname, called the takeover a ``severe violation of the principles of the OAS charter.'' The 13-nation Caribbean Community, known as Caricom, issued a statement by its chairman, Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley, expressing ``dismay and outrage'' and demanding full restoration of democracy in the former Dutch colony of 400,000 people. Manley said otherwise Caricom members may ``reconsider the future relationship with Suriname and the Caribbean Community.'' Suriname does not belong to Caricom. The first public criticism at home was contained in an editorial published Thursday by the daily newspaper De Ware Tyd. ``Reduced to its essentials, the army has simply imposed its will on the government,'' the newspaper said. The Council of Labor Union Federations, which represents organized labor in Suriname, issued a statement rejecting the army's interpretation of the constitution, approved approved by a plebiscite in 1987. The council noted that its objection was in spite of its displeasure with the Shankar government. Graanoogst became acting army chief Saturday after military strongman Desi Bouterse resigned in a dispute with Shankar. Bouterse, as chairman of the five-commander Military Authority, remains the most powerful figure in the country. Bouterse came to power after a 1980 military coup deposed Arron, then president. Bouterse headed a military dictatorship that ruled the Georgia-sized nation until parliamentary elections were held in 1987. Shankar's three-party coalition, the Front for Democracy and Development, won by a landslide. The assembly elected him in 1988 to a five-year term as president. Shankar's overthrow coincided with growing popular discontent with his government's inability to revive the economy, beset by high inflation and unemployment. The government has a monthly trade deficit of $10 million. The economic decline began during Bouterse's rule. Major factors included a fall in prices for bauxite, the country's main export, and guerrilla attacks that disrupted bauxite and aluminum production. The Netherlands suspended the development aid in 1982 after the massacre of 15 opposition leaders while in military detention. Bouterse had accused them of plotting his overthrow.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Drug Law Ruled Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: A state law providing for a four-year sentence for first-time crack users and probation for first-time users of powdered cocaine is racially biased - and thus unconstitutional, a judge has ruled. Hennepin County District Judge Pamela Alexander ruled Thursday that state sentencing guidelines are flawed, saying there is no logical reason why people convicted for possession crack should be treated any differently from those convicted of possessing any other form of cocaine. Assistant Hennepin County attorney Chuck Sweetland said if the ruling issued Thursday is upheld, it could affect 100 cases in his county alone. It will be appealed to the state Supreme Court, he said. ``If this isn't reversed, it is going to make it impossible to prosecute the vast majority of urban crack cases,'' Sweetland said. Attorneys for five suspects who challenged the crack law said 92 percent of people arrested on charges of possession of crack in 1988 were black, while 85 percent of people arrested on charges of possessing powdered cocaine were white. Crack is cocaine in the form of highly purified, pebble-like nuggets that can be smoked. ``Cocaine is cocaine,'' the judge said in her ruling. ``So regardless of the form that it's in, it should be treated the same, and all persons charged under that should be treated the same regardless of whether they're black, white, pink or purple.'' Under the statute, which took effect Aug. 1, 1989, the recommended punishment for a first offender convicted of crack possession is a four-year prison term but possession of cocaine calls for only probation. State Rep. Randy Kelly, one of the legislators who drafted the tougher sentencing for crack, said he was stunned by the judge's ruling. ``We never ever considered that it was going to be applied unequally to people of color or whatever,'' Kelly said. ``Our major concerns were its potency, its absolutely devastating influence on people, its cheapness and its attractiveness in terms o selling to children. Those were the concerns.'' Alexander's ruling is binding only in Hennepin County unless it is affirmed by an appellate court, according to James E. Konen, head of the Criminal Division for the Ramsey County Attorney's Office. Until the high court rules, no convicted user will be freed. But Sweetland said about 15 suspects awaiting trial in Hennepin County could get out of jail immediately. A Supreme Court decision is not expected for several months.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead, Two Missing After Family's Car Plunges Off Bridge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Divers planned ..., with 2 grafs to UPDATE with search resuming. Pick up 3rd graf, `The bodies ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A car plunged off a flooded bridge, killing four members of a family and leaving two others missing, officials said. Divers resumed searching this morning for Chris Wiesner Jr., 5, and his brother, Josh, 2, in Back Creek near Hedgesville. The search had been called off during the night because of heavy snow and strong current in the creek. Rescuers decided to resume out of fear that the creek would swell even more when the snow begins to melt, police Cpl. Dennis Streets said. The bodies of the boys' parents, grandfather and stepbrother were recovered up to 2 miles downstream from the bridge. The family was returning from a Christmas visit to relatives in Baltimore when the car fell off the bridge early Wednesday, said Preston Gooden, Berkeley County sheriff. The creek, swollen by recent rain and snow to twice its normal depth of 4 feet, is over the bridge's surface. A motorist noticed the car submerged in the creek Wednesday afternoon and called police. The driver's window was open, suggesting the passengers may have climbed out, Gooden said. Searchers found the body of the boys' grandfather, Richard Wiesner, 62, late Thursday night. Earlier they found the bodies of the boys' parents, Laurie Wiesner, 30, and Chris Wiesner Sr., 31, and their stepbrother, George Hall, 10.

DOC.HEAD: City Proposes State Oversight Authority
DOC.TEXT: The state of Pennsylvania would assume some control over Philadelphia's spending under a new plan to rescue the city from bankruptcy. The proposal outlined Thursday by City Treasurer Benjamin Blakney calls for creation of an oversight authority that would borrow money to cover a $229.5 million shortfall in the fiscal year ending June 30. The city would be required to provide ``assurances that the means are in hand to prevent deficits in the future,'' he said. Blakney presented the plan during testimony before the City Council's new Select Committee on Fiscal Stability and Intergovernmental Cooperation. The committee's chairman, Councilman John F. Street, said the authority would be granted additional powers if Philadelphia proved unable to balance its budget after the deficit was eliminated. Details of an oversight body would be determined by the state Legislature, which convenes next week but won't get down to business until the last week of January. ``In the weeks ahead, we will be urging all involved parties to support the creation of a new authority that can provide and control the borrowing capacity ... of the city,'' Blakney said. Mayor W. Wilson Goode, City Controller Jonathan A. Saidel and other Democratic leaders have urged creation of an oversight entity whose powers would be triggered if the city failed to pass realistically balanced budgets. A consortium of banks, in loan negotiations with the city, last week put forth a recovery plan that would create an independent board with line-item veto power over city spending. In recent weeks, the city has sought to sell up to $300 million in short-term notes to local banks and two pension boards to keep essential bills paid through winter. Banks have trimmed the request to $150 million, which would allow the city to meet its payroll but not pay all its debts to suppliers and service providers, while a long-term solution to the city's fiscal ills is worked out. Goode said Wednesday that the city would not be able to pay employees a full salary after next week.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Begin Between Sikh Leader, Prime Minister on Separatist Demands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with talks beginning, Sikh leader demanding extremist groups have role in talks. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar today opened talks with a Sikh leader aimed at ending a 7-year-old secessionist conflict in Punjab that has claimed thousands of lives. The talks were the most serious attempt at discussing the dispute since a peace accord between the Sikhs and the government collapsed in 1986. The meeting follows a conference two days ago by three rival Sikh political groups that authorized a Sikh leader, Simranjit Singh Mann, to meet the prime minister to negotiate self-determination for the wealthy northern state. Mann, a former police officer who was accused of plotting the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, said he would try to broaden the talks to include outlawed militant organizations. ``We want to involve the militants. They are the ones who are laying down their lives,'' Mann said, reached by telephone before meeting the prime minister. Mann told journalists before entering the prime minister's residence that he had come with the mandate for securing the right of self-determination for the people of Punjab. On Thursday, the five-member Panthic committee controlling the most powerful extremist groups issued a statement that it would consider talks with the government if a venue and agenda could be agreed. The group is said to control the most powerful extremist groups. The statement reportedly suggested talks in Geneva or the United Nations. It said Pakistan should act as an observer in the talks. Pakistan supports the Sikhs' political claims but denies allegations by India that it also provides aid and shelter to the militants. The prime minister has ruled out independence for Punjab, but he says he's willing to negotiate constitutional amendments to overcome Sikh grievances. Mann declined to predict the results of the talks or say how long they will last. He also refused to say if he would consider a moratorium on violence while the talks were under way. Mann served five years in prison on sedition charges and was to stand trial for conspiracy in Mrs. Gandhi's murder when he was elected to Parliament in 1989. Charges against him were dropped by the government of Rajiv Gandhi, Mrs. Gandhi's son, and he was released from jail. Punjab has been under federal rule since 1987, when a campaign of assassination and intimidation intensified against Hindus and Sikh moderates. Unofficial accounts say the militants have killed more than 3,260 people in the past year. The toll makes 1990 the bloodiest year since the extremists began their campaign to separate from India in 1983. Sikhs say they are targets of discrimination in this Hindu-dominated country, where they comprise 2 percent of the 880 million population.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NEW YORK: officials said.
DOC.TEXT: Transit Authority spokeswoman Caren Gardner said the deaths occurred after a weather-related fire broke out on the third rail in the subway tunnel underneath a Brooklyn street. One of those killed was a 35-year-old woman, Gardner said, but she did not know whether she or the other victim was a passenger. Lynn Schulman, a spokeswoman for Emergency Medical Services, said there were about 100 people injured in the accident, which occurred in the tunnel used by the No. 2 and No. 3 subway lines.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Infant Exhumed After Mother Confesses To Killing Three
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `From Michigan ..., to CORRECT spelling of Donochick, sted Donchick; SUBS 5th graf, `Wayland police ..., with 2 grafs to CORRECT that baby died in neighboring county, sted lived there, and UPDATE with status of case; pick up 6th graf, `At the ...
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the body of an infant who died in 1983 exhumed after her 23-year-old mother confessed to suffocating her and also killing two other children since then. Diane L. Spencer of Wayland, Mich., is being held in the Allegan County (Mich.) Jail charged with first-degree murder in the September death of her 6-month-old son Aaron A. Spencer. From Michigan, she wrote to Pennsylvania authorities to protest the planned exhumation of her daughter Joyce A. Donochick, who died in 1983 at age 6 weeks. Parts of the letter were read aloud in court Thursday. But Clearfield County Judge John Reilly Jr. ruled nevertheless that Joyce's body should be examined by forensic pathologists. ``I believe this to be totally unnecessary at this point and am willing to do whatever I myself or authorities in Pennsylvania deem necessary to prevent the exhumation,'' Spencer wrote. Wayland police Chief Dan Millerhas said Spencer admitted smothering the boy and also confessed to killing Joyce in 1983 and another daughter, 17-day-old Autumn Dawn Spencer, in 1987. Clearfield County Coroner R. Joel Heath said Joyce's body would be exhumed within two weeks. A woman in the Clearfield County district attorney's office who refused to identify herself said today that investigators were also reviewing records of an autopsy done after the death of Autumn Spencer, who lived in Clearfield County but was pronounced dead at a hospital in neighboring Centre County. At the time, authorities believed the children died of sudden infant death syndrome. Pennsylvania authorities have not filed charges related to the deaths of Spencer's daughters. A first-degree murder conviction in Pennsylvania carries a possible sentence of death in the electric chair. At the time of Aaron's death three months ago, the child's father was in jail on drug charges, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-President to End Internal Exile This Weekend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with dissidents' association comment. Pickup 3rd, `Chun and...'
DOC.TEXT: Chun Doo-hwan, the disgraced former president, will return to his house in the capital over the weekend, ending his two-year rural exile in a remote temple, aides said today. Chun's aides, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he will leave the 14th century Buddhist temple in the eastern mountains on Sunday. A dissidents' association in southern Kwangju issued a statement saying the people would not accept Chun's return. ``We warn against restoration of a suppressive rule following the former president's comeback.'' Dissidents have asked the government to prosecute Chun, contending he ordered the military to crush a 1980 pro-democracy uprising in Kwangju. By official count, about 200 people were killed in the uprising. Kwangju is a major stronghold of opposition leader Kim Dae-jung. Kim said he would not oppose Chun's return, but he told the former president to stay out of politics. Chun and his wife, Lee Soon-ja, went into exile in the Paektam-sam temple in November 1988 after apologizing for abuses during his authoritarian rule, which began in 1980. When Chun left Seoul, he said the house and other properties would be turned over to the government to atone for wrongoing. President Roh Tae-woo has said Chun should be allowed to live in his old house. Roh sent one of his secretaries to the temple to discuss Chun's future after stating on Monday that he hoped the former president would return home. Roh, a former general who helped Chun seize power in 1980, has appealed to the nation for mercy for Chun. A dozen of Chun's relatives and associates have been convicted of corruption and imprisoned since Roh took office in February 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Girls Joined at Chest Die After Bouts With Pneumonia
DOC.TEXT: Nine-month-old twin girls, joined from the chest to the navel, died in their mother's arms at home after suffering from pneumonia. Doctors had said the outlook for their health was uncertain when Shaneka and Shanell Florence - who shared a liver and fused hearts - were born March 23. They died Wednesday as their father looked on. Yolunda Florence, the Siamese twins' 20-year-old mother, said the girls recently caught pneumonia. The babies also suffered from cyanotic heart disease, or ``blue baby syndrome,'' stemming from abnormal blood flow through the hearts. It prevented them from getting enough oxygen. Yolunda Florence and her 22-year-old husband, Lister, each dropped out of school to care for their daughters when they became ill last month. Yolunda is expecting another child in two months. ``Shanell and Shaneka taught me to be happy with whatever you have, every day you have,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Believes `Time for Healing' Has Arrived
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Rushdie, in essay, regretting renewed Iranian threats. Pickup 7th pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie, the novelist condemned to death by Iran for allegedly blaspheming Islam, believes a ``time for healing'' will enable him to emerge from hiding, according to an interview released today. His comments to the United News of India were among a series of attempts this week aimed at ending his isolation. Rushdie on Monday affirmed his belief in Islam and said he would not support a paperback printing or further translations of his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' However, a religious leader in Iran responded by saying the nation would not lift the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's call to kill Rushdie for his novel, which they said blasphemes Islam. In a guest editorial today in The Times of London and The New York Times, Rushie said he regretted ``the renewed threats from Tehran and cannot help wondering why the British government seems no longer to feel any need to respond to such threats.'' The Indian news agency quoted Rushdie as saying: ``Gradually, good will can replace ill will. There is a feeling that enough has been done (to me).'' ``Most Moslems are not violent or bloodthirsty. Though Moslems throughout the world now know me by name, relatively few Moslems know what sort of person I am, and they could be willing to listen to me,'' he was quoted as saying. Rushdie, a British national who was born in India, went into hiding in Britain in February 1989 after the death call. He has emerged in recent weeks for a television interview in London and has showed up unannounced at a London bookshop to autograph copies of his newest book, ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories.'' In the interview with United News of India, Rushdie was quoted as saying: ``I don't think I can call myself a good Moslem, but I am Moslem and I believe in the oneness of God and the central tenets of the Prophet's teaching.'' While many Moslems in Britain have denounced Rushdie, he asserted that ``there is a silent majority which feels the matter must be brought to an end,'' United News said. Rushdie noted ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories'' had been well-received in his native India, adding perhaps the change that enables him to come out of hiding can start in India. ``There's something new to talk about - that is the process of healing, and it's particularly important to talk to Indian Moslems - that's where I came from, and if that is where it began, it can be one of the palces where the ending can come from,'' he was quoted as saying. Predominantly Hindu India, where tensions with the Moslem minority periodically erupt into deadly riots, was one of the first nations to ban ``The Satanic Verses.'' Within a few weeks, at least 19 people were killed as riots over the book started in Rushdie's hometown of Bombay and Indian-governed Kashmir and spread to neighboring Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Record Immigration in December, Housing Shortage Looming
DOC.TEXT: A surge in the number of Soviet Jews immigrating to Israel in December will give the Jewish state its highest monthly total of immigrants in its 42-year history, an Israeli official said today. The influx of 40,000 Jews this month - 35,000 of them from the Soviet Union - is intensifying a major housing crisis, said Simha Dinitz, head of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency. Dinitz urged the government to take over construction to resolve the crisis. The pace of immigration has accelerated in recent weeks because of increasing uncertainty in the Soviet Union and better transportation arrangements by Israel, Dinitz told a news conference. December will be ``a record month in the history of immigration in Israel,'' said Dinitz, whose agency assists the Israeli government in transporting and resettling immigrants. The government expects more than 200,000 immigrants this year, about 90 percent of them Soviets. The total will be second only to 1949, when more than 239,000 immigrants arrived in the new state. Soviets have been pouring into Israel since spring 1989, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's government eased its policy on exit permits. Dinitz said that discussions with newly arrived Soviets showed that ``the question of lack of stability, the disintegration of the (Soviet) system, is the thing that worries them most.'' In addition, he said, Israel has improved its transport arrangements via Budapest, Bucharest and Warsaw. He said the housing crisis was created because the construction planned by the government had not been carried out. Dinitz said, for example, that government budgeted for 45,000 new housing units this year, but that only 27,000 had been started. Not one of the 15,000 planned prefabricated homes has been erected, he said, and only 950 of 30,000 mobile homes have been moved into place. He predicted ``a difficult situation for the next 10 to 12 months'' and urged the government should take over construction. Dinitz said he did not believe the newcomers would have to be housed in tents, as some Israeli officials have said. Instead, he said, Israel will have to make use of ``every available space'' in hotels, collective farms, army camps and public buildings. He said Israel estimates there are 3 million to 3.5 million Jews in the Soviet Union, about 1 million higher than Soviet estimates, and that as many as 2.2 million could come to Israel. He said more than 200,000 have arrived over the past two years and that 1 million more already have Israeli invitations to immigrate. ``We are already working on the second million,'' Dinitz said. ``I think easily another million is in the pipeline provided no catastrophe happens.'' Israel has a total population of 4.56 million people, including 3.7 million Jews and 840,000 Israeli Arabs, the people and descendants of the people who stayed within Israel's boundaries when the state was founded in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: Postcard Arrives in Mail 50 Years Late
DOC.TEXT: FDR was president when Anne Brestensky subscribed to Woman's Household Magazine. She paid half of the $2 subscription fee to a salesman, and was told she'd be billed later for the other dollar. She didn't realize how much later. The bill arrived in the mail 50 years later. ``I didn't even know what it was when I got it,'' said Mrs. Brestensky, 77, who received the card at her Allegheny Township home five days before Christmas. ``Where has it been all this time?'' The bill was mailed March 6, 1940. ``It just goes to show that a piece of mail, no matter how old it is, still is important to the Postal Service,'' said Bill Zaken, communication manager for the U.S. Postal Service's Pittsburgh office. ``We deliver.'' Zaken said the postcard, which bears a New York postmark and metered postage for 1 cent, probably was caught in a piece of machinery or a delivery crate.

DOC.HEAD: More than 200 Vehicles Collide in Fog; One Killed
DOC.TEXT: Thick fog caused several chain collisions Friday involving about 200 cars and several trucks along the Milan-Bergamo highway, traffic police said. One person was killed and several were injured in the collisions, a police officer said. The accidents occurred in both directions, forcing closure of the highway, which links Milan and Venice.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Flight Delayed After Bullet Found
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines flight was delayed nearly four hours after a bullet was found near the boarding area at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, an airline spokesman said Friday. ``It appears to have been a .45-caliber cartridge ... found at the time Flight 44 was boarding to leave for London,'' spokesman Bob Gibbons said. The unspent cartridge was found Thursday by a passenger. ``We're still trying to find out how it got there,'' Gibbons said. After the bullet was found, the 348 passengers and their hand-luggage were rechecked by security guards. ``Nothing was found and they were boarded back onto the plane,'' Gibbons said. The flight took off shortly before 10 p.m. and arrived in London, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested in Tourist's Killing Shot to Death
DOC.TEXT: A man who was in custody in connection with the slaying of an elderly tourist lost in the black township of Soweto was shot and killed by police Friday when he tried to escape, police said. The man was arrested Friday in the township, said Soweto police spokesman Capt. J. Ngobeni. Police opened fire when he tried to flee while leading officers to a hostel where an accomplice allegedly was hiding, Ngobeni said. The man was detained in connection with the Oct. 30 shooting death of Alfred Harrison, 74, of New Zealand. Harrison and his wife, Phyllis, had been visiting their daughter in South Africa. They strayed into Soweto, near Johannesburg, after they got lost driving. Assailants killed Harrison and injured his wife after stopping their car in Soweto and stealing the couple's wristwatches.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Bows Out As Washington Mayor After Humbling Year
DOC.TEXT: By any measure, 1990 was a terrible year for Mayor Marion Barry. It began with his videotaped arrest in a drug sting, and saw him convicted of cocaine possession and defeated for a lesser office. And in the end, his wife moved out on him. Barry, once one of the nation's most prominent and promising black politicians, is set to leave office on Jan. 2 unemployed and with a six-month jail sentence hanging over his head. But the former civil rights worker, who has relished the underdog's role in a 30-year career in the public eye, insists his chin is up - even after being forced to abandon plans to run for a fourth, four-year term and suffering a humiliating defeat in his bid instead for a city council seat. ``Some people would be sad, other people would be disappointed ... sort of downcast,'' Barry said in an interview. ``I feel relieved. Some people would feel regret, but that's not here with me - maybe it ought to be, but it's not.'' But detractors and supporters alike can't help but wonder at the promising future once held by a man who left behind the bleak poverty of his boyhood in Itta Bena, Miss., to become a foot soldier in the civil rights movement and later the unrivaled star of Washington's local politics. ``He had his life together beautifully at one time, but he's blown it, and he blew it in this last term,'' said Max Berry, a former Barry supporter who directed the mayor's 1986 re-election effort. ``He did a lot of good things in those first seven years that no one will remember, and he's the reason that his own life is in disarray.'' Longtime supporter Calvin Rolark, a local community activist, said Barry is ``a success story, because he showed what true black leadership can be about.'' ``At the same time, he showed the effect of drugs on individuals, no matter how strong people are,'' Rolark said. ``I think the history of Marion Barry will show that you can go from a law maker to a law breaker.'' Dissident black Roman Catholic priest George Stallings described Barry's legal travails as ``a national tragedy,'' but insisted that the mayor should be remembered for his wide range of accomplishments, particularly the development of a minority contracting procedure that generates more than $600 million annually for businesses owned by African-Americans, Hispanics and other groups. ``On that front, Marion Barry took the city to a new level, and that was a great example to other municipalities,'' Stallings said. ``He was a very strong leader, and that should not be forgotten either.'' Barry was both relaxed and reflective as he prepared to leave the job he has held for a dozen years, but he demonstrated none of the braggadocio that used to be his trademark. The mayor, who has admitted to alcoholism, addiction to prescription drugs and occasional cocaine use, credits his recovery program with taking the blunt edges off his personality. ``This isn't like death,'' Barry said of his departure from the local political scene. ``I've gotten ready for this, and I look back and say, `Someone's going to take over ... I won't have that awesome responsibility anymore,' and in some ways that is nice. I have more perspective now.'' Barry stressed his contributions to the city, including his minority contracting plan, a downtown development boom, senior citizen and youth programs, and the order he initially brought to the city's chaotic financial books. But he admits that in recalling his career, many will think first of his legal troubles. ``I believe that in time, my personal situation will evaporate from people's minds and they will finally get around to the good things I did here,'' Barry said. ``But that's what people will remember for awhile, and you can't stop that.'' The mayor also said he can cope with the prospect of spending time in prison if he fails in the appeal of his cocaine possession conviction and subsequent six-month sentence. ``If it happens, it happens - I'll do the six months and move on,'' Barry said quietly. Not that I like the prospects of it, but I've learned that I can't change that, and I may have to do it, come out and start again.'' How did Barry's downfall begin? Berry, his former campaign director, says ``I think that he partied a lot, drank too much, got on the dope, and did too many crony deals, really just fell in with the wrong people.'' ``Maybe in the future, if he stays clean, he will learn to pick his friends better,'' Berry said. Sharon Pratt Dixon's landslide victory in the race to succeed Barry was seen as a stunning repudiation of the mayor, whose love for the trappings of power contrasted sharply with Dixon's pledge for a simple, no-nonsense government. And as Dixon prepares to tackle problems that include a massive municipal budget deficit, record murder rate and other woes, Barry turns his attention from those difficulties to the problem of finding a job. ``I'm not anxious about the future, I'm not panicky about it,'' said Barry, who has no firm plans beyond a handful of speaking engagements. ``One thing is for sure - I won't be sitting on the sidelines like a little mayor, commenting on everything the new administration does.'' Barry's wife Effi moved out of their home with son Christopher last month after sitting in her husband's trial all summer and listening to a lurid string of tales that detailed his alleged drug use and womanizing. ``This whole thing has been hard on all of us - hard on me, hard on her, and hard on Christopher,'' Barry said. ``But she and I are friends, and we have an understanding. We'll work something out.'' Despite the mayor's recent setbacks, those who have known him over the years believe the strengths that have marked his career - a sharp mind combined with disarming charm - may lead to good things in the future. ``I'm very sad about this, because of what he has done to himself, and by extension, to the city,'' Berry said. ``But you know, something about him makes me want to like him, even now, even though I know he's a scoundrel.''

DOC.HEAD: Riegle Asks Treasury Department To Study Insurance Industry
DOC.TEXT: ``Keating Five'' Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. is asking the Treasury Department to study the condition of the insurance industry, warning that the nation cannot afford to ignore the development of problems similar to the savings and loan debacle. Riegle, D-Mich., who chairs the Senate Banking Committee, asked Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to have his aides examine whether insurance companies have made too many risky investments in commercial real estate and other slumping sectors. He asked the department to look into whether state guaranty funds are adequate to protect customers from insurance company defaults and to estimate the risk to the economy of a major insurance company failure. He also sought to determine whether consumers can get enough information to identify high-risk insurance companies and to recommend whether federal regulation of insurance is needed. ``I believe that the recent history of the savings and loan and commercial banking industries makes clear that the federal government cannot afford to ignore serious problems in any industry that lies close to the heart of the American economy,'' Riegle wrote in a letter dated Dec. 20 and released Thursday. He asked that the Treasury Department report back by Sept. 1. A Treasury spokeswoman said the department was considering the request. On Dec. 10, Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, began a series of hearings examining whether state regulation of insurance has been adequate. He chairs the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights. Riegle is one of five senators being probed by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., former head of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. Riegle, who like the other senators has denied any wrongdoing, received $78,250 in contribution funds from Keating and his associates. He later returned the money.

DOC.HEAD: Deadlock Persists Over U.S.-Iraq Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today charged Iraq with blocking progress on setting up talks to deal with its annexation of Kuwait. Joseph C. Wilson IV, the senior U.S. diplomat in Baghdad, did not discuss the situation for a second day in a row with Iraqi foreign ministry officials, Mark Dillen, a State Department spokesman, said. Wilson had been in almost daily contact with Deputy Foreign Minister Nizar Hamdoon or other Iraqi officials. ``Iraq continues to block any progress toward setting dates for an exchange of visits,'' Dillen said. He referred to the stalled proposal by President Bush for Iraq to send Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz here and then for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to go to Baghdad to see President Saddam Hussein. The cutoff for a Baker trip to Iraq is Jan. 3. That is 12 days before the deadline the U.N. Security Council set last month for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or to risk a military clash with the United States and its allies. Iraq had invited Baker to visit Jan. 12, but he refused, saying it was too close to the deadline for withdrawal. Baker is on vacation in Houston and is expected to return to Washington Jan. 1. He has meetings scheduled with Bush on Jan. 2 and Jan. 4, officials said. Meanwhile, Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador to Washington, did not return to his post today after consultations in Baghdad. Other Iraqi ambassadors had been called home, as well. U.S. and Iraqi officials said Mashat was expected in Washington this weekend or early next week.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Signal Protracted Slump
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge plunged in November, the fifth consecutive monthly drop, and analysts said it signaled increased joblessness and a slump extending until late next year. ``The basic message is there's no light down there in the tunnel that we can see,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``The recession is clearly in place and clearly has further to go,'' he said. Friday's announcement of the November decline of 1.2 percent in the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Indicators was the latest in a spate of gloomy news about economic conditions last month. Unemployment jumped to a three-year high of 5.9 percent. New orders to factories for ``big ticket'' durable goods such as automobiles and appliances plunged 10.5 percent, matching the worst decline on record. Consumer spending and income growth was virtually flat, and construction of single-family homes fell to the lowest level since 1982. Analysts said the latest drop in the leading index, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, offered almost no hope that the economy will revive soon. Less than three weeks ago, most private analysts believed the economy, having entered a recession in the fourth quarter of this year, would begin to grow again next spring. The November decline in the leading index followed a 1.3 percent drop in October, the steepest since the month after the October 1987 stock market crash. The decline left the index at 139.7 percent of its 1982 base of 100, down 4.4 percent from its 146.2 peak in June. It has been the worst multiple-month retreat by the index since 1981, at the start of the last recession. ``The November indicators leave no doubt that a serious and lengthy recession is under way,'' said economist William K. MacReynolds of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``... This is good evidence that the current recession will last at least through the third quarter of 1991 - longer than could have been foreseen just weeks ago.'' ``It means a continuous drop in jobs throughout most of next year and a rise in the unemployment rate to about 7.5 percent,'' he said. ``That's a loss of more than a million jobs from where we are now.'' Top administration officials, including President Bush, have been reluctant to label the slump as a recession. But on Thursday Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, said, ``We will, in fact, have a recession,'' and warned the unemployment rate could go as high as 8 percent. However, analyst Samuel Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. the nation's economic prospects may not be as bleak if the Persian Gulf crisis is resolved early in the year. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices soaring and the confidence of American consumers plummeting. That, in turn has caused sharp pullback by businesses, he said. ``If the war is settled, we might get a boost in consumer confidence, which could turn the whole thing around rather quickly,'' he said. In November, eight of the 11 forward-looking components of the Commerce Department's index fell. Pulling it down were a jump in new claims for unemployment benefits and declines in new orders to factories for consumer goods, prices of raw materials, the backlog of unfilled orders at factories, new orders for business investment equipment, the length of the average workweek, the inflation-adjusted money supply and building permits. The only positive contributors were an increase in stock prices, a slowing in business delivery times and a slight improvement in consumer confidence.

DOC.HEAD: More Warships Receive Gulf Orders; Iraqis Train for Suicide Missions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with U.S. forgiving Egyptian debt, Bush administration reporting no progress on setting up peace talks. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Less than three weeks from a U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face possible attack, the U.S. Navy began beefing up its forces in the Persian Gulf and 16,000 sailors and Marines had orders today to leave for the region. A day earlier, President Bush dismissed reports that the United States is still weeks away from being ready to mount a full military strike. Officials were quoted today as saying Bush favors a quick war to save American lives. Because such a conflict could involve the use of biological weapons, the Pentagon said today it plans to inoculate American troops against them. Such weapons could be launched at the U.S.-led forces by missiles, and for the second time this week Iraq test fired a surface-to-surface missile today. The U.S. Central Command in Saudi Arabia reported that the missle was fired away from multinational forces so that it landed within Iraq. ``The firing appeared to be part of an additional testing or training mission,'' said Air Force Lt. Casey Mahon, a Central Command spokesman. Military analysts also said today that thousands of Iraqis have been trained for suicide attacks on U.S.-led multinational forces if war breaks out.
