In other developments: -President Bush today ordered forgiveness of Egypt's $7 billion in military debts as a reward for its cooperation with the U.S. efforts against Iraq. Bush cited U.S. national security interests and said the action was necessary for ``the success of Desert Shield,'' the code name for the U.S. gulf forces. -The Bush administration today charged Iraq with blocking progress on setting up talks on the gulf crisis. The dispute over dates has prevented Secretary of State James A. Baker III from meeting with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. The 16,000 sailors and Marines were scheduled to begin leaving U.S. ports for the gulf today aboard 17 ships, including the aircraft carriers America and Theodore Roosevelt from the Norfolk Naval Base in Virginia. Navy officials said it should be a two-week voyage, meaning the ships would arrive before the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline. Aircraft carriers on station in the Middle East region are the USS Saratoga in the eastern Mediterranean, the USS Midway in the Arabian Sea and the USS John F. Kennedy in the Red Sea. The deployment of such a large number of U.S. warships to one part of the world is unprecedented since the Vietnam War. More than 400,000 U.S. troops are expected to be deployed by mid-February, as well as about 100,000 from other nations. Iraq, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, has more than 500,000 troops in southern Iraq and in Kuwait. The New York Times reported today that inoculations of soliders against biological weapons could begin ``within a matter of weeks.'' A Pentagon Statement released today confirmed the account. ``We are committed to providing maximum protection for our troops, including protection against chemical and biological weapons,'' the statement said. It did not say when the vaccinations would begin. Saddam has denied having biological weapons, based on viruses and bacteria that can spread diseases such as typhoid and cholera. Iraq has used chemical weapons against its Kurdish population and against Iran. Lt. Gen. Calvin Waller said last week he did not believe the United States was prepared for a full attack on Jan. 15. Several media reports says that view has wide support among the military. But Bush said Thursday: ``Don't believe those reports you're reading'' and noted he was ``very comfortable'' with U.S. firepower on hand in the region. He also said there had been ``no progress'' on settling a disagreement over dates for a proposed meeting between Saddam and Baker. The Iraqis have insisted on Jan. 12 talks, but Bush said there would be ``no compromise'' on the U.S. position of talks no later than Jan. 3. Should negotiations fail, Bush favors a quick attack, according to senior government officials quoted in today's Los Angeles Times. The officials said Bush believes a prompt strike will reduce American casualties. Asian military analysts in Baghdad, meanwhile, said Iraq has been training army commandos and volunteers for special operations against the allied forces. The training includes sea and airborne suicide missions, they said. A senior Iraqi Baath Party official told Iraq's government Al-Jouhouriya newspaper that 138,700 volunteers had completed courses at a military camp in Najaf, Iraq, 90 miles south of Baghdad, since the gulf crisis began.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Vanna White bought a marriage license in this celebrity-filled ski resort, but she didn't provide a clue about when she'll say ``I DO.'' With a scarf wrapped tightly around her head, the 33-year-old ``Wheel of Fortune'' letter-turner and her boyfriend, Brooklyn native George Santo Pietro, 44, picked up the $20 license Thursday at the Pitkin County Courthouse. No one recognized White, even after she provided her driver's license for identification. ``I didn't even know who it was,'' said Deputy County Clerk Kim Schultz, who helped the couple fill out their marriage license forms. Santo Pietro's mother, Catherine Santo Pietro of Plainview, N.Y., said she was ``delighted, very delighted'' that White will become part of her family. Mrs. Santo Pietro said she had been told of the wedding plans, but didn't know when it would be. The marriage license is good anywhere in Colorado for 30 days. White was the second celebrity this week to get into the marriage game at a Colorado ski resort. On Christmas Eve, film star Tom Cruise and Australian actress Nicole Kidman married in a secret wedding in Telluride. --- DALLAS (AP) - Actor Martin Sheen knows how to get his name in a newspaper. Just show up in a newsroom with a camera. Sheen filmed scenes at The Dallas Morning News on Thursday for his new movie, ``Touch and Die.'' In the film, Sheen plays a reporter in Europe who discovers stolen plutonium is being sold to finance a presidential campaign in the United States. Sheen, the father of actors Charlie Sheen and Emilio Estevez, is known for his activism on behalf of environmental causes and the homeless. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Tammy Wynette says a new generation of performers has helped popularize country music all over again. ``The abundance of great new talent ... is changing the demographics of the listening and buying audience,'' she said in comments published in the Country Music Association's ``Close-Up'' magazine. ``Because of their impact, the audiences are younger and the consumer dollars at both the record and concert levels have greatly increased,'' she said in the publication's January issue. She cited Mary-Chapin Carpenter, Joe Diffie, Randy Travis, Ricky Van Shelton, Clint Black, Patty Loveless and Garth Brooks as among those making an impact. Wynette, the first lady of country music, has had such hits as ``Stand by Your Man'' and ``D-I-V-O-R-C-E.'' --- LONDON, Ohio (AP) - Johnny Paycheck, who achieved stardom in 1978 with the worker's anthem ``Take This Job and Shove It,'' is singing the blues to Gov. Richard Celeste in hopes of getting out of prison. Paycheck, whose real name is Donald Eugene Lytle, is serving a seven-to-9{-year prison term for a shooting in a bar in 1985. The singer is asking Celeste to grant him clemency before the governor leaves office Jan. 15. A spokesman for Celeste declined to comment, except to say that the governor has an ``extremely conservative record in granting clemency.'' Paycheck, 51, has served 10 months for aggravated assault, tampering with evidence and using a handgun. He was convicted for shooting a fellow bar patron in the head in 1985, injuring him. He won't be eligible for parole for five years. Highland County Prosecutor Rocky Coss said he has written to the Ohio Parole Board to object to Paycheck's clemency bid. ``He's used his celebrity status all his life to evade the consequences of the law, both criminal and civil. I think it would not serve the law to give him clemency due to his celebrity status,'' Coss said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Police Chief Daryl F. Gates' forthcoming autobiography will be nothing short of arresting, his publisher hopes. The outspoken chief's work should attract readers because of the ``glamour and charisma'' of the Los Angeles Police Department, said Stuart Applebaum, spokesman for New York-based Bantam Books. Gates' sometimes blustery style has ruffled some feathers. This year, for example, he told a U.S. Senate hearing that casual drug users should be shot. Gates has received an advance of close to $300,000 for the book, which Bantam will release in 1992, said Police Department spokesman Cmdr. William Booth. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Jose Canseco is striking out with the homeowners association in his exclusive neighborhood. The Oakland Athletics baseball star and his wife, Esther, are facing foreclosure for skipping $4,264.44 in maintenance fees on his two estates in the bayfront development of Cocoplum. The Cocoplum Homeowners Association charged in a Dec. 14 foreclosure lawsuit filed in Dade Circuit Court that the Cansecos ``have failed or refused to pay their past-due assessments and charges.'' Last month, the association placed liens on the homes, valued at a total of $2.3 million. Association officials have refused to comment on the matter. ``This is between Mr. Canseco and the association,'' said Michelle Gorman, the organization's attorney. Canseco, who signed a five-year, $23.5 million contract with the A's in June, grew up in Miami and returns to Florida during the offseason. No one answered the telephone Friday morning at the office of his agent, Dennis Gilbert. --- AVIGNON, France (AP) - It hasn't been an easy year for the leader of France's Communist Party. But Georges Marchais is a survivor. Marchais, who triumphed in a party election last week only to be laid up by a mild heart attack, walked out of a hospital Friday after two days of treatment. The 70-year-old communist leader played down the attack as ``a light problem'' and told reporters that ``retirement isn't for me.'' He then set out for his home in Paris. Marchais had been at his vacation home in nearby Robion when he was stricken. He had been enjoying a holiday after last week's party congress, where he received 99 percent of the delegates' votes to serve a new term as party secretary-general. He has led the party since 1972. The victory marked a triumph after a year of criticism by party reformers for Marchais' failure to change his orthodox views despite the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Shift Cuba Policy Over Economics, Will Politics Be Next?
LaserPhoto NY18
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is expected to dramatically reduce economic aid to Cuba in January, and some legislators say a re-evaluation of political ties with the longtime ally may be next. Cuban leader Fidel Castro has scoffed at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 5-year-old reform campaign, and some Soviet deputies say he continues to foment insurgencies around the world while ignoring the needs of his people. ``Some members of parliament ... are fed up with the export of revolution. If they (Cubans) continue the so-called `old course,' we'll let them continue. But foreign aid won't be as it was before,'' said Nikolai V. Neyland, a member of the Supreme Soviet's Foreign Affairs Committee. Officially, the Kremlin is sticking by Castro politically. But Castro's steadfast refusal of Soviet-type reforms may play a role when the national Supreme Soviet legislature considers a foreign aid bill. Western experts estimate Soviet economic aid to Cuba at $5 billion a year, and military aid at about $1.5 billion. Soviet reformers say this is a luxury the country cannot afford when it can't feed its own people, and cuts are expected in trade talks beginning next month. The foreign aid bill, proposed by Gorbachev, envisions a 75 percent cut in ``gratuitous'' foreign economic aid, apparently affecting all Soviet allies. It would accompany a new policy, starting Jan. 1, requiring allies to pay convertible currency at world prices for most trade with the Soviet Union. That would end a practice of giving aid - in the form of favorable trade terms - to countries such as Cuba, Vietnam, North Korea and Ethiopia. In other changes, the Soviets also are pushing for a thaw in U.S.-Cuban relations, a 31-year antagonism that nearly led to nuclear war over the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Gorbachev, preaching ``new thinking'' in foreign affairs, said during a visit to Cuba in 1989 that he rejected Castro's support for Communist revolutions in countries such as El Salvador, Angola and Nicaragua. Still, the official reason given for the cutback in aid is economic. ``We have given up the state monopoly on foreign trade, given enterprises the right of access to the international market, given up ideological-ridden approaches which used to lead to waste of resources in relations with some countries,'' Gorbachev told the parliament last week. The huge Russian republic, with 90 percent of the country's exportable energy, is seeking more say over some foreign policy questions and could lead the way in asking hard questions about ties with Cuba. ``We don't want to interfere in the internal affairs of Cuba. Cubans must decide for themselves,'' said Yevgeny Kozholkhin, chairman of the Russian legislature's committee on foreign relations. ``But as we come to any consideration (about aid), we should just consider what kind of regime we have before us.'' At some point, ``we must consider human rights,'' he said. A hint of anti-Cuban sentiment in the national legislature emerged in October, when legislator Olzhas Suleimenov took the floor and criticized Cuba as a ``totalitarian'' state. In November, an expose in the reformist daily Komsomolskaya Pravda reported that Castro has 32 houses, a personal security force of 9,700, and five children by his ``present wife.'' That would shock many Cubans, who have been told only that Castro was divorced 35 years ago. The report prompted the Communist Party daily Pravda to run a response by Cuba's ambassador to the Soviet Union, Jose Ramon Balaguer Cabrera, calling the report ``lies.'' Since the fall of hard-line governments in East Europe last year, Cuba's favored status among Soviet allies has come under bolder attack. Commentators have questioned the value of the Kremlin's commitment to a country they say has offered little in return. ``How many more years is the Soviet government going to take away the `rations' of poverty-stricken peasants in order to underwrite and maintain the inefficient, militarized economy of this far-off overseas state?'' asked a commentator in the labor newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna last month. Andrei Kortunov, a staff researcher at the Soviet Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada, has estimated that more than one quarter of the $12 billion annual Soviet foreign aid budget in 1989 went to Cuba. Vyacheslav Krestyaninov, an editor of Latin America, a Soviet monthly, said the new policy would shift the basis of Cuban-Soviet relations from a political to economic footing. But he said decades of Soviet adoration of Castro would not die so quickly. ``I wouldn't call it a split,'' Krestyaninov said. ``It's like a new agreement in a family. It's still a family.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Criticized for Golfing at All-White Club
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS spelling of Cypress in 6th graf
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle cancelled a second round of golf at a California course today after being criticized for playing at the country club with an all-white membership. His office said he had been unaware of the controversy surrounding the Cypress Point Club. Quayle shot more than 18 holes Thursday at the course in Pebble Beach. Beach. The Professional Golfers Association in September ruled the club ineligible for the 1991 AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. ``I have a great concern about the vice president of the United States playing at Cypress Point and not being aware of the sensitivity of the issue that revolves around it,'' Monterrey County Supervisor Sam Karas said. Quayle couldn't be questioned for reaction because Secret Service agents kept reporters and photographers off the club's private grounds. But his office in Washington released a statement from Press Secretary David Beckwith, stating Quayle was ``unaware of the controversy surrounding the Cypress Point golf course. He has been assured the club does not discriminate and has never had a policy of discrimination.'' However, the statement said, ``The vice president is unwilling to leave any impression that he condones any form of discrimination. He has therefore canceled his round of golf today.'' Quayle is a member of the Burning Tree country club outside Washington, which has an all-male membership. He was returning to his skiing vacation in Colorado before returning to Washington on Saturday. Quayle will leave Saturday night for a New Year's visit to the troops in the Persian Gulf. Asked how Quayle could be unaware of the highly publicized controversy involving the club's banning from the national tournament, his chief of staff Bill Kristol said in a telephone interview: ``It proves he's not spending time reading the golf pages.'' An official who answered the telephone at the club's hotel, where Quayle was staying, said the staff had been instructed not to try to contact Quayle's party. Golfing with Quayle on Thursday were two Cypress Point Club members who are prominent officials in the Bush administration - Donald B. Rice, the Air Force secretary, and Ebersole Gaines, U.S. Ambasador to the Bahamas.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Love Drove Irishman to Climb Palace Walls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs with one graf to ADD date of arrest. Pickup 4th pvs, `Peter Codner...'
DOC.TEXT: Eugene Smith said Friday he had scaled the walls of Buckingham Palace to ask Queen Elizabeth II where he could find his lost love. Smith, who had picked up a rock to smash his way into the palace if the doors and windows were closed, failed to make it. Police arrested him Dec. 7 in the palace grounds and charged him with carrying a piece of masonry without lawful excuse with intent to destroy Crown property. Peter Codner, Smith's attorney, told Bow Street magistrates' court that the 32-year-old jobless Irishman came to London from Dublin after becoming infatuated with a woman who claimed to be the queen's niece, and that his only desire was to find her. He called Smith's actions ``strange'' but said that sometimes people get so profoundly moved that they do peculiar things. Smith was conditionally discharged by magistrate Ronald Bartle, who said if he came before the court again within 12 months he would have to pay $950. ``I met her in Amsterdam about three months ago. Her name is Julie Craig and she is 24 years old, blonde and beautiful,'' Smith said after leaving the court. ``She made me promise to come back and said she was related to the queen. I have not been able to make contact with her. I climbed the walls of the palace grounds in desperation. ``If only I could find her I would give her the biggest kiss and tell her I love her and will love her for ever and ever. She is wonderful,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Allies Fill Front Lines, But Offensive Role Unclear
DOC.TEXT: HAFR AL-BATIN, Saudi Arabia (AP) - The front line arrayed against Iraq is a polyglot Arab-Islamic force whose role in the northern Saudi desert may be merely symbolic. As the United Nations' Jan. 15 deadline approaches for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face possible force, it's still not clear what part the Arabs would play in a potentially bloody offensive. More than 100,000 Saudis, Egyptians, Syrians, vengeful Kuwaitis and others have joined to confront Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, a fellow Arab, since he invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Forces from Pakistan, Morocco, Bangladesh, Niger and Senegal have planted their flags on Saudi soil. Some contingents are little more than token forces. Behind them are about 350,000 American, British and French troops with the firepower needed to hammer the Iraqis. ``If peace doesn't arrive, and if we're ordered by our supreme commanders, we can teach (Saddam) a lesson he'll never forget,'' boasted Lt. Gen. Khalid bin Sultan, the Saudi prince who commands the 145,000-member Arab-Islamic force. Those are big ifs. The Arab alliance is like an orchestra. All the players have instruments, but some play different notes. Not all of them will sound ``Charge'' if the U.S.-led multinational force is ordered into Kuwait. The Kuwaitis, of course, want their country back, but they won't fight in Iraq. The Saudis will fight with the United States and its allies if invited by Kuwait. The Egyptians say they will do what the Saudis do. The Syrians and others have said only that their role here is defensive and to stop aggression. ``It's clear that there are varying levels of commitment in terms of willingness to use offensive military action to achieve our objective,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney acknowledged recently. It is also uncertain what the Arab response would be if Saddam carried out his threat to launch a missile attack on Israel. It would be difficult for the Syrians and the Saudis to fight Saddam if he gets into a shootout with the Arabs' main enemy. The Arab states who have the most at stake, the ones ``that really count,'' are the Saudis and the Egyptians, Cheney noted. The Saudis have a 75,000-member army and air force; the Egyptians have pledged 40,000 troops, including two armored divisions. The Egyptians and Syrians, who have sent an armored division with their 20,000-member contingent, bring combat experience to the Saudi desert. Both have fought the Israelis, and the Syrians have been in action in Lebanon. The U.S.-equipped Egyptians also trained with American troops in a 1988 exercise. But some analysts say the biggest contribution of the Arab-Islamic force is is symbolic: Arabs are standing up to Saddam, muting criticism of having Western forces in a land that houses Islam's holiest shrines. The Arab alliance is ``a useful show of political solidarity,'' said Ian Kemp, a military analyst with Jane's Defense Weekly. ``But if it comes to an offensive operation, I don't think they'll play anything but a marginal role. The Americans and the British will play the lead.'' Some expect a force of Kuwaitis and Saudis to spearhead the U.S.-British effort as a political gesture. ``This will allow the Arab-Islamic forces to say they were the ones who liberated Kuwait City,'' said Tony Banks, political editor for Jane's. ``But when it comes to the real thing, the Americans and the British will bear the brunt of it.'' By agreement, no offensive can be launched from Saudi soil without the consent of King Fahd and President Bush. In the defensive configuration, Prince Khalid shares command of the 28-nation force with U.S. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. ``If there's any blood shed, I can assure you Saudi forces will be the first to spill it,'' the Saudi prince stressed recently. ``If anyone touches my land, you will see vicious soldiers who will do their job well.'' The Saudi army, untested in combat, lives well. Television antennas sprout from their tents, rugs cover the sand and wool blankets adorn their bunks. Egyptian commandos, in contrast, eat raw rats to prove they can live in the desert. Syrians drill with Soviet-made T-60 tanks. U.S. Special Forces train with many of the Arab forces. They teach techniques such as mine-clearing, setting up fire zones and calling in air strikes. Among the Arab forces are the remnants of Kuwait's shattered army. They work with their salvaged tanks and practice karate - a dubious asset against Iraqi armor and chemical weapons. They call themselves the Martyr Brigade, and they talk tough. ``We ask to be in the front. We must have revenge,'' said a tank commander who gave his name only as Ali because his family is still in Kuwait. ``By dying, I'll feel I'm doing something.''

DOC.HEAD: Boston Trolley Accident Injures 31; Most Injuries Described As Minor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to UPDATE with at least one person in critical condition; SUBS 9-13th grafs pvs, bgng `The area...', with 6 grafs to add detail from hospital, background. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `Mayor Raymond...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX5,BX6,XBX1
DOC.TEXT: A trolley car was struck by another trolley this morning as it unloaded commuters in a station on the edge of Boston Common, injuring 31 people, at least one critically, officials said. ``I just screamed out, `Everybody hang on and get down! We're going to hit!''' said Steve DePaulo, a passenger on the moving train. ``It just seemed like seconds later we smashed into the trolley in front of us. People just went flying everywhere.'' He said he thought his train was moving rather fast as it entered the station. The collision between two outbound Green Line trains occurred at around 6:45 a.m. at underground Arlington Station. The Green Line is one of four subway lines operated by Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The accident came less than 2{ weeks after more than 250 people were injured at nearby Back Bay station when an Amtrak train struck a commuter train. It also occurred about 2{ hours before a New York City subway fire killed a passenger and injured at least 100 from smoke inhalation. John Fasana of Emergency Medical Services put the number of injured in the Boston accident at least 31, describing the injuries as ``typical injuries expected from a low-impact collision.'' ``Two of them suffered what I would consider to be serious injuries,'' he said. ``The rest of them were walking wounded-type injuries.'' Ernest Jones, a passenger on the stationary trolley, said one minute he was reading his newspaper, the next they were hit and he saw at least four people bleeding from head injuries. ``I was looking at the lady across from me. Next thing I knew the lights went out and she was on the floor,'' he said. ``I saw one man in the back on the floor on his back, crying, obviously in agony, hurt.'' Transit authority officials said each of the one-car trains was carrying about 40 people, with the capacity for 60. They said ridership was light because of the holidays this week. After the accident, riders were bused between stations on each side of the accident site. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis made the Green Line well-known during the 1988 presidential campaign because he commuted on the line from his home in Brookline to the Massachusetts Statehouse. At the time of the accident, the area was experiencing its first snowstorm of the season, but officials said they doubted that weather played a role in the underground collision. ``That will be part of the investigation, but it does not appear to be weather related,'' said Nancy Sterling Gleason, a transit authority spokeswoman. Many of the injured were carried from the station on stretchers. One person was admitted and listed in critical condition at the New England Medical Center, said Cheryl Paris, a hospital spokeswoman. Other hospitals had not determined whether any of the injured they were treating would have to be admitted. Mayor Raymond Flynn, who was on the scene shortly after the collision, said he wasn't ready to believe reports of another rail crash so soon after the Back Bay collision, which remains under investigation. ``You think it's just some sort of joke at first, that there was another train accident,'' Flynn said. ``But we arrived here and saw the situation.'' Thomas Glynn, transit authority general manager, said despite the fact that there have been two rail crashes in less than three weeks, ``I think in the end people are going to realize that overall our record is good.'' Glynn said operators of both trains were sent for drug and alcohol tests.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Misses David Letterman Call
DOC.TEXT: One of the biggest calls Lois Decatur ever got came this week, but she wasn't there to get it. It was talk-show host David Letterman, hoping to chat about the weather. ``He's the most important person ever to call me, and I wasn't home, gosh darn it,'' Decatur said Thursday. ``I should have stayed home.'' Letterman picked her number at random from a telephone directory while taping his NBC-TV ``Late Night'' show Wednesday night. Decatur, 61, said she was driving her son to a bingo game. Letterman tried six other numbers around the country. They weren't home either. ``How many people are living in this country, 250 million?'' Letterman asked on the show. ``You'd think we could get one at home.'' He finally called the mother of a ``Late Night'' employee. Decatur said her phone rang a lot the next day - callers who'd seen her miss her chance in the limelight on national TV. Her son didn't win any bingo games either.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Lands in Woman's Back Yard
DOC.TEXT: Joylean Lucas did her bit for Operation Desert Shield, donating coffee and cornbread to the Mississippi National Guard helicopter crew that landed in her back yard. But her first reaction was to call the sheriff's office. After all, as Mrs. Lucas observed Thursday, ``It's not every day that a helicopter sits down in your backyard.'' The whapwhapwhap of a helicopter's rotor can be startling at close range. Mrs. Lucas heard it while she was taking down her Christmas decorations. ``It sounded like they were going to take the top of the house down. I guessed I had better see what was going on,'' she said. ``I ran outside, and I saw the helicopter landing behind the catfish pond. ``At first, it looked like he was going to land in it.'' The helicopter turned out to be from the Mississippi National Guard's 155th Armored Brigade, forced to the ground by fog on the way from Camp Shelby, Miss., to Fort Hood, Texas. Five other helicopters landed at nearby Buckeye Elementary School. Once the chopper set down, Mrs. Lucas recalled, ``two men got out of the helicopter and said, `We're kind of in a bind.' The pilot said he was flying along with the others when he couldn't see anything and spotted our pasture. There was plenty of open field and pasture for him to land.'' Mrs. Lucas invited the men inside for coffee, and offered them some of the lima beans, rice and cornbread she had cooked for dinner. ``All they wanted was some cornbread because they said it smelled so good,'' she said. The 155th Armored Brigade is one of three National Guard combat brigades in the country activated as part of Operation Desert Shield. It will train at Fort Hood.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Preparing Commando Suicide Squads, Analysts Say
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Iraqis are being trained to conduct attacks against U.S.-led forces if war breaks out, and Asian military analysts said Friday some were being prepared for possible suicide missions. In another defense move, Iraqi media reported Friday that paramilitary militias in the Kurdish region have been reactivated to shore up the country's northern border with Turkey. The Asian military analysts, speaking in Baghdad on condition of anonymity, said Iraq has been training army commandos and volunteers from the Popular Army for special operations against the 400,000-strong allied forces in Saudi Arabia. The analysts said the training includes preparations for possible sea and airborne missions that they characterized as suicidal. A day earlier, a senior Iraqi Baath Party official was quoted as saying that thousands of volunteers had completed courses at a military camp in Najaf, Iraq. He said they receieved special training on weapons and commando tactics. Abdul-rahim Abdul-qadder told Iraq's government-run Al-Jouhouriya newspaper that since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August, 138,700 volunteers have been trained in special operations at the camp, 90 miles south of Baghdad. ``The Najaf camp is ideal in training combatants who symbolize heroism and discipline,'' he told the newspaper. The Asian analysts said the volunteers were probably receiving training in commando missions to be launched behind the lines of the multinational forces. More than half of Iraq's 1 million-strong army is deployed in southern part of the country and in Kuwait. The U.N. Security Council has said Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face possible attack by U.S.-led forces. The Popular Army was set up by the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party as an ideological counterweight to the Iraqi army. Officials in Baghdad say it numbers 8 million, but diplomatic sources place its strength at closer to 850,000 and say the soliders are mostly poor combatants. Meanwhile, Iraqi Interior Minister Samir Mouhamad Abdul-wahab urged local chieftans in the Kurdish region to take part in ``plans to confront the challenges imposed on Iraq,'' news reports from Baghdad said Friday. The chieftains were appointed as commanders of the pro-government paramilitary forces formed during the 1980-88 war with Iran to combat the Kurdish rebellion in northern Iraq. The units, known as National Defense Brigades, were defunct after the cease-fire went into effect in the Iran-Iraq war and the government had crushed the Kurdish rebellion. The analysts said the reactivation of the militia of about 300,000 men was intended to beef up Iraq's defenses against Turkey, Iraq's northern neighbor. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week accused Turkey of deploying troops and warplanes on the border and said Iraq had to increase its military strength in the area to counter the buildup.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Nicolas Cage Father of Baby Boy
DOC.TEXT: Actor Nicolas Cage stole a baby in the movie ``Raising Arizona.'' Now he's raising Weston. Cage is the father of a baby boy born Wednesday to girlfriend and actress Christina Fulton at Cedars Sinai Hospital, according to a statement released by Cage's publicist. Weston Coppola Cage weighed 8 pounds, 2 ounces. Cage, 25, whose real name is Nicolas Coppola, starred in ``Firebirds,'' ``Wild at Heart'' and ``Moonstruck.'' Miss Fulton will appear in Oliver Stone's movie, ``The Doors.''

DOC.HEAD: Eighth-Graders Sell Script to Steven Spielberg
DOC.TEXT: Three eighth-graders who created a script for an afternoon children's show about a vacation gone wrong will travel to Los Angeles next month to sign a contract with Steven Spielberg. Renee Carter, Amy Crosby and Sarah Creek created an illustrated 200-page story book for an episode of the show, ``Tiny Toon Adventures.'' It is produced by Spielberg, whose movies include ``Jaws,'' ``Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' ``Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' and ``E.T.'' ``It was a miracle our idea was ever accepted,'' said Miss Crosby. ``They told us the studio usually returns unsolicited material without even opening it.'' Studio officials said someone at Warner Bros. which syndicates the show, mistakenly opened the manuscript package, liked it, and passed it on. The manuscript passed from desk to important desk, impressing all readers, until it arrived in front of Spielberg. He liked what he saw. Warner Bros. lawyers were said to have advised against pursuing the script. They said it would create a precedent and that the studio would be swamped with scripts from school children. ``But Steven wanted it, and you don't say no to Steven Spielberg,'' said Jean MacCurdy, vice president and general manager of Warner Bros. Animation. Spielberg sent Ms. MacCurdy and Barbara Brogliatti, senior vice president of publicity and promotion, to Waynesboro on Dec. 13 to meet with the students and make an offer. ``They proposed paying us $250 for the episode, which we will split three ways, and to fly us and our parents to Los Angeles for four days,'' Miss Carter said. The girls and their parents leave Jan. 18 for Los Angeles. While there, they will tour Universal Studios, Magic Mountain, Warner Bros. Studios, and attend a news conference and story meeting with Spielberg. Miss Carter said the idea for the story book, a series of drawings and captions detailing the action of an episode, came to her at school one day. She began drawing characters and laying out a story line. The story eventually was titled ``Buster and Babs Go Hawaiian.'' The characters Buster and Babs take a free Hawaiian vacation, which turns out to be a nightmare of lost luggage, inoperable rental cars, bad hotels and a cruise that ends up in a shipwreck. The two other girls contributed story ideas and artwork. The episode is expected to air next fall on ``Tiny Toons Adventures,'' which is seen on the Fox network. Classmates of the girls are already asking them to get Spielberg's autograph. ``Sure,'' said Miss Carter. ``On the contract.''

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, More Than 140 Injured As Fire Strikes NYC Subway Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE injury total to 145; dead man described as rider; prognosis `not favorable' for revived woman; add that train eventually was backed into station where passengers departed. Picks up penultimate graf, `Some 30...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY19,NY21
DOC.TEXT: An electrical fire spread choking smoke through a subway tunnel today, killing a commuter and injuring more than 140, officials said. Terrified passengers screamed and prayed out loud. Transit Authority spokeswoman Caren Gardner said the death occurred after a weather-related fire broke out on the electrified third rail in the subway tunnel underneath downtown Brooklyn. ``We really thought we were gone, that we wouldn't see New Year's,'' said Gertrude Hoyte, a 51-year-old Brooklyn resident who was on her way to work in Manhattan. She described how smoke filled the subway cars, causing people to panic and several to vomit into their newspapers. ``People were screaming, `We're going to die!''' said passenger Dana Sullivan, 28, of West Islip. Others were praying out loud, she said. The accident occurred about 9:10 a.m. in the tunnel used by the No. 2 and No. 3 subway lines, going through downtown Brooklyn and then under the East River toward Manhattan. Authorities said 145 people were injured, all apparently from smoke inhalation. So many were taken to hospitals - 132 in all - that city buses had to be used. The identity of the dead man, described as a subway rider, was not released. Medical staff at Long Island College Hospital managed to revive a woman whom authorities at the scene had believed to be dead, but her condition remained grave, hospital officials said. ``The prognosis does not look favorable for her,'' Dr. Neil Flomenbaum, chairman of emergency medicine at the hospital, said this afternoon. It was one of two serious transit accidents this morning. In Boston, more than 30 people were injured when a trolley car slammed into the rear of a stopped car in an underground station near Boston Common. Authorities in New York estimated that there were 300 to 400 people aboard the train most severely affected by the smoke. Naomi Smalls-Watson, 23, of Brooklyn said she was sitting in the first car of the train when she ``heard a popping noise and then a whoosh.'' ``Then there was another big boom and people started panicking,'' she said. At that point, the subway tunnel began filling with smoke, so much that passengers could not see anything outside the train, she said. ``A lot of people passed out,'' she said. Witnesses said some passengers considered trying to open train doors but were convinced by fellow passengers that it would only worsen the smoke. Eventually, the train was backed up to a station that was farther away from the fire and the passengers were able to leave the train. The fire on the third rail apparently occurred when snow from streets above leaked into the subway system and onto wires on the tracks near the Clark Street station, the last station in Brooklyn before the train goes under the river, Gardner said. She said it's possible the snow grounded some heavy-duty electrical cables against the third rail. Some 30 firefighting units responded in Manhattan and Brooklyn, said department spokesman Joe McGee. He said the smoke condition was heavier on the Brooklyn side. By late morning, dozens of people were being treated or comforted in the lobbies of downtown Brooklyn buildings. Some passengers sat wearily in the lobby of a Crosslands Bank as employees gave them cups of water; others received oxygen from emergency personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine Dealer Cheats Police; Handed Lighter Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A convicted cocaine dealer cheated undercover police in a drug deal, and ended up with a lighter prison sentence. Ramon Leon of Grand Rapids would have faced a mandatory 20 years in prison if he sold 8 ounces of cocaine to the police. But the officers later discovered they bought only 7.8 ounces. Leon, 28, was sentenced Thursday to 13 to 20 years. ``He shorted us,'' Kent County Assistant Prosecutor Ellwyn Bloemers said. ``That's not unusual to have that happen to us. When we buy 2 ounces, it should be 56 grams, but we come back with 49 frequently. He's very slick; he's very polished.'' Bloemers said that on Nov. 22, 1989, an officer weighed the eight cocaine-filled bags on a scale kept in his car's trunk but may not have accounted for the weight of the bags. Police paid $6,800 for the drugs. Bloemers said he believes Leon intentionally held back, knowing an 8-ounce deal could mean a 20-year term. State law says a dealer convicted of selling 225 grams or more of cocaine faces at least 20 years in prison. Dealers convicted of selling 50 to 224 grams face at least 10 years. ``The only reason you're not covered by the 20-year minimum term is that you cheated the officer in that transaction,'' Circuit Judge Donald Johnston told Leon before sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Mortgages Averaging 9.68 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-year, fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.68 percent this week, up from 9.64 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Two weeks ago, fixed-rate mortgages hit a 44-month low of 9.56 percent after peaking for 1990 at 10.67 percent during the week ending May 4. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.92 percent, up from 7.86 percent last week, the lowest in 29 months. The one-year rate hit its high for the year of 8.63 percent in the week ending May 11. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: TV Chairman Pulls Popular Show, Opposes Shevardnadze Commentary
With AM-Soviet-Politics-Analysis, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The state broadcasting committee has canceled two episodes of one of the Soviet Union's most popular television programs because it disapproves of its political coverage, the show's host said Friday. The episodes of ``Vzglyad,'' English for viewpoint, were to include stories about outgoing Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, including a March interview in which he said he considered quitting to protest shootings by Soviet troops in his native Georgia, said the host, Alexander Lyubimov. Shevardnadze resigned on Dec. 21, saying he feared hard-line Communist force were pushing the Soviet leadership into a dictatorship. Program officials said the cancellation was clearly politically motivated and that it indicated a return to state censorship. The episodes were to have been broadcast Friday night and Jan. 4. on Soviet TV's main channel, said Lyubimov, who is also a lawmaker in the Russian republic's legislature. He said that Gostelradio, the state committee for television and radio, ``told us they don't like political issues'' broadcast on Channel 1 and said the programs should be withheld ``until ... the situation is more clear.'' He said Gostelradio's new chairman, lawmaker Leonid Kravchenko, told him that Channel 1 ``should be a presidential channel, serving the president and his policies, his politics.'' Andrei Shipilov, head of the youth office at Central Television, said the episodes were canceled ``for political reasons.'' But Lyubimov said ``Vzglyad'' could not ignore Shevardnadze's resignation and warning or the Congress of People's Deputies' vote to strengthen President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's powers. He said that when the weekly live news and entertainment program began in 1987 ``it was one of the first that broke the barriers of censorship on Soviet TV.'' ``We are worried about the coincidence between this event and the recent resignations of supporters of the liberal cause on Gorbachev's team and the dramatic events at the Congress of People's Deputies,'' he said. ``So far, Gorbachev's team comprises old players and we can hardly express even cautious optimism in regard to our future. ... I think that this (cancellation) is another piece of Gorbachev taking over.'' Lyubimov said Friday night's program was scheduled to include interviews with Shevardnadze's aides discussing his resignation. Vice President Gennady I. Yanayev, a long time Communist Party bureaucrat whose confirmation by the legislature Thursday dismayed leading reformers, had also been invited to appear, he said. The Jan. 4 broadcast was to include a 75-minute documentary on Shevardnadze, videotaped by a crew who accompanied the foreign minister on an eight-nation African tour in March, Lyubimov said. The documentary included a ``very frank'' interview in which Shevardnadze said he considered resigning over the bloody April 1989 clash in Tblisi, Georgia. Soviet troops shot and killed 19 pro-independence demonstrators. The weekly ``Vzglyad'' program includes a game show, a historical section, and American rock music in addition to the news segment. Lyubimov said the other segments would be broadcast as usual. Earlier this year, the Sunday night news program ``Seven Days'' was canceled after its popular host made remarks critical of the government. Two weeks ago, ``Authors' Television,'' a group of late night news and commentary programs, was also pulled off the air, although it has not formally been canceled. Kravchenko, former director-general of the official Tass news agency, was appointed head of Gostelradio last month as part of a shakeup of the state television monopoly. The reorganization replaced the one Central Television Station with four separate channels. Each was supposed to have creative and commercial independence. The government newspaper Izvestia said at the time Channel 1 would continue to carry the country's principal news programs and remain an outlet for government information and cultural programming. Earlier this year, the Supreme Soviet passed a new law on freedom of the press, giving legal backbone to Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or greater openness. It also ended censorship except on matters of state security.

DOC.HEAD: Norfolk Newspaper Goes to All-Day Format
DOC.TEXT: Norfolk's two daily newspapers, The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star, announced plans Friday to merge next year into a single, all-day newspaper under The Virginian-Pilot name. The newspapers will be combined in September. Subscribers to The Ledger-Star, an afternoon newspaper, will begin receiving afternoon editions of The Virginian-Pilot, which has been published in the morning. ``We will have the same number editions as we do now - four in the morning and one in the afternoon,'' said Frank Batten Jr., vice president and associate publisher of the newspapers. ``At present, the same reporters write for both newspapers, and many of the stories appear in both newspapers. Having one name on the masthead recognizes that The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star are almost the same newspaper today.'' The newspapers, owned by Landmark Communications Inc., combined their staffs in 1982. ``The change to one name will make it easier for people to understand what we are,'' Batten said. The weekday circulation of the morning newspaper paper is 157,292, and 72,066 for the afternoon paper. On Saturday and Sunday the newspapers publish a combined edition with 239,457 circulation on Saturday and 239,189 on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Ease Drought in Northwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Even though ...' to restore dropped word `said'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Storm Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Recent storms through the Pacific Northwest are easing four years of drought in Washington and Oregon. The snowy, cold weather that barreled into the western United States a week before Christmas has built up a substantial snow base in the Cascade Mountains that could fill reservoirs when it melts this spring, agriculture officials said. ``The Yakima River basin was just barely getting by on irrigation water in the past few years,'' said William Weller, a Spokane-based water supply specialist for the U.S. Department of Agriculture. ``It appears this year they will be in real good shape.'' But the weather has done little to alleviate California's equally long drought. ``Mostly, we had frost,'' said Emil Loe with the marketing division of the California Department of Food and Agriculture. ``If it did anything, it made things worse, because frost dries everything out a lot. There really was no measurable impact on the drought from last week's weather here.'' Temperatures plunging into the teens and 20s have wiped out 80 percent of California's navel orange crop for a loss of nearly $288 million in farming revenues, the department reported. Navel oranges make up about half of the state's total orange crop. Valencia oranges may also be affected, but agricultural officials will not know the extent of damage until harvesting begins in March. ``People in the industry say they've never seen anything like this,'' said Tom McNair, agricultural statistician for the California Agricultural Statistics Service. ``In future years freezes will be compared to this one. They will say, `It's not as bad as 1990.''' The state avocado producers report a loss of 20 percent of their crop. And in Imperial County on the Mexico border, cold weather will leave the lettuce, celery, broccoli and cauliflower crops a little brown around the edges, but edible, agricultural officials said. The melting snow has helped restock the Northwest's much-depleted water supply, but Barry Norris, engineer for the Oregon Water Resources Department, said the state has yet to recover fully from its dry spell. ``We need a good wet January and February, too,'' Norris said. ``We need a couple of better than average years to fill the reservoirs, get the soil moisture back in good shape and get our river levels back up. We've gone through a dry cycle.'' In Washington state, things started to improve in November as days of rain pushed more than a dozen rivers past flood stage and forced thousands to flee their homes. The winter precipitation is welcome as long as it stays in the highlands, agricultural officials said. ``It's good news if we can get it to stay up there in the mountains and melt off slowly for summer use,'' Weller said. ``But it was bad news for western Washington when we had warm rains come on snow and it melted into floods in November.''

DOC.HEAD: Town Reaches Solution on Pigeon Waste, Some Still Unhappy
DOC.TEXT: The great pigeon dropping debate here has been resolved with a decision to pay $67,000 to remove the offending detritus from town buildings, a solution that an opponent says is for the birds. ``I think it's crazy,'' said David Keenan, who showed up for one of the many meetings on the subject attired in a ``Pigeon-Buster'' mock space suit. Removal of the waste from Town Hall and a school stirred passionate debate, with Keenan's faction decrying the prospect of spending town money to do a job they said could be handled by volunteers. T-shirts were printed up with silhouettes of the ubiquitous pigeons surrounded by the familiar red circle with a diagonal slash drawn through it. The town had set aside $125,000 for the job, but officials received bids lower than that. The lowest bid failed to meet state specifications, so the $66,836 contract is going to the second-lowest bidder, Venture Asbestos Abatement of Salem, N.H., according to Laurie Benoit, administratative assistant to the town manager. ``Everything is in place and we should have a signed contract by the end of next week,'' she said Friday. ``It's been a good process. There's been a lot of public input and it's been a good learning experience.'' But Keenan, a real estate agent, contractor and candidate for position of selectman, was less sanguine. He noted that Amherst, a small town that mixes Yankee heritage with the intellectual circles from two private colleges and the state university, is holding a special meeting to debate a resolution urging Bush not to go to war in the Persian Gulf. ``That's Amherst,'' said Keenan, one of the few Republicans in town. ``It can't clean up its own pigeon poop but we're going to have a special Town Meeting to tell Congress what to do.'' The town of about 34,000 has voted to oppose every war since 1812 and suggested banning the nuclear bomb during the Cold War. It voted to declare the town a nuclear-free zone and to ban officials from investing town funds in companies doing business in South Africa or companies that make nuclear weapons. In the pigeon debate, Benoit said the volunteer approach suggested by Keenan and fellow businessmen was impractical because it raised too many insurance and liability problems and ran afoul of state bidding laws. ``There was no way. We tried,'' she said. Keenan said he still believes in the volunteer approach. ``We would rather do things like that than keep raising our taxes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Arabs and Iran Move Closer, But Some Skeptical
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Spurred by Iraqi aggression, Persian Gulf Arab leaders say they're ready to forge a new regional security structure with Iran, a country that they feared for years. But some observers are skeptical that Iran and its neighbors will ever overcome mutual suspicions and engage in meaningful cooperation to defend the oil-rich region. The Gulf Cooperation Council - Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and Kuwait - was formed in 1981 primarily to counter the threat posed by Iran's Islamic revolution and its stated aim of toppling the conservative Gulf monarchies. But Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani began a process of rapprochement with the gulf states following the death of Iran's revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in June 1989. Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait accelerated that process. Rafsanjani's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, has been courting Iran's jittery neighbors since then. Saddam's actions proved how vulnerable the gulf states were and underlined their dependence on the Americans, despite massive spending on high-tech weaponry. The leaders of the GCC states made clear during a four-day summit in Doha that ended last Tuesday that they now believe Iran has to be part of long-term defense arrangements in the strategic region. A summit communique expressed interest in developing ``special relations'' with Tehran and urged it to settle differences with GCC states ``seriously and realistically.'' Kuwait's minister of state for foreign affairs, Sheik Nasser Mohammed al-Sabah, stressed during a recent visit to Tehran: ``Without the powerful presence of Iran, no regional security is possible or practical.'' Sheik Nasser's statement reflected how the political map of the region has been turned upside down by the invasion of Kuwait, producing alignments that only a couple of years ago would have been unthinkable. Iranian-backed terrorists for years waged a bombing campaign in Kuwait and tried to assassinate the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, in 1985. The Iranians plotted in 1981 to topple Bahrain's ruling family. Saudi Arabia was a target for Iranian subversion where it hurt most, the annual Hajj to Mecca. Riyadh severed relations with Tehran in April 1988. Most of the GCC states sided with Iraq during the 1980-88 war with Iran. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia gave an estimated 34 billion dollars to Baghdad. Iran attacked their ships in retaliation. Since the 1988 cease-fire, Rafsanjani has tried to end Iran's isolation and rebuild bridges with his neighbors. The indications are that Saudi Arabia and Iran could soon restore relations, a necessary step before the two biggest gulf states can join forces in a new security structure. That's unlikely to happen until Kuwait has been liberated and Saddam humbled. There will be other obstacles to overcome. Iran is likely to demand a pre-eminent position in any alliance that emerges, something the gulf Arabs are not expected to accept without argument. Diplomats said Iran stands to gain the most from an alliance and cautioned that Tehran was not expected to abandon its aim of regional domination. Iran has opposed the invasion of Kuwait, but it has also condemned the Western military force brought into the gulf by the Saudis. The Americans say they want to see a new security structure in the region, which sits on two-thirds of the world's oil reserves. Saudi and other Arab officials say that will involve sizeable U.S. forces staying on for some time, a factor likely to antagonize the Iranians and other Moslem fundamentalists. Iran's radicals oppose any rapprochement with Saudi Arabia. Rafsanjani has largely outflanked them in a post-Khomeini power struggle, but they remain a thorn in his side. Tehran's radical Kayhan daily on Friday dismissed a regional defense accord as ``a mirage'' and warned that Iran would be ``the only loser.'' ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Aly Mahmoud, chief of the AP's Bahrain bureau, has covered Persian Gulf affairs for more than a decade.

DOC.HEAD: Government Wants ``Disneyland,'' But Residents Unamused
LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: Pehlad Singh, a farmer in this small village in northern India, is fighting a battle - against an amusement park. Seven centuries ago, Singh's ancestors fought the Moslem Emperor Balban when he tried - and eventually succeeded - to take over their area. Now, Singh and his fellow villagers want to stop roller coasters and lagoons from being built on their ancestral lands. They say the park, which is popularly called ``Disneyland'' but has no connection with the real one in California, will destroy their source of livelihood and ruin their culture. ``The government wants to take our land and drive us out,'' Singh said. ``We have warned them that rivers of blood will flow if they touch our land.'' The confrontation began early this year when the government of the northern state of Haryana announced plans to build India's first big amusement park on 28,000 acres of land inhabited and farmed by 150,000 people in 28 villages. The government said the park would cost an estimated $555 million. But the villagers, mostly small farmers and cattle grazers, said the government was trying to uproot them. Chief Minister Om Prakash Chautala, Haryana's highest elected official, pushed the project through despite the people's resistance. Even before ``Disneyland,'' Chautala's name was synonymous with dynastic rule and corruption for many people. Villagers accused Chautala of using the amusement park to push up land prices. They said Chautala and his friends had bought a lot of the surrounding land, which would appreciate enormously once the amusement park was built. Haryana's tourism minister, Siri Krishan Hooda, dismissed ``all these allegations'' as ``baseless.'' The people's fears were aggravated further last month when Chautala's father, Devi Lal, became India's deputy prime minister and tourism minister. Chautala succeeded his father as Haryana's chief minister last winter but was forced out of office by political infighting at the national level and the killings of at least 12 people when he ran for the state legislature. But his father retains the political clout to expedite the ``Disneyland'' project. In December, Devi Lal met the villagers and told them he would give the go-ahed for the project. Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, who accompanied Devi Lal, said he supported the project and wanted to see it through. ``This is all nonsense,'' said Khem Chand, a 60-year-old retired soldier who lives in one of the villages that would be supplanted by the amusement park. ``Instead of providing us education and basic health care, the government is offering us amusement.'' Like many towns, none of the 28 villages in this area, 25 miles southwest of New Delhi has sufficient drinking water. The nearest hospital is several miles away and is usually filled to capacity. ``The government is legally right but morally wrong,'' said Amrit Singh, a village headman, ``They say they have no money to spare for village development but have enough for this useless project.'' Singh's lament - and that of many others - strikes at the heart of India's most pressing problem: how to develop an overpopulated country of 880 million plagued by illiteracy and poverty without alienating the people. ``The amusement park is not a need of the people,'' said Prem Chowdhry, a historian and a native of Haryana. ``It's an example of development that leaves people out.'' The Haryana government doesn't agree. It says it will pay the villagers $5,555 an acre for their land and will employ them in the amusement park. But the money offered by the government is several times lower than the market price. India has a huge black market economy that pushes up the price of land enormously. If the villagers sold their land to businessmen, they could get between $27,777 and $55,555 an acre. But the state government has frozen all land sales in the villages. The villagers are also wary of the government's guarantee of employment. They say the government seldom employs local people in tourist resorts. Two years ago the government held out a similar promise when it built a motel in Damdama. It hired four villagers, but fired them within a week. Many villagers say they will not be able to put the money the government gives them to good use. ``We have been farmers for generations and have never handled large sums of money,'' said Dhoom Mahase, a 42-year-old farmer. ``Too much money will only destroy us.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Drops Demand for Protocol, Calls for Renewed Talks
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's secessionist parliament agreed Friday to drop conditions on negotiations with the Kremlin over Lithuanian independence and called for a new round of talks, the Baltic government said. The vote by the Lithuanian Supreme Council was intended to restart talks with Soviet officials that were bogged down over Lithuania's demand for signing of a ``protocol on the starting, goals and conditions'' of negotiations. Soviet officials had refused during preliminary talks to sign the protocol, insisting the preliminary talks themselves represented negotiations. The sides agreed last June to start negotiations after Soviet officials said they would lift an economic embargo if Lithuania suspended its March declaration of independence for 100 days. Counting toward the deadline would begin with the start of negotiations. The parliament voted Friday ``to allow the state delegation ... to begin negotiations with the U.S.S.R. without a previously determined negotiations commencement protocol, but without violating the sovereignty of the Lithuania state,'' according to Lithuanian statement sent by telex. Lithuania President Vytautas Landsbergis, in a speech to the parliament, said he was ready ``to soften the demand for a ... protocol whose signing the Lithuanian side had considered necessary for the start of negotiations,'' the pro-Lithuanian news agency Baltfax reported. The statement gave no date for the start of talks. There was no immediate reaction from the Kremlin. During the preliminary talks in Moscow last fall, the Soviet delegation was led by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who suffered a heart attack last week. It was unclear who would lead the Soviet side in his place.

DOC.HEAD: Professors Debate Diversity in Literature
DOC.TEXT: Watch your language. Some 10,000 academics - representing a veritable ``Who's Who'' of English and language professors - were in town Friday. The president of the Modern Language Association says the group's annual convention is bent on exploring ``the newest of methods and the oldest of texts.'' ``I think this association really represents a great commitment to diversity of inquiry and freedom of thought,'' said Catharine Stimpson, president of the 32,000-member organization. Stimpson said much debate in academic circles today focuses on the trend on college campuses to teach and review literature beyond the traditional scope of Western Civilization. New perspectives include those of minority, feminist, Third-World and homosexual authors. The trend has been criticized for forcing students into ``politically correct'' interpretations of written works and moving away from the study of classics. But the purpose of studying literature is to learn about cultural values and that study shouldn't be limited to old methods and established texts, said Stimpson, an English professor at Rutgers University in New Jersey. ``There are lots of different perspectives. Some are richer than others and some are more comprehensive than others,'' Stimpson said. ``Historically you can look back at literature to see the way it's shaped culture's ideas of what is beautiful, what is true.'' Many professors and graduate students welcomed the move toward exploring more diverse literature. Some criticized more traditional presentations for giving the impression that authors must be white, male, European and dead to be worth studying. ``These newer texts, I think, will show students that literature is still an open-ended enterprise,'' said Robert Hamner, a professor at Hardin-Simmons University in Abilene, Texas. ``A writer doesn't have to be dead to deal with serious issues.'' Hamner, who specializes in Caribbean literature, has been teaching since 1968. He said while the movement toward diversity isn't new, it's finally gaining attention. ``Some students find it exciting, they're looking for something new and interesting,'' Hamner said. ``I tell them to remember that these writers are not being touted because they're minority artists. They are just good authors.'' But introducing a more diverse selection of literature isn't just a matter of choosing the authors and telling students to start reading, said Susan K. Harris, who teaches at Queens College, City University of New York. ``Philosophically I'm all for it,'' said Harris, who specializes in American literature and 19th century women authors. ``But on a practical level I'm still struggling.'' Harris said professors encounter difficulty drawing critical and thematic connections between the newer texts and the classics. ``I have found ways to talk about the new literature in artistic terms,'' she said. ``People critical of the new approach often feel it's all come down to the fact that we've thrown out art in favor of diversity.''

DOC.HEAD: Greece to Pardon Imprisoned Members of Former Right-Wing Dictatorship
DOC.TEXT: The conservative government announced Friday it intends to pardon nearly all the imprisoned leaders of the 1967-74 right-wing dictatorship. The announcement to free seven of the eight former military leaders outraged socialists, Communists and other leftists, thousands of whom were jailed or exiled during the dictatorship. Many politicians and other citizens were tortured. Andreas Papandreou, whose socialist government ruled from 1981 to 1989, denounced the decision as an ``insult to those that fought and died for democracy in our country.'' Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis proposed the pardon for humanitarian reasons after meeting with President Constantine Caramanlis. Justice Minister Athanassios Kanellopoulos said the ministry's pardons committee will discuss it Monday, and approval was expected. According to practice, a pardon is proposed by the government and approved by the committee, clearing the way for a presidential decree. Eight members of the junta are serving prison terms ranging from 20 years to life imprisonment for their involvement in the military coup. Since their sentencing by a special court in 1975, they have refused to apply for pardons. The only junta member left out of the proposed pardon was Dimitris Ioannides, who engineered a failed 1974 coup in nearby Cyprus, a disaster that led to the partition of the Mediterranean island and Greece's return to civilian rule. Those serving life sentences include former Col. George Papadopoulos, 71, who led the April 1967 army coup in Greece; his brother Constantine, 69; and Ioannides, 67, a former brigadier who in turn overthrew Papadopoulos. They were originally sentenced to death for high treason. The rest of those jailed are former military officers convicted of torture. The military took over the government in 1967 following a period of political instability, and Papadopolous vowed at the time: ``There is no possibility of democracy as practiced in the past ever returning to Greece.'' The junta was condemned in the West as clumsy and authoritarian. Its political opponents were tortured by the military police and exiled by the thousands to barren Greek islands. The United States distanced itself from the junta and temporarily banned arms sales to Greece, but then-Vice President Spiro Agnew went to Greece in 1971 in a visit seen a tacit approval of the regime. The junta relinquished power after a student uprising in November 1973 and Ioannides' failed 1974 coup in Cyprus aimed at uniting the island with Greece. The short-lived coup resulted in Turkey invading the island, ostensibly to protect the Turkish-Cypriot minority. The July 1974 invasion of Cyprus brought Greece and Turkey to the brink of war. The military turned over power latr that year to an interim government led by Caramanlis, which oversaw elections. Caramanlis also had immediately commuted the death sentences handed down by the special court. Six other members of the junta have been released over the years for health reasons. Papandreou, the main opposition leader, said the government's decision to pardon the junta members would allow them to claim their 1967 military coup was justified. ``It is a case of justification. They didn't ask for a pardon. It was imposed on them from above,'' Papandreou said. The Communist-dominated Coalition of the Left and Progress said it considered ``the government decision an insult to the democratic feelings of the Greek people.'' Mitsotakis' conservative New Democracy returned to power in April after losing to the Socialists in 1981. The prime minister said Caramanlis did not have any objections to his decision.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Carriers Shove Off for Operation Desert Shield
LaserPhotos NK1,NY25
DOC.TEXT: With tears streaming, they stood on the piers and watched and waved. Wives and mothers, fathers and friends, they strained to catch a last glimpse of the gray-hulled ships whose silhouettes bled into a foggy gray horizon. Friday was shipping-out day for 16,000 sailors and Marines. For the first time since the Vietnam War, two aircraft carriers - the America and the Theodore Roosevelt - were sent overseas at the same time from the huge Norfolk Naval Base. Six other ships assigned to the carriers' battle groups also left the Virginia port, and nine other Navy vessels sailed from New York City and Mayport, Fla. They are being sent to the Persian Gulf to augment American forces in Operation Desert Shield. For those whose loved ones are aboard the ships, it was a difficult farewell. ``I wish men would stop being so greedy,'' a sobbing Michelle Coats of Virginia Beach said of the crisis that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Mrs. Coats married seaman Brad Coats of the destroyer Caron just last weekend and celebrated a combined Christmas-honeymoon at home. A brisk wind, occasional drizzle and temperatures just above freezing failed to keep hundreds of family members off the piers as ships pulled away. A few people waved American flags; others carried signs with personal messages, such as ``Love Ya Jim.'' Emotions ran high, and many people cried and hugged each other as the ships shoved off. ``Once he goes out, he'll have a great experience,'' said Vida Tyndall of Covington, Ga., whose son, Dorian Cheek, is assigned to the Roosevelt. ``But the threat of war puts a damper on the excitement.'' Cheek, a port equipment maintenance specialist, said he was thrilled at his first deployment but would miss his family. ``Can't wait to get over and get back,'' he said. Joseph Leyes of Millford, Conn., who came with his wife, Margaret, to watch the departure of their son Louis aboard the Caron, said he felt ``sad, excited, supportive, frightened.'' ``They're going to go out there, they're going to do a job, they're going to come back,'' Leyes said. ``I'm very confident they know what they're doing.'' How long the deployment will last is the second big question for families, after their concerns about a war. ``We know it's going to be a long time,'' said 13-year Navy veteran Gordon Wilson of Norfolk, a Roosevelt crewman who said he hopes to return in time for his son's 10th birthday next September. ``This will be the longest he's ever been away,'' said his wife, Toni. She said the crisis has given her a keen interest in following the news. ``You cling to every word when you hear something about the Roosevelt or the Navy or the Persian Gulf,'' Mrs. Wilson said. The America and Roosevelt will join three other carriers in the area: the Kennedy, Saratoga and Ranger.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Wins New Power, But Will It Help?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS bio note at bottom.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won victory after victory at the Congress of People's Deputies session that ended this week. But he still may have come out a loser. The 59-year-old Soviet president gained new constitutional powers, streamlined the executive branch of government, and pushed reluctant lawmakers into confirming his nominee for the new job of vice president. But he came no closer to solving the key question of how to hold the 15 republics together - a problem that burst onto the surface again Thursday, the final day of the Congress, in an angry rift with the Russian Federation over the national budget. Earlier in the 10-day session, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's sudden resignation and dramatic warning that the country was moving toward dictatorship caused international concern over the fragility of Gorbachev's democratic reforms. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov's heart attack deprived Gorbachev of a second faithful political ally, at least temporarily. And in choosing Communist Party apparatchik Gennady I. Yanayev as vice president, Gorbachev missed an opportunity to pick a better-known figure who might have stopped his slide in public opinion polls. ``The more the president surrounds himself with little-known politicians, the lower his own rating will be,'' reformist lawmaker and Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak told reporters. The 2,250-member Congress, which usually meets twice a year, is the country's highest legislative body and must approve all constitutional amendments. After a carefully orchestrated debate - Chairman Anatoly Lukyanov shut off the microphones of dissenters and refused to allow votes on their motions - the lawmakers overwhelmingly approved Gorbachev's reorganization of the executive branch. Gorbachev asked for, and got, a ``vertical line of authority'' from the presidency, through the new Cabinet of Ministers, to government officials at the regional, city and village level. In the past, decisions by the ministries could be overturned by the Supreme Soviet, the 542-member standing legislature elected by the Congress. Now, the ministries answer directly to the president. The streamlining, coupled with the authority previously granted to issue presidential decrees, gives Gorbachev strong weapons to put down ethnic disputes, enforce economic changes and impose other orders. His only defeat was a vote against creating a Supreme State Inspectorate, a new law enforcement agency to ensure compliance with his decrees. But a presidential aide said Gorbachev believes he can still establish the inspectorate - by decree. With his dual position as leader of the Communist Party and head of the restructured government, the only thing now standing between Gorbachev and authoritarian rule may be his personal commitment to democracy. Fear of that commitment wavering under pressure from hard-liners appears to have been behind Shevardnadze's warning. ``My guess is that what he worried about was not so much a conscious effort that, `We're going to establish a dictatorship,' but a slide into the use of authoritarian methods,'' a western diplomat in Moscow said Friday. ``For example, if force is used in some of the republics now, and that brings a reaction of the people, you could get an escalating situation, and a growing bloodbath.'' Short of using force, it is unclear how much obedience Gorbachev can expect from the republics, no matter what legal authority he might have. That uncertainty was underlined on the final day of the Congress when the president demanded that lawmakers in Russia, the largest of the 15 republics, reverse their stance on the national budget. Russia's parliament recently asserted control over the lion's share of taxes and other government revenues raised on its territory. Gorbachev told the Congress that Russian lawmakers had voted to cut the republic's contribution to the 1991 national budget by about 80 percent. As though giving a stern lesson to a lazy pupil, Gorbachev ticked off some major items in the national budget: education, health care, scientific research, defense and subsidies for heavy industry. ``What are we supposed to do, disband our military entirely and stop all fundamental science?'' he said. Gorbachev said he was now unable to conclude a temporary agreement to maintain economic ties between the republics pending the completion of a new Union Treaty, the fundamental document that formed the country in 1922. If other republics follow Russia's suit, he warned, the result could be ``the collapse not only of the economy, but of the union.'' After Gorbachev's impassioned speech, the response from Russian lawmakers was an unsettling silence. The republic's president, Boris N. Yeltsin, was on a trip to the Yakutsk region of Siberia. Its parliament had recessed for the New Year's holiday. When the Russian lawmakers convene next month, Gorbachev will face a severe test of his moral and political authority - and his new constitutional powers are unlikely to be much help. ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Alan Cooperman is a correspondent for The Associated Press based in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: LA's First Black City Councilman Dies
DOC.TEXT: Gilbert Lindsay, the city's first black city councilman who played an instrumental role in shaping the modern skyline of Los Angeles, died Friday. He as 90. Lindsay, who had served on the council since January 1963, died at Queen of Angels-Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center, said Bill Chandler, a spokesman for Mayor Tom Bradley. Lindsay had been hospitalized for four months by a stroke. The cause of death was cardiac arrest, the mayor's office said. ``I am deeply saddened that Gil Lindsay, with whom I shared a lifelong friendship and more than 27 years of public life, has died,'' said Bradley. Lindsay was born on a Mississippi cotton plantation in 1900. He served in the Army's 10th Cavalry and the 25th Infantry. After leaving the military, he moved to Los Angeles and became a janitor in the city's Department of Water and Power. In 1952, Lindsay signed on with county supervisor Kenneth Hahn's campaign. Hahn, the longest-serving supervisor in state history, made Lindsay the county's first black deputy supervisor. After a decade in that job, Lindsay was appointed to the vacant 9th District seat on the City Council in 1963. In that job, representing the downtown financial district, Chinatown and Little Tokyo, he helped push through legislation lifting the city's 12-story building height limit. That prompted a boom in high-rise development that transformed the city.

DOC.HEAD: Fifteen Injured in Clash
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of two rival political parties battled with homemade bombs in a Dhaka suburb Friday, leaving at least 15 people injured, police said. The clash was the first major outbreak of violence between political parties since the ouster of President Hussein Muhammed Ershad earlier this month. It erupted when the Awami League and the Freedom Party held campaign rallies at the same place. Police said both sides exploded homemade bombs during the hourlong melee. They said they used steel-tipped batons to stop the fighting. Police said three policemen were among the 15 injured.
