The Awami League is led by Sheik Hasina, who was at the forefront of seven weeks of nationwide protests urging the ouster of Ershad. Ershad stepped down Dec. 6, turned over power to a caretaker government and was placed under house arrest. The Freedom Party is led by Syed Farukur Raman, a retired army colonel, who took part in a 1975 coup that ousted Bangladesh's first independent government headed by Sheik Mujibur Rahman, father of Mrs. Hasina. The caretaker government headed by acting President Shahabuddin Ahmed has announced parliamentary elections for Feb. 27. A Home Ministry press communique warned Friday that the government will deal sternly with incidents of violence between political parties. ``The government wants all political parties to exercise restraint for holding peaceful elections,'' the communique said.

DOC.HEAD: Italian TV Decides to Squelch Saddam Interview
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: Italy's state-owned television decided Friday not to air an interview with Saddam Hussein, saying the broadcast might ``disturb the efforts'' for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. The decision to squelch the broadcast indefinitely drew sharp protest from reporters. The journalist who conducted the interview, Bruno Vespa, threatened to resign. The director-general of RAI television, Gianni Pasquarelli, announced the move in a letter to Vespa, the highly regarded director of the nightly TG-1 news broadcast. ``Italy is president of the European Community and we must avoid, in a moment of extreme delicacy, any act that could contribute to disturb the efforts that are being made to find a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis,'' said the letter, read on the evening broadcast. It did not say how the interview might have affected peace efforts. Vespa told viewers of Friday night's TG-1 program that he disagreed with the decision. ``I expressed to the director-general my surprise and my complete dissent,'' he said. A RAI spokesman said he did not know if the Italian government had asked the network to stop the broadcast. The government funds RAI and political parties have broad influence in its operation. The Iraqi leader has given numerous interviews to Western television stations since his country invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Vespa said that during the 1-hour, 40-minute interview conducted several days ago, Saddam had harshly criticized the United States and seemed to rule out negotiations. He added that Saddam had ``implicitly admitted'' he would use chemical weapons in a war. The editorial committee of the RAI said it supported Vespa in the dispute. ``The invitation (by Pasquarelli) to not transmit the interview appears like an act of self-censorship that the editorial staff of TG-1 can not consider acceptible in any way,'' the committee said in a statement. Pasquarelli, who belongs to the dominant Christian Democrat Party, became director-general of RAI earlier this year after serving as managing director of the state highway corporation. He was previously a television journalist. The Christian Democrats control appointments at RAI-1, the channel that broadcasts Vespa's program. The second-biggest party in the government, the Socialists, have strong influence at RAI-2, another state-owned channel. The Communists, Italy's biggest opposition party, condemned the decision not to show the interview. ``We have denounced for some time the new climate of censorial secrecy that is predominant at the RAI,'' said Walter Veltroni, the party's spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyer Files Motion to Have Demjanjuk Released
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for convicted Nazi war criminal John Demjanjuk said Friday he has filed a motion to have his client freed because of new evidence that could prove his innocence. The Supreme Court will hear the motion Monday, said Yoram Sheftel, Demjanjuk's Israeli attorney. The court hear Demjanjuk's appeal of his death sentence last summer, but has not yet issued its final ruling. Demjanjuk, a retired auto worker, lived in Ohio after the war and was extradited to Israel for trial in 1986. Sheftel said a file discovered in Moscow proves that his client is not ``Ivan the Terrible,'' a gas-chamber operator at the Treblinka camp in Nazi-held Poland who raped, beat and stabbed Jews headed to their deaths. The newly discovered file contains ``numerous statements taken in the 1950s by Ukrainian guards at Treblinka that state clearly that `Ivan the Terrible' was Ivan Marczenko,'' Sheftel said. ``There is no dispute that Demjanjuk was never called Marczenko and was born under (the name) Demjanjuk,'' Sheftel added. The prosecution contends Demjanjuk took the alias Marczenko because it was his mother's maiden name. Sheftel said he discovered the material in Moscow three weeks ago and that the prosecution had flown to Moscow to investigate it. Prosecutor Michael Sheked could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament to Look into Romanian Visit by Ex-King Michael
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has decided to investigate officials who allowed former King Michael to enter Romania on Christmas Day but then deported him, state media reported Friday. Deputies from all parties decided to form a multiparty commission to investigate and asked a full report from Interior Minister Doru Viorel Ursu, the official news agency Rompres reported. Opposition parties in the assembly criticized the National Salvation Front government for deporting Michael hours after authorities let him into the country. Lawmakers from the governing party demanded that airport authorities and the Interior Ministry be investigated for letting the 69-year-old Michael in, allegedly without a visa. The former monarch was flown back to Swiss exile in a military plane early Wednesday, less than 12 hours after arriving on his first visit to Romania since Communists forced him to abdicate in 1947. His wife, Anne de Bourbon-Parma, a daughter and accompanying staff and reporters were also ejected. A statement issued by Michael's office in Geneva and carried by Rompres on Friday said he was in Romania ``on a perfectly legal basis'' and blamed the ``highest Romanian authorities'' for expelling him. It said this could not prevent Michael's ``unabated wish to travel to Romania as a free citizen of this country.'' The former king ``declares himself ready to serve the cause of the Romanian people,'' it added. But Deputy Foreign Minister Teodor Melescanu said Michael could have been tried for ``fraudulent border crossing'' and would have faced up to six months in jail, if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: North Carolina Sues Dredge Company For Cost of Bridge Repair
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina filed a lawsuit Friday seeking $5.5 million from the operator of a dredge that broke loose from moorings and knocked out the only road link to Hatteras Island. North American Trailing Co. was negligent in the Oct. 26 accident because the dredge's captain failed to drop a second anchor during a storm, the lawsuit said. The accident stranded residents and tourists on the island. The U.S. District Court suit filed in Norfolk, Va. seeks money to repair a damaged 370-foot section of the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge. ``We think they were negligent in making their decision to anchor where they did in light of weather forecasts,'' said Grayson Kelly, a spokesman for the state attorney general's office. ``We think they were negligent in being unable to navigate under the bridge without striking the bridge, which they were required to do under contract by the Corps of Engineers,'' he said. The U.S. Coast Guard ruled Dec. 18 that the dredge captain, William Cliett, may have been negligent in not dropping a second anchor to help keep the craft from slamming into the bridge. There was no answer Friday to repeated telephone calls to North American Trailing's offices. The cost of repairing the bridge initially was estimated at about $3 million, but was raised to $5.5 million, Kelly said. The amount could go up again, he said. In testimony before the Marine Safety Office in Norfolk last month, Cliett said the vessel was anchored in its usual place before the accident. He said weather conditions ``well beyond the conditions which had been forecast'' led to the accident. Officials estimated in mid-November that repairs, which are under way, would take until the end of January to complete. But many of the island's 5,000 residents said they expected bad winter weather to prolong repairs. The state is spending $20,000 a day on ferry service to Hatteras Island, another cost the state hopes will be passed to North American Trailing, Kelly said. The Coast Guard said Cliett chose to try to free the vessel rather than secure it with a second anchor. ``Under the circumstances, it would have been prudent to use all means available and a second anchor may have added sufficient holding power to prevent the (accident),'' the Coast Guard said in a statement. ``The master's failure to use the second anchor constitutes evidence of negligence on his part.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Objects to Kuwait's U.N. Envoy
DOC.TEXT: Iraq referred to its conquest of Kuwait as a ``felicitous union'' in a letter circulated Friday objecting to Kuwait's ambassador being seated in the General Assembly. The letter from the Iraqi U.N. Mission, dated Dec. 20 but released Friday, expresses a reservation to the General Assembly's credentials committee report in the case of Kuwait. Iraq did not try to challenge Kuwait's right to be seated. It would have lost any such attempt in the General Assembly by a humiliating margin. Nearly all the 158 other voting members would have backed Kuwait's membership. Iraq's letter says the ``felicitous union produced by the merger of Iraq and Kuwait on 9 August 1990 has made Iraq and Kuwait once again a single state represented by a single delegation to the United Nations. ``Accordingly, the delegation of Iraq enters a reservation with respect to the decision of the Credentials Committee to accept the credentials of the so-called delegation of Kuwait to the United Nations and wishes to have that reservation officially recorded.'' Baghdad announced Aug. 9 it had annexed Kuwait as Iraq's 19th province, a week after invading the emirate. The Security Council voted 15-0 that same day to declare the annexation null and void in international law, in Resolution 662.

DOC.HEAD: Police Step Up Patrols Near Terrorized University of Florida Campus
DOC.TEXT: Police will step up patrols in neighborhoods where five students were slain as the University of Florida's campus begins to fill up after the holiday break, the police chief said. The still unsolved killings happened in August at the beginning of the fall semester, Police Chief Wayland Clifton said. Five students, four females and a male, were stabbed to death and mutilated in their off-campus apartments. Clifton said confusion caused by students moving in, many not knowing their neighbors and being careless about security, may have been a factor in the slayings. The second semester starts Jan. 7. ``We want to be particulary cautious,'' Clifton said Thursday. Undercover and uniformed officers will patrol southwest Gainesville and other areas heavily populated by students, he said. Clifton didn't say how many officers will be sent to the neighborhoods. ``We want to saturate the area,'' he said. Clifton said a task force of investigators is making progress on the case and he believes it will be solved. The focus has faded from former University of Florida freshman Edward Lewis Humphrey, for weeks considered a strong suspect. He is serving a sentence in a mental institution for beating his grandmother.

DOC.HEAD: Foes Snub Romania's Iliescu, Warn of `New Dictatorship'
DOC.TEXT: Prominent members of the original leadership of Romania's revolution spurned President Ion Iliescu's invitation to attend a first anniversary celebration of the uprising Friday and warned of a ``new dictatorship.'' A spokeswoman at Iliescu's office said the celebration was going ahead as planned Friday evening, with most of those invited expected to attend. Eight founding members of the National Salvation Front, which took power during the December 1989 revolution against Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, said they would boycott celebrations at Iliescu's offices in Bucharest's Cotroceni Palace. In a letter, they accused the Front of having used them ``to lend legitimacy to the appearance of democracy ... as a democratic ornament for a masked new dictatorship.'' The group includes popular revolutionary figures such as former dissidents Doina Cornea and Ana Blandiana, intellectual Gabriel Andreescu and actor Ion Caramitru. ``We are united in the feeling that we were used from the beginning,'' said the letter, a copy of which was made available to The Associated Press. The Front overwhelmingly won elections last May. But the government it formed has come under increasing fire from opponents, who claim many of its leaders are old regime holdovers and still harbor Communist tendencies. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed on Dec. 25, 1989. Last week, Iliescu sent invitations to all 71 members of the Front's original council, hastily formed by former Communists, dissidents, prominent intellectuals and others on Dec. 22, 1989, when Ceausescu fled Bucharest. Many members, including the eight boycotters, soon resigned and later became Iliescu's most vocal critics. The letter from the eight said their attendance would have given the ``illusion of dialogue (with the government) which has proven impossible over the past year.'' Sources close to Iliescu, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the invitation was ``an honest attempt at reconciliation at a difficult time for Romania.'' Frequent, sometimes violent anti-government street protests have taken place since the May elections. In mid-June, six people were killed when police and pro-government miners suppressed a 53-day opposition rally in Bucharest. Government economic reforms proposed in November that included raising prices on many basic goods have also led to popular protests among consuers. On Friday, Finance Minister Teodor Stolojan presented to Parliament a national budget for 1991 of $7.2 billion, slightly higher than 1990's budget of $7 billion. He said state investments in the economy would decrease from $1.7 billion this year to $890 million in 1991 and would help slash a budget deficit that totaled $1 billion this year. He said private savings here could help boost the economy. ``There is enough money around for investments in the economy,'' Stolojan told Parliament. ``We do not need to allocate large sums from the budget.'' He urged quick adoption of new tax and foreign investment laws. He also said that Romania's currency, the leu, ``is still far from convertibility.'' The leu was devalued officially in November from 20 to the dollar to 35 to the dollar. Its unofficial value on the parallel market usually exceeds 120 to the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed, 27 Hurt When Bus Flips in Spain
DOC.TEXT: A bus carrying passengers leaving the capital for the New Year's holiday flipped over and smashed into a sign post Friday four miles north of Madrid, killing at least 12 riders and injuring 27, officials said. Investigators blamed apparent excessive speed, a spokesman for the Civil Guard Traffic Office said. He said the bus veered off M-30 city ring road onto a new access road leading to the Madrid-La Coruna highway. The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said at at least four of those injured, including the driver and alternate driver, were in critical condition. The bus was bound for Vigo, on Spain's northwest coast.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets Year Sentence in Flag Burning
DOC.TEXT: A woman convicted of inciting violence after she burned an American flag to protest the military buildup in the Persian Gulf was sentenced Friday to one year in prison. Cheryl Lessin of Cleveland was taken to jail immediately after a judge imposed the sentence. Several of Lessin's supporters chanted ``Stop the U.S. war machine no matter what it takes'' as they left the Justice Center. Her lawyers said they will ask that Lessin be freed pending appeal. A jury in October convicted Lessin, 46, on a charge of inciting violence after she took part in an Aug. 10 protest against the presence of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The rally in downtown Cleveland escalated into scuffling and yelling after Lessin burned the flag. Two police officers testified that she ran through the crowd throwing punches and shouting obscenities. Lessin and other witnesses said at the trial that the protest was not a riot. Lessin's lawyer, Christopher Stanley, asked the Ohio Supreme Court to disqualify Common Pleas Judge Patricia Cleary, saying she was prejudiced, but the high court rejected the request. Stanley said Cleary should have instructed the jury that flag burning is a protected form of free speech. He said prosecutors used a state law against inciting violence to prosecute Lessin for burning the flag. Clearly said she applied the law correctly during the trial and in her jury instructions.

DOC.HEAD: Former Secret Police Chief Arrested in Chilean `S&L' Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A former secret police chief under the military regime was arrested Friday for his alleged involvement in a financial scandal that has shaken the Chilean army. Gen. Gustavo Abarzua wa held incommunicado by judge Marcos Libedinsky, who has five days to either charge or release him, said Abarzua's lawyer, Marcelo Cibie. Two other generals, Patricio Gualda and Patricio Varela, were briefly detained and questioned by Libedinsky, but were not charged. Libedinsky was appointed two months ago to investigate an illegal savings and loan scam in which hundreds of soldiers, lured by interest rates of up to 30 percent, deposited their savings with army officers. The bank, called La Cutufa after the name of a dog reportedly owned by one of its officers, collapsed when the operators fell short on payments. So far eight officers have been charged with breaking the banking law. News coverage of his investigation has clearly upset former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who turned over the government to elected President Patricio Aylwin in March after a 16-year dictatorship. Pinochet put the army on alert for several hours Dec. 19 to protest the investigation. The government, sensitive to the military's anger, has tried to keep a lid on the affair. But Pinochet did order an internal army investigation of the bank, and has given Libedinsky a list of 150 officers and non-commissioned officers who were punished by the military as a result of the probe. Many were discharged. Abarzua was the last chief of the feared military intelligence agency, known by its Spanish initials CNI, which was disbanded shortly before Pinochet stepped down. Abarzua, Gualda and Varela were retired in October by Pinochet, who remains commander of the 60,000-man army.

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Opposition Asks Protests To Oust President
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties called for immediate mass protests Friday to force President Mobutu Sese Seko from power. They said Mobutu is a dictator who has delayed a promised transition to democracy. It was the first time Mobutu's opponents joined in a common front. Mobuto has ruled this central African state for 25 years. He pledged in April to install a multiparty democracy within a year, but modified this later to say he would permit only three political parties to contest 1991 elections. The opposition emanded Friday that Mobutu resign and be replaced by a government of national unity to organize elections ending one-party rule. The Zairean leader is also under pressure from the United States and other Western governments. U.S. officials previously shrugged off accusations of human rights abuses in Zaire to support Mobutu as a bulwark against Marxism in the region. But Congress ignored appeals from the Bush administration and cut all aid to Mobutu's government following charges that Zairean troops massacred from 50 to 150 students at the University of Lubumbashi in a night raid last May 11. Mobutu's government said one student was killed in what it first described as ethnic factional fighting. Later, it blamed regional government officials for the attack and said they would be punished. The opposition on Friday asked an international inquiry into the incident. Mobutu refused such a request earlier from Belgium, the former colony power. At least six people were killed this month in demonstrations against price increases. Government foes say soldiers shot the six. Officials deny it. The opposition parties also complained Friday of economic hardship and devaluation of Zaire's currency.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Riders Near Wounded Knee for Centennial of Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with arrival of riders at Wounded Knee. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of American Indians on horseback arrived Friday at the site of the 1890 Wounded Knee massacre on the eve of its centennial. Religious ceremonies and other observations were planned for Saturday at the site of the final bloody chapter in the 19th century U.S.-Indian wars. Fifty riders set out Dec. 15 from Standing Rock Indian Reservation in north-central South Dakota. Others joined along the way. About 300 riders arrived at Wounded Knee at the conclusion of the 220-mile trip. The event they are commemorating occurred Dec. 29, 1890, when U.S. calvary troops killed hundreds of Sioux men, women and children at Wounded Knee. The exact number is a point of contention. The federal government says about 150 died; the Sioux say as many as 400. Among the riders on the pilgrimage to Wounded Knee was former American Indian Movement leader Russell Means, who declared Thursday that there is little left for the radical Indian organization to accomplish because tribes have learned to speak for themselves. ``There's no need for AIM to be a vanguard,'' Means said in an interview at Kyle, about 20 miles northeast of Wounded Knee. ``We're still around and we still make statements, but we're no longer needed because the Indian people have collectively risen up and said what they want to say independently.'' Means, who helped lead a takeover of Wounded Knee in 1973, said his return to the site had him ``swelling with a tremendous amount of prideful emotion.'' ``Wounded Knee proved to Indian people that it's all right to stand up and be an Indian, and that it's even worth fighting for,'' he said. Means helped organize an armed 71-day occupation of Wounded Knee on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation 17 years ago. Two men were killed and several others wounded in the action that divided the Sioux Nation. Resulting indictments against Means and about 115 others were dismissed by a judge.

DOC.HEAD: Suez Canal Chief Plays Down Iraqi Threat to Waterway
DOC.TEXT: The Suez Canal chief played down Iraq's threat to block navigation in the international waterway in the event of war. The Suez chairman, Mohamed Ezzat Adel, said his men can remove any obstacle in the strategic waterway that links the Mediterranean with the Red Sea within 48 hours. Adel made the remarks in a statement scheduled for publication Saturday in the state newspaper Akhbar El-Yom. The weekly said the comments were made in reaction to Iraqi threats to block navigation in the canal. He said it is hard for anything to block the canal because its navigation width is about 630 feet. The canal was widened several times under successive development plans carried out after Egypt and Israel signed a peace treaty in 1979. Adel also said the canal authority would lose about $4.3 million daily if war broke out in the Persian Gulf. He said 36 percent of gulf trade with the outside world was passing through the canal before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Since then, he said, the canal has been losing 29 percent of its income. He said navigation safety is being supervised by ``high security authorities.'' The reference could mean that the presidency and the Egyptian intelligence service are overseeing security of the canal. Adel told Egyptian new media three days ago that authorities are stepping up security in the canal. Canal sources first disclosed the heightened security to The Associated Press a week ago. They said the aim was to prevent a possible Iraqi attempt to scuttle a vessel in the waterway and block it. Sealing the 101-mile-long canal would greatly curtail the flow of troops and arms from Atlantic and Mediterranean points to the U.S.-dominated multinational force countering Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Test-Fires Second Missile This Week
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Friday test-fired a surface-to-surface missile for the second time this week, shooting it away from multinational forces in Saudi Arabia, the U.S. Central Command said. ``The firing appeared to be part of an additional testing or training mission,'' said Air Force Lt. Casey Mahon, a Central Command spokesman. Mahon said the missile landed in Iraq. He could not comment on the alert status of the 300,000 U.S. troops in Operation Desert Shield during the firing. Details about the flight path or the kind of missile were also not released. Reporters visiting the U.S. hospital ship Mercy said crew members went on a heightened state of alert because of the missile launch, carrying their protective gear against chemical weapons with them. Land-based troops were already on a heightened alert because of the possibility of a terrorist attack over the Christmas and New Year holidays. Iraq test-fired a missile Wednesday under nearly identical circumstances, the U.S. military said. British and U.S. military officials said Iraq test-fired SCUD missiles from east to west Dec. 2. Fired north to south, the missiles would hit Saudi Arabia, where multinational forces confront Iraq following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Concern has been expressed that the pressure of the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline allowing use of force against Iraq unless it withderaws from Kuwait might prompt Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to launch a pre-emptive strike. Saddam has threatened to hit Israel first to split the Arab and Western coalition ranged against him.

DOC.HEAD: Last Egyptian Military Debt Written Down to Zero
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday ordered forgiveness of the remaining $1 billion of Egypt's $6.7 billion in military debts as a reward the country for its cooperation with the U.S. efforts against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The president said the action was necessary for ``the success of Desert Shield,'' the code name for the U.S. military operation in the Persian Gulf. Bush's action, directing the Treasury department and Pentagon to reduce the debt to zero, completed the debt forgiveness which Congress approved as part of this year's $15.5 billion foreign aid package.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Named Commander of U.S. Navy Salvage Vessel
DOC.TEXT: A woman has been named commander of an active U.S. Navy vessel for the first time, officials said Friday. Lt. Cmdr. Darlene M. Iskra was installed as commander of the salvage vessel USS Opportune on Thursday night after Cmdr. Edgar J. Jones was flown back to the United States for a medical emergency, said Lt. Scott Campbell, public information officer for U.S. naval support activity in Naples. ``We've never had a female commanding officer of a deployable ship or ship that can be sent overseas,'' Campbell said. ``There's a little bit of naval history being made here.'' Iskra will command an all-male crew of about 100, Campbell said. Iskra, a special operations officer, is the most senior female diving officer in the Navy and is a graduate of officers' candidate school in Newport, R.I., Campbell said. She had originally been scheduled to succeed Jones on Jan. 24. The USS Opportune is assigned to the U.S. Sixth Fleet, based in Naples. It is a noncombatant vessel, said Campbell. As a result, the vessel will not be involved in military action in the event of a war in the Persian Gulf. However, the ship could be sent to an area outside the war zone to provide support. The ship is responsible for recovering equipment or the wreckage of ships or planes from the sea, and sometimes makes repairs to Navy vessels, Campbell said. It also tows disabled ships. The next woman scheduled to receive command of a Navy ship is Cmdr. Deborah Gernes, a surface warfare officer. She is scheduled to be installed in December 1991 and will command the USS Cimarron, Campbell said. Nearly 11 percent of all officers in the U.S. Navy are female, Campbell said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain To Inoculate Troops against Germ Warfare
DOC.TEXT: British troops will be vaccinated against possible germ warfare in the Persian Gulf, Ministry of Defense officials said Friday. Earlier Friday, the U.S. Defense Department said American troops will receive similar vaccinations. No details emerged on how either U.S. or British officials intend to carry out the inoculation programs. Britain also said it will begin issuing gas masks to British civilians in the region. Intelligence reports warn that Iraq may wage warfare chemical and biological warfare. Iraq has used chemical weapons against rebellious Kurds at home and against Iran during their 1980-88 war. The Foreign Office earlier urged Britons to leave eastern Saudi Arabia by the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait. The Security Council authorized members to use force if Iraq remains in Kuwait after that date.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Quashes Anti-Hate Law, Renews First Amendment Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 20th graf pvs, `Sherman McDonald...,' to DELETE incorrect first name. Note language in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Justice was accused of two crimes by a prosecutor: setting fire to a house and using a racial slur to describe the inhabitants. ``Don't worry, it's just a bunch of niggers,'' Justice allegedly told neighbors after the fire. District Judge Thomas Shea agreed there was enough evidence to order Justice to stand trial on the arson charge. But he said the U.S. Constitution protected Justice's right to say whatever he wanted about his neighbors, contrary to Michigan's law prohibiting ethnic intimidation. The law, which took effect April 1, 1989, makes it a crime to threaten or harm persons or their property because of their race, religion or ethnic background. Conviction carries a maximum penalty of two years in prison and allows a jury to award triple damages to a plaintiff. At least 30 other states have similar laws. Shea's Nov. 28 quashing of the law applies only to his five-township jurisdiction about 20 miles west of Detroit. But Prosecutor William Delhey said he's afraid that eastern Washtenaw County could become a haven of hatred. ``We think Judge Shea was wrong and we want a determination of the constitutionality of the ethnic intimidation statute so it will be applied uniformly in the entire county,'' Delhey said. Justice, 21, of Superior Township, remains jailed in lieu of a $500,000 bond on the arson charge stemming from the Nov. 9 fire at the home of Sherwin McDonald. A trial before Circuit Judge Patrick Conlin is scheduled March 18. Justice faces up to 20 years' imprisonment if convicted. Delhey's office has asked Conlin to reinstate the ethnic intimidation charge, and he might rule by the end of January, said David Lady, chief assistant prosecutor. Shea said the law was unconstitutional because it violated First Amendment guarantees of free speech and was too vaguely worded. The American Civil Liberties Union agrees with him. ``The law's too vague to be able to stand,'' said Howard Simon, Michigan ACLU director. ``The appellate courts have got to come down with an interpretation.'' Justice's attorney, Don Ferris, believes the law violates free speech. But he also said prosecutors failed to prove Justice was motivated by prejudice. Ferris said no evidence was introduced at Justice's preliminary hearing that indicated he knew the McDonalds were black, or threatened them before the fire. The alleged racial statements were uttered after the fire and not to the McDonalds but to neighbors, who said Justice was drunk, the lawyer said. ``The problem with the law is, as Judge Shea ruled, parts of it are not very properly defined,'' Ferris said. ``The less clear the words are in a statute, it gives prosecutors ... a lot more discretion in applying the law.'' The author of Michigan's ethnic intimidation law predicted Shea's ruling would be reversed. ``It's definitely constitutional,'' state Sen.-elect David Honigman said. ``It doesn't regulate any kind of speech whatsoever. It regulates conduct.'' Similar laws in other states have survived challenges on constitutional grounds, Honigman said. The triple damages portion of the law has yet to be used. Honigman said the provision was meant to cripple organized hate groups. ``We can't legislate good will,'' he said. ``But we can make ill will terribly costly.'' McDonald, 29, a Ford Motor Co. engineer, said Shea's ruling added insult to the injury of having lost his home in the fire. ``If this isn't ethnic intimidation, nothing is,'' said McDonald, who now lives with his wife and twin daughters in an apartment. ``We always thought our girls would grow up in Washtenaw County. But if this is the type of judge that represents Washtenaw County, then maybe that won't be. ``Maybe we'll have to move back to Detroit, where it's safe.''

DOC.HEAD: Two More Carriers Sail for Gulf; Troops to Get Germ Warfare Vaccinations
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS spelling ``inoculations'' in 8th graf: ``In London,''
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon announced Friday it plans to vaccinate troops in the Persian Gulf against possible germ warfare attacks by Iraq, and a 17-ship carrier armada set sail to bring America's naval deployment in the region to a level unprecedented since the Vietnam war. The naval reinforcements, scheduled to arrive in the gulf in about two weeks, are carrying 16,000 Marines and sailors and include the carriers USS America and Theodore Roosevelt, each with about 80 warplanes, from the Norfolk Naval Base in Virginia. They will join three other carriers in the area - the USS Saratoga in the eastern Mediterranean, the USS Midway in the Arabian Sea and the USS Kennedy in the Red Sea. The fresh troops will bring the United States closer to its goal of having about 430,000 in Saudi Arabia and nearby waters to confront Iraq if it refuses to withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15 - the deadline imposed by the United Nations. Meanwhile, the Pentagon said it was preparing to inoculate troops against possible germ warfare by Iraq. ``We are committed to providing maximum protection for our troops, including protection against chemical and biological weapons,'' said a brief statement. ``We expect to begin a program of inoculations soon,'' it said, but did not provide further detail. The New York Times, which first reported the plan, said the inoculations could begin ``in a matter of weeks.'' It also said the United States doesn't yet have sufficient vaccines for all its troops in the gulf. In London, the British Defense Ministry said British troops taking part in Operation Desert Shield also would receive inoculations. The ministry said it was issuing gas masks to about British 21,000 civilians in the area. Britain is contributing about 21,000 troops to the anti-Iraq force. In other developments Friday, Iraq test fired a surface-to-surface missile for the second time this week. The U.S. Central Command in Saudi Arabia reported that the missle was fired away from multinational forces, and that it landed within Iraq. Military analysts also said that thousands of Iraqis have been trained for suicide attacks on the U.S.-led forces if war breaks out. CIA Director William Webster has said in recent weeks that Iraq has sizable stockpiles of biological weapons. Iraq denied the allegations. Biological weapons are basically germs - viruses and bacteria - that cause diseases such as cholera, anthrax, typhoid, botulism. They can be delivered by warheads on missiles, by low-flying planes spreading the germs much like a crop duster, or by contamination of water supplies. Unlike nuclear or even chemical arms, biological weapons are easy to make because they rely on the kind of agents and equipment used in manufacturing pharmaceuticals and are readily available on world markets. The U.S. Commerce Department, for example, approved more than 20 shipments of biological agents to the Iraqi government, according to a congressional staffer investigating the sales. The U.S. company which sold the agents believed they would be used for vaccinations, said the official. Defenses against germ warfare include protective clothing, masks, and vaccines. Experts caution, however, that dozens of diseases can be converted into weapons - making it hard to know against which to inoculate. Also, it could take one month or longer to develop immunity to some of the diseases after being vaccinated, said Dr. Sanford Kuvin, vice chairman of the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases. One of the diseases Iraq is believed to have in its arsenal is anthrax, an easily transmittable and severely incapacitating illness. The vaccine, however, is not commercially available because the only people who need it in this country are those handling imported raw hides and goat hair. The vaccine is only made by Michigan's public health lab, which is having trouble keeping up with the demands for gulf troops, Newsweek reported. Another disease Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is known to have in his arsenal is botulism, a form of stomach poisoning which is treatable with antibiotics but against which there is no vaccine. The United States wasn't the only nation gearing up for a possible fight. In London, the government ordered the call-up of 390 medical reservists for service in the gulf after getting too few volunteers. The British are members of the anti-Iraq coalition. And, to prevent being stranded by war, more than 250 Soviet citizens left Iraq Friday and 1,000 others were to be evacuated by Jan. 10. Soviet Deputy Premier Igor Belousov met with officials in Baghdad seeking to terminate numerous commercial contracts with Iraq. But Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu urged talks with Iraq on averting war. The State Department said, however, that there hadn't been any progress in efforts to arrange a meeting between Secretary of State James Baker and Saddam. Iraq wants Jan. 12 as the meeting date but Baker says he won't go after Jan. 3. For the second day in a row, the senior U.S. diplomat in Baghdad, Joseph C. Wilson, did not have any contact with the Iraqi foreign ministry, said Mark Dillen, a State Department spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: German Companies Accused of Helping Iraq's Nuclear Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 4th `I would...' to paraphrase part of quote in order to CLARIFY meaning. Pickup graf 5 pvs, `Spiegel and...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As world leaders debate Saddam Hussein's nuclear potential, the list of German companies alleged to have helped him advance Iraq's atomic technology grows. At least 100 German companies are suspected of helping Iraq develop its unconventional weapons capability, sources say. German officials won't say how many of those are being investigated for suspected nuclear technology exports. The news magazine Der Spiegel said this week that ``several dozen'' European companies were implicated and listed six German companies with some reported connection to Iraq's weapons program. ``I would not like to be George Bush and going to bed tonight'' with the uncertainty over whether Iraq has a nuclear bomb, said Kenneth Timmerman, editor of the Paris-based Middle East Defense News. Spiegel and the specialized McGraw-Hill publication, NuclearFuel, both alleged this week that German companies are suspected of supplying Iraq with sophisticated technology to make weapons-grade uranium. The companies and individuals named in the reports deny any wrongdoing. It is not clear how far along Iraq might be toward making a nuclear bomb. The British newspaper, The Sunday Times, reported earlier this month that Iraq might be only a year away from the goal. But a major source for its report, German engineer Bruno Stemmler, denied the paper's time frame in an interview Thursday. He said, based on a 1988 visit to Iraq, the country was at least five years from building a centrifuge that could make enriched uranium. It would then take several more years before a series of centrifuges, called cascades, could come on line. At least 1,000 cascades are needed for bomb production. Spiegel predicted it would be eight to 10 years before Iraq could build a bomb. ``Iraq is acquiring enrichment technology,'' a German official said on condition of anonymity. ``It's not believed that Iraq is now producing highly enriched uranium in significant quantities.'' But he said, without elaborating: ``You cannot exclude that they are doing something ... on an experimental level.'' The official, with access to intelligence data, said Iraq could be from two to seven years away from an atomic weapon. Timmerman, however, who chronicled Iraq's acquisition of poison gas in a book, said Friday that information he's received ``is so disturbing and the extent of delivery to Iraq from Germany and other places would appear so great, that I would not feel safe saying that Iraq does not have a bomb today.'' NuclearFuel has cited a secret government report it obtained last fall from the Economics Ministry, which monitors export regulations. The report says German centrifuge design may have been provided to Iraq by two engineers who formerly worked for a German centrifuge design company, MAN Technologien GmbH. It quoted a source who attended a secret briefing on the report as saying Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann ``told us that centrifuge equipment sent to Iraq was of German origin.'' In addition, officials have confirmed that customs officers last summer intercepted a German shipment of centrifuge parts at Frankfurt airport bound for Iraq. The International Atomic Energy Agency reviewed Iraq's declared nuclear facilities in November, under the terms of Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, of which Iraq is one of 141 signatories. The agency said it found nothing unexpected. So far, only one arrest has been reported in the scandal. The director of a Bonn-based weapons supplier remains under investigation for alleged export violations, officials say. Companies in other countries, including the United States, Britain, Switzerland and Brazil, have also been named in connection with suspected Iraqi nuclear development. As allegations mount against German companies, so does frustration in Washington. ``We know what the Germans are up to,'' said a U.S. Senate source on condition of anonymity. ``There is only an argument over how long it takes before he gets the bomb.'' He referred to Iraq's Saddam. German officials deny they are being lax. But one source in Bonn's inner circle said: ``Have you seen the harbor in Hamburg, you just can't control every container.'' Germany's federalist justice system also makes it difficult to halt violations, despite tough new export laws. Laws are drafted by the Economics Ministry, enforced through the Finance Ministry's Customs police, who can turn the case over to local authorities for further investigation and potential charges. Lutz Stavenhagen, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's top intelligence adviser, has suggested letting the country's counterespionage unit investigate suspected export violations. But the proposal is likely to meet with strong resistance in a country that remembers Hitler's police state. The latest allegations of German nuclear help to Iraq follows last week's announcement that the United States gave Germany a list of 50 companies suspected of breaking the international embargo against Iraq. A government official said Friday that of 87 companies under review, 16 had been cleared and 10 were being further investigated for allegedly preparing to break the embargo. The other cases are pending.

DOC.HEAD: Deputies Charge Vote Irregularities in Vice-President Balloting
DOC.TEXT: Reformist lawmakers on Friday questioned the fairness of this week's parliamentary election of Vice President Gennady Yanayev, alleging that ballots were incorrectly counted. The Interregional Group of Deputies, which represents 229 deputies in the Congress of People's Deputies, showed reporters what they said were seven ballots that were not submitted for tabulation at the Thursday session that elected Yanayev, Tass reported. Parliament officials charged with counting the votes had reported that only five ballots were not put into ballot boxes during the vote, the official news agency said, raising questions about other possible discrepancies. The group, founded by the late human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov, also echoed accusations that approval of strong new presidential powers was dangerous. The country ``is heading toward dictatorship where the key role is assigned to repressive bodies and violence could become the major means of solving internal political issues,'' the group said in a statement. Yanayev was elected on the second ballot at the end of the stormy 10-day session, after deputies initially rejected his nomination by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. On the first secret ballot, deputies voted 1,089-583 for Yanayev, leaving him 31 votes short of the margin needed for confirmation. Parliament election officials recorded 107 abstentions and invalidated 113 ballots for unspecified reasons. Yanayev needed a simple majority of 1,120 votes out of the 2,239 registered members of the parliament. The total number of deputies attending the session was lower than the number registered. At least three delegations from secessionist republics were boycotting and an unknown number of other were absent for various reasons. The parliament earlier this week approved nearly every constitutional amendment Gorbachev wanted to reorganize the government under direct presidential control. Some lawmakers said that by rejecting his nominee, the usually obedient parliament showed its deep dissatisfaction with Yanayev in the potentially powerful and visible new job. But Gorbachev, determined to win confirmation of the 53-year-old career Communist Party official, argued that he needed a man he could trust in the job and persuaded deputies to vote again. On the second secret ballot, deputies voted 1,230-563 for Yanayev, surpassing the 1,120 votes needed for a simple majority. The remaining ballots were not filled out or were declared invalid, but the exact numbers were unavailable. It was also unclear whether the same number of ballots in the first vote - 1,847 - were distributed in the second vote. If so, that would have left just 54 abstentions or invalid ballots in the second vote, down significantly from the 120 in the first vote. After the first vote, speakers had implored the deputies to vote during the second round and support Gorbachev. ``A political battle is going on and you can't get away from it - you must choose,'' said Marshall Sergei F. Akhromeyev, a presidential adviser and former armed forces chief of staff. Meanwhile Friday, the dramatic resignation during the parliament of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze continued to reverberate in the media. The State Committee for Television and Radio, known as Gostelradio, canceled two episodes of ``Vzglyad,'' one of the Soviet Union's most popular television programs, because it disapproves of its political coverage, the show's host said. Alexander Lyubimov said the shows were scheduled to include stories about Shevardnadze, including a frank interview in which he said he considered quitting as foreign minister to protest shootings by Soviet troops in his native Georgia. Shevardnadze resigned over another issue last week. Program officials saw the cancellation as a return tostate censorship clearly done for political reasons.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Killed, Husband Injured During Gang's Robbery Spree by Bike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Detective E. Nathan in 7th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: More than a dozen bicycle-riding gang members fatally stabbed a woman and injured her husband during a robbery spree, authorities said Friday. Ten people were robbed in as many minutes in the Thursday evening rampage in the Watts section, said homicide Detective Larry Kallestad. Police described the 15 young men taken into custody as gang members. Tomasa Rivas, 44, died from a stab wound to the chest when she and her husband were attacked while walking home with bags of groceries. Ms. Rivas was attacked when she ran toward her 52-year-old husband, Jesus Rivas, who had just been stabbed, Kallestad said. Rivas was in stable condition Friday after surgery at Martin Luther King Jr.-Drew Medical Center. The Rivases were the only stabbing victims, Kallestad said. Two victims received minor injuries struggling with their assailants but did not require hospitalization, he said. Eight of the young men arrested were released Friday after witnesses failed to identify them in a lineup, authorities said. Detective E. Nathan said seven others, four juveniles and three adults, were booked for investigation of murder and robbery. The names of those taken into custody were withheld, she said. Arraignments were expected Monday. ``We've released eight of the suspects but that doesn't mean that they're home free,'' Kallestad said. ``We're not sure we've got all of them.'' Kallestad said a police helicopter followed a group of bicyclists fleeing from the area of the last robbery. ``They all ran into one house and were taken into custody there.'' He said stolen purses and other evidence was recovered at the house.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Approves Opposition Newspaper, Media Get More Independence
DOC.TEXT: Albania's Communist government legalized the first opposition newspaper on Friday and announced greater independence for television and other news media, the state news agency ATA reported. In a dispatch monitored in Vienna, ATA said the Council of Ministers decided to allow the Democratic Party to publish a newspaper and to make directors of ATA and of official television and radio responsible to the state, indicating the Communist Party would have less direct control. An official journalist reached by telephone in the capital of Tirana said Communist-sponsored directors would probably keep their posts for the moment. The ministers also decided to set up a commission to draft a news media law for approval by Parliament after Feb. 10 elections, ATA said. ``Up to now there was no law regulating the media. I understand this move to mean more independence from the party,'' the journalist said, speaking on condition of anonymity. President Ramiz Alia has sped up political reform since student protests over dormitory conditions this month grew into demands for democracy in Albania, Europe's last holdout for hard-line Communism. The Communists, in power since 1944, still control nearly all spheres of public life, including the media. Gramoz Pashko, a co-founder of the recently legalized Democratic Party, said Friday's decision meant the planned newspaper Rilindja Demokratika, or Democratic Revival, would go to press ``in the next day or two.'' He said in a telephone interview that the Democrats held a rally Friday in the central city of Elbasan - their second rally outside Tirana - and estimated that 35,000 people attended. Pashko reported no police interference and no incidents. He said the government authorized use of state-owned presses at a fee to print the paper. A first edition of 100,000 is planned, to be distributed around Albania by students and other supporters for a one lek (10-cent) cover price, he added. Pashko said the paper would also be sold to Albanian communities in neighboring Yugoslavia and elsewhere abroad - ``We shall cover the costs and, by selling abroad, raise funds for the party.'' The price for the eight-page paper was three times that of the Communist Party daily Zeri i Popullit. An electoral law, adopted before the Democratic Party was legalized, forbids political parties to receive foreign funding, but Pashko said raising funds through newspaper sales was legal. Four decrees by the Council of Ministers on Friday were all signed by Premier Adil Carcani. One says newspapers would not be allowed to publish articles calling for overthrow of the constitutional order or other ``destabilizing acts,'' said an Albanian radio report monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. Pashko confirmed reports by the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug that the Communists organized counterrallies Friday in Tirana and other Albanian cities, but he said attendance was ``sparse ... and mainly old people were there.'' Speakers at the opposition rally asked popular support for the Democratic Party's demands that February elections be postponed for two or three months, to allow the Democrats more time to organize an effective campaign. Even with a newspaper, the opposition must rely mainly on word-of-mouth and rallies to propagate its cause in this small, isolated Balkan nation of 3.2 million, with its poor roads and communications. The government on Monday rejected the request for a postponement, saying urgently needed reforms and constitutional changes require that parliamentary elections as soon as possible. Alia on Wednesday acknowledged there ``have been mistakes'' in the 46 years of one-party rule. He pledged to reform the Communist Party and remove the Communists' guaranteed leading role in society from the constitution. He also promised reforms to shore up Albania's isolationist economy, now on the brink of collapse.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Optimistic About Soviet Investigation of Katyn Murders
DOC.TEXT: Soviet officials investigating the massacre of 15,000 Polish officers during World War II are conducting a ``thorough and comprehensive'' probe, a Polish prosecutor said Friday. Deputy Prosecutor General Stefan Sniezko said Soviet military prosecutors showed him 35 volumes of files relating to the 1940 Katyn massacre, including such details as schedules for trains that carried the prisoners. After 47 years of denials, the Soviet government in April admitted responsibility for the murders, which it had previously blamed on the Nazis. On Dec. 18, Polish prosecutors were allowed their first look at the documents, Sniezko said. A total of 4,254 Polish prisoners, including the cream of the Polish intelligentsia and 800 doctors, were executed and stacked in mass graves by the Soviet secret police in the Katyn forest, near the city of Smolensk. The bodies were found by German troops moving east through Russia in 1943. But until the current investigation, the whereabouts of an additional 10,000 Poles who were interned in camps at Starobielsk and Ostashkov, northwest of Moscow, had been a mystery. Sniezko said that the Soviet military prosecutors, who took over the case in October after the personal intervention of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hoped to chart the fate of each victim. Polish experts have been invited to attend an exhumation of bodies next year near Kharkhov in the southern Ukraine, Sniezko said. Referred to as the ``second Katyn,'' the site found in June is likely to contain bodies of prisoners from the nearby Starobielsk camp. Poles regard the murders as evidence of Stalin's drive to prevent the resurrection of an independent Polish state after Nazi Germany and the Soviets divided Poland between them in 1939.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officials Assure Jordan of Peaceful Intentions
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders assured Jordan on Friday that they intend to remain at peace with the neighboring kingdom. Tensions have risen with reports of military buildups on both sides of the border. Jordan, which has shown sympathy for neighboring Iraq, has reinforced its security forces along the cease-fire line with Israel as a precaution against an attack by the Jewish state, Jordanian military sources said Thursday. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, during a meeting with visiting U.S. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner, said Israel is carefully monitoring the events in Jordan but ``wants to live with it like good neighbors,'' Israel radio reported. ``The real interest of Jordan is to keep any country, any foreign element from entering Jordan. ... Jordanian officials have presented this as one of the reasons for the present increased level of defensive alert,'' said Israel's Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron. Shomron, in a speech in Tel Aviv on Friday, said Israel wants to prevent ``any alien element and of course the Iraqis'' from invading Jordan. Israel has repeatedly issued such warnings to Jordan, which it fears Iraq may use as a springboard for an attack on Israel. However, ``the Jordanians are wrong in assuming that we plan to invade Jordan, to harm it and to seize territory. We have no such intentions, and I'm also saying that reports that we are massing troops on the Jordanian border are simply not true,'' Shomron said.

DOC.HEAD: Mental Patient Who Refused Abortion Has Baby
DOC.TEXT: A mentally ill woman who refused to have a court-ordered abortion has given birth to a boy. Denise Lefebvre, who spent much of her pregnancy strapped to a hospital bed to protect staff from her violent outbursts, had the baby Wednesday, said her guardian, Kathleen Phillips. The 5-pound, 10-ounce infant, who wasn't expected until January, suffered no obvious ill effects from Lefebvre's medication for severe manic depression, Phillips said. ``It's a sad and happy occasion,'' said Phillips, who became Lefebvre's guardian when she was declared mentally incompetent in September. ``We have a baby, but who knows what will happen to the baby. Denise is very ill.'' Who will be the child's guardian has yet to be decided, but Phillips said the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services likely will take custody of the boy. The birth at Broward General Medical Center will allow Lefebvre to resume powerful drugs she was taking before she stopped last spring for fear it would hurt her unborn child. She quickly slipped into a deep psychotic state, prompting doctors at Broward General to seek a court-ordered abortion they said was necessary to save her life. Lefebvre insisted on keeping her baby. But without her medication, Lefebvre was attacking and accosting her doctors, urinating and defecating on herself and refusing to sleep or eat. In September, after the case bounced through south Florida's courts, a judge declared Lefebvre mentally incompetent and appointed Phillips to act on her behalf. Phillips and the doctors agreed to help Lefebvre have her baby. Lefebvre's ordeal drew the attention of pro-choice and anti-abortion groups, which united in support of her decision to keep the baby. Phillips said Lefebvre is reacting to her baby the way any mother might. ``She's very happy,'' Phillips said. ``I don't think she realizes what will happen to the baby.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Stays Out of MCA Fight
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top four grafs new with full court refuses to intervene; picks up 3rd graf: ``Go-Video sought,'' now 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Friday refused to block the $7.4 billion purchase of movie-making MCA Inc. by Japan's largest electronics company. Justice Antonin Scalia, acting without any written opinion, first rejected an emergency request by Go-Video Inc. to block consummation of the deal set for Saturday. Go-Video then turned to Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who referred the matter to his colleagues. The court announced in the early evening that all nine justices, again acting without a written opinion, had refused to act. Go-Video sought a postponement until a formal antitrust challenge could be mounted. A federal judge in Arizona and the San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals previously had turned down Go-Video's request. It will be the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. company, providing giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. the entertainment ``software'' - programs of all kinds - it needed to complement its electronics ``hardware.'' The combination mirrors one struck by Sony Corp., which bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $5 billion a year ago. Matsushita is familiar to American consumers through brand names such as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. MCA, which runs Universal Studios, has grown into a colossus of films (``E.T. the Extra-Terrestial,'' ``Jaws,'' ``Back to the Future''), records (Reba McEntire, Elton John, Guns N' Roses) and television (``Murder, She Wrote,'' ``Major Dad''). It also owns Florida and California theme parks. In seeking to block the purchase, Go-Video contended that Matsushita's takeover would lessen competition in the ``software'' industry. In rejecting that argument last week, U.S. District Judge Robert Broomfield in Phoenix said, ``I'm simply not persuaded that the proposed merger is necessarily anti-competitive.'' The case is Go-Video vs. Matsushita Electric, A-498.

DOC.HEAD: Two Saved after Nine Hours in Sunken Barge off Finland
LaserPhotos HAG1,HLE7
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers drilled a hole in the hull of a capsized barge off Finland and saved two crew, but officials said Friday that although divers continued to search, eight more missing men were thought dead. Olli Lommi, 36, first mate, and Jouko Kosonen, 41, chief engineer, were rescued late Thursday after being trapped for nine hours in an air pocket in the engine room of the upturned Finnish vessel Finn-Baltic. Rescuers working in a snowstorm and heavy winds had redoubled their efforts after hearing tapping inside the barge. The 550-foot, 15,000-ton barge, including a motorized ``pusher'' section, capsized in rough weather off the southwestern port of Hanko at about 1 p.m. on Thursday while carrying iron ore between Finnish ports. News reports said it overturned in 10 seconds because the barge took on water and the cargo shifted. Strong winds and rain forced rescuers to stop searching late Thursday but operations resumed after weather conditions improved Friday morning. The barge was reported entirely submerged at first, but officials said it later drifted into shallower water and part of it jutted a dozen feet or more above the surface, allowing rescuers to walk on the hull. ``We don't believe anyone else is alive in the pusher-barge, but we have a dozen or so divers trying to get into the vessel from the underneath,'' Nils Radstedt, deputy chief of the Hanko Coast Guard, said. The pusher-barge had nine Finnish crewmen and a pilot on board. Rescue officials declined to speculate on why the vessel sailed in winds of up to 62 mph. ``We just don't know and we will leave that upto the special investigation committee. All we know is that it happened very quickly and there was no warning,'' Radstedt said in a telephone interview. Jan-Eric Dahlberg, the security chief of FG Shipping, the barge owner, said, ``The two survivors said they had sailed in worse conditions before. This vessel was built to sail in rough seas.'' Radstedt said heat from the pusher's engine helped keep Lommi and Kosonen alive while a snow storm raged outside. ``They were in good health when taken to the Hanko Medical Center.'' ``The (rescued) men said they think there are eight others trapped in the ship. But there is no hope that they are still alive,'' Radstedt said. In a separate incident, the German freighter Transgermania which hit a rock Thursday was being towed into Turku on Finland's west coast. Rescue officials said the Finnish-built roll-on roll-off vessel had a cargo of dangerous chemicals but danger had passed that it would sink. None of Transgermania's 22 German crew were in danger, said Jari Simi of the Turku Maritime Rescue Coordination Center. ``There are still 12 crew on the ship and 15 firemen pumping water out. Three tugs are pulling the vessel and there is no danger now,'' Simi said. Earlier, 10 crewmen were evacuated from the sinking ship which had worked itself free off the rock and listed dangerously. The ship's pumps, main engine and anchor chain broke in the storm.

DOC.HEAD: Militant Group Says Talks Under Way With ANC on United Front
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to ADD government announcement it will help group repatriate exiles. Picks up 5th graf, ANC spokeswoman . .. ADDS 6 grafs with details.
DOC.TEXT: The militant Pan Africanist Congress said Friday it has been holding talks with Nelson Mandela's African National Congress about joining forces in a united front against apartheid. In another development, Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee announced that the government will help an anti-apartheid group with the repatriation of thousands of political exiles expected to return soon. The return of exiles has been a key demand by the ANC and other major opposition groups. If exiles begin returning in large numbers, it will help improve the climate for black-white negotiations between the government and opposition groups. Pan Africanist President Clarence Makwetu said in a New Year's message Friday, ``1991 will be characterized by the creation of a united front or patriotic front of the principal liberation movements. ``In this regard, it pleases us to announce that preparatory discussions between the PAC and the ANC for the creation of a united or patriotic front are proceeding with great promise.'' . Leaders of both organizations have said black opposition groups should confront the white-led government together, but they have many disagreements. ANC spokeswoman Gill Marcus said as far as she knew there have been ``very, very preliminary'' discussions. She added, ``Unity isn't something simply declared on a piece of paper or achieved in talks. It must be forged on the ground, in action. ... You have to have certain common basic principles.'' Such unity could be difficult to achieve for the ANC, the Pan Africanist Congress, and Inkatha Freedom Party, the largest anti-apartheid groups. They are split by deep rivalries. The Pan Africanist Congress was formed in 1960 by militants who broke away from the more moderate ANC. It refuses to recognize the white-led government and has rejected an invitation to join current talks involving the ANC and government. The negotiations are intended to open the way for full-scale talks on giving majority blacks a say in the country's political system. Both the Pan Africanist Congress and ANC support international sanctions to pressure the government to end apartheid, the official system of racial separation. But the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party opposes sanctions. In addition, supporters of the ANC and Inkatha Freedom Party have waged virtual warfare for five years in Natal province. The fighting spilled over to the townships around Johannesburg in August. More than 3,000 people have died this year in the unrest. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid. But they differ on tactics for fighting it and on their vision of a future South Africa. Coetsee announced on Thursday that the government has appointed two senior officials to work with the National Coordinating Committee for the Repatriation of South African Exiles. The repatriation committee, headed by anti-apartheid activist Rev. Frank Chikane, has urged the government to allow the United Nations to play a role in the process. But Coetsee's statement did not address the issue of U.N. involvement. The ministry will help identify problems related to exiles' return and bring them to the attention of appropriate officials, the statement said. The government agreed in August to allow the return of tens of thousands of exiles. But the process has bogged down as the government and the ANC have tried to resolve a variety of issues. The ANC has demanded blanket amnesty for exiles. But the government says exiles who fled prosecution for specific crimes must apply for amnesty and will have their cases judged individually. The exact number of exiles is unknown. The ANC says about 20,000 of its members are in exile.

DOC.HEAD: Snowstorms Wallop Northeast, Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Winter storms Friday engulfed the nation's Northwest and Northeast and freezing rain extended into central New Mexico. Snow fell across much of New England at midday. Caribou, Maine, chilled to 17 below zero to tie a low temperature record for the date set in 1980. Snow also fell in northwest New York state and southern New Jersey. In Pennsylvania, 10 to 16 inches fell overnight in Somerset, Cambria, Blair, Bedford, Fulton and Franklin counties. In the Pacific Northwest, winter storm warnings were posted over eastern Washington state, Oregon's Willamette Valley and Columbia Gorge, and northern and central Idaho. High winds in the Seattle area whipped the Puget Sound into a froth. Blizzard warnings were posted for northwest and central Montana and winter storm warnings were issued for the northwest and western mountains of Wyoming. In North Dakota, temperatures ranged from around zero in the extreme southwest to about 20 below northwest part of the state. Winds of 25 to 35 mph brought the wind chill index down to 35 below to 60 below. Snow fell in the afternoon over upper Michigan, northern Wisconsin, northern Minnesota, northwest Iowa, much of North and South Dakota, Nebraska, Montana and Idaho. One to 3 inches of fresh snow fell over Albuquerque, Santa Fe, Los Alamos and Gallup, N.M. Other parts of the state got freezing rain. In contrast, Meridian, Miss., reached 75 degrees to tie its high record for the date set in 1984. Snowfall during the six-hour period ending at 1 p.m. EST included 3 inches at Hartford, Conn., Portland, Maine, and Portsmouth, N.H., 2 inches at Bridgeport, Conn., Providence, R.I., and Walla Walla, Wash., and 1 inch at Utica, N.Y. The morning low for the nation was 24 below zero at Cutbank, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 24 below zero at Cutbank to 85 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Emergency Room Doctor Arrested For Obstructing Police Officer
DOC.TEXT: The only emergency room doctor on duty at a hospital was arrested because he didn't respond quickly enough to a police request to draw blood from a suspected drunken driver, officials said. Clarkson Hospital officials said Thursday the emergency room was left unattended for about an hour when Dr. Bruce Harvey was arrested for obstructing an officer. Dennis Earl, the hospital's associate administrator, said Harvey wanted to attend to patients, including one with heart problems, before he complied with the police request Tuesday night to draw blood for a blood alcohol test. The police officer, Michael Thomas, wanted him to draw the blood immediately. State law allows police to make such requests of hospitals. ``I told him that the more time that was wasted could seriously affect the results of the test,'' Thomas said. Thomas said the doctor was handcuffed, taken downtown for booking and returned to the hospital after about 45 minutes. Earl said Harvey was not allowed to telephone for a replacement doctor.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Recluse Dies In Fire; Leaves $1 Million To Charity
DOC.TEXT: A reclusive millionaire killed when fire gutted his cluttered home left more than $1 million to charity, his attorney said. Nathan Rounds, 76, had no close relatives, showed little interest in money or taxes and rarely went anywhere in the past decade, said attorney Joseph T. Thompson. ``He wasn't unpleasant,'' Thompson said. ``He just liked to keep to himself and wasn't a sociable person. He was acquainted with Howard Hughes at one time and he was a recluse.'' Thompson said his client spent his last years secluded like Hughes and had attended the 1947 flight of the multimillionaire's ``Spruce Goose'' flying boat. The attorney said Rounds left an estate worth more than $1 million and directed in his will that the money be donated to charity. The will does not specify how the money should be spent. Rounds died early Wednesday of apparent smoke inhalation after he fell while trying to escape a fire that gutted his $560,000 home in Sherman Oaks, said police Detective Mark Rooney. ``To say the house was cluttered does not come close to describing it,'' Rooney said. ``It was like an obstacle course without a path.'' There was no indication of foul play, Rooney said. Several small electric heaters placed all over the house may have caused the fire, Rooney said. An autopsy was scheduled Friday but preliminary results were not available from the Los Angeles County coroner's office. Rounds inherited his fortune from parents who found him on a church step and adopted him. He showed little interest in the trust fund his parents left after they died, Thompson said. ``He didn't try to invest to make more money and didn't file his income taxes on time,'' Thompson said. ``I never knew him to be employed. He didn't need to be. I heard he drove race cars as a young man.'' Thompson said he met Rounds two or three times a year to deliver stock dividend checks, but was never invited inside the hilltop home. Instead, the two always met in his client's garage, he said. ```He wasn't incompetent and certainly wasn't mentally impaired,'' Thompson said. ``He didn't want to be bothered. He didn't want to do things and just generally didn't care.''

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Cruzan's Death Called a `Gift of Freedom' at Her Funeral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with color, quotes. No pick up
DOC.BYLINE: LaserPhoto JOP1, LaserColor JOP101 ^By SCOTT CHARTON
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan's family gave her ``the gift of freedom'' by disconnecting her feeding tube and allowing her to die after nearly eight years in a vegetative state, her father said Friday at her funeral. ``It was time,'' Joe Cruzan told about 200 people gathered at a chapel. ``We all feel good that Nancy is free at last.'' Ms. Cruzan, 33, died Wednesday at Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon, 12 days after her family won court permission to disconnect the feeding tube that kept her alive. ``She did not die in vain,'' her father said. The family's legal efforts to end her life led to a landmark Supreme Court decision June 25 that patients like Ms. Cruzan could be allowed to die if there was ``clear and convincing'' evidence that was their wish. Ms. Cruzan had been in a persistent vegetative state after suffering severe brain damage in a 1983 car accident. Her parents and former co-workers said it was her desire to die rather than live in such a state. Ms. Cruzan's father said requests for living wills, which allow adults to decide whether they want to be kept alive by artificial means, increased 500-fold since her case got national attention. ``I believe that these facts alone speak to the legacy that Nancy left us,'' he said. Ms. Cruzan was buried in Carterville, just north of her southwest Missouri hometown of Joplin. Her blue metal casket, adorned with drawings of flying sea gulls, remained closed during the 45-minute service. Two dozen floral arrangements surrounded the casket, including a single red rose from her grandparents. Thirteen photographs of Ms. Cruzan were displayed above the casket, including one of her as an infant bundled for winter play, as a little girl wrestling with a too-tall bicycle and as a young, dark-haired woman dressed in red with a beaming smile. ``Nancy seemed to be born with laughter in her spirit,'' said the Rev. Bob Clyde, the Cruzans' minister. Tapes of Ms. Cruzan's favorite songs were played in the chapel, including ``The Rose'' by Bette Midler and ``Coming Home'' by Bob Seger. Demonstrators picketed and camped outside the hospital while Ms. Cruzan was dying and unsuccessfully pleaded with Missouri and federal courts to order her feeding tube reconnected. ``To the ones who maybe didn't understand or didn't agree, we did what we felt we had to do,'' Cruzan told reporters. ``We appreciate their prayers.'' After a crush of mourners left Ms. Cruzan's grave, her father returned, stood quietly for a moment, then placed a single pink flower on the casket before wiping his eyes. ``Nancy's free at last ... thank God,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice to Challenge Hawaii Combination
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Friday it had filed a civil antitrust suit aimed at blocking the planned merger of two banks in Hawaii. The banks are First Interstate and First Hawaiian. First Hawaiian planned to buy all the shares of First Interstate on Monday for $140 million. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Honolulu, charged that the consolidation would have excessive market power in business banking services in Hawaii to an extent forbidden by the Clayton Act. The department said First Interstate is the fourth largest bank in Hawaii with $771 million in deposits, or 5.6 percent of the Hawaii total, while First Hawaiian is the second largest, with deposits of $5 billion or about 32 percent of the total. James F. Rill, assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, said in a statement: ``This acquisition will hurt the many small to medium-sized businesses in Hawaii. The acquisition will eliminate one of only a few banks serving those customers and will likely result in them paying higher prices for services.'' Walter Dods, president of First Hawaiian, said in Honolulu the department had nine months to make its objections known, but waited until the last possible day to go to court. Asked if the merger was an antitrust violation, he said it was not. ``We have very strong opinions and our lawyers agree and that's why the Federal Reserve Board approved the deal.'' He said it was ``highly likely'' the bank would contest the department's suit.

DOC.HEAD: Voice of Cinderella Sues Over Videocasettes
DOC.TEXT: The singer who provided the voice of Cinderella in the animated film has filed a $20 million lawsuit claiming that Disney violated her contract by producing videocassettes of the classic. Ilene Woods Shaughnessy, who in 1948 was paid $2,500, said in the suit that her contract forbids Disney from making copies of the movie for sale to the public. ``In 1988, defendant Disney commenced production and marketing for sale to the public videocassette versions of `Cinderella,' all of which has been done without plaintiff's consent,'' the suit said. Steve Feldstein, a spokesman for the home video division of Disney, said the company had not seen the suit and had no comment. Shaughnessy, who lives in Woodland Hills, was 22 when she provided the voice of Cinderella, said Dave Smith, archivist for Walt Disney Productions. Walt Disney liked her clear delivery when he heard her sing for the movie's composers, according to company records kept by Smith. She performed such songs as ``So This is Love'' and ``A Dream is a Wish Your Heart Makes'' for the movie, he said. Shaughnessy also sang on radio programs, including ``The Bing Crosby Show'' and ``The Paul Whiteman Show,'' Smith said. The suit is similar to at least two others brought against Disney. Singer Peggy Lee won a summary judgment in April against Disney in a suit in which she claimed the company needed her approval before releasing the videocassette version of ``Lady and the Tramp.'' Lee provided voices and co-wrote songs for the 1955 animated film. Singer Mary Costa, the voice of the princess in the 1959 movie ``Sleeping Beauty,'' filed a suit in May 1989 seeking royalties related to videocassette sales. Shaughnessy asks for $10 million in damages for breach of contract and at least $10 million more for her contribution to the success of the videocassette. Feldstein said he didn't know how many videocassettes of the movie have been sold.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Blows Doors Off Apartments, Starts Fire
