DOC.TEXT: An explosion Friday that may have been triggered by work on a gas line blew the doors off apartments on the top floor of a 14-story housing project and started a fire, officials said. The fire in Brooklyn was brought under control in about 1{ hours, said fire department spokesman Adam Krause. ``On the 14th floor all the doors were blown off and four apartments were demolished,'' said police spokesman Fred Weiner. ``Damage was also done to the 12th and 13th floors.'' The top floor of the Albany Housing Project in the Crown Heights section collapsed and flames shot out windows at the height of the blaze. Nine adults and three children were seriously injured and two firefighters were treated at the scene, Weiner said. Under investigation was the possibility that the fire was triggered by a gas explosion, Krause said. ``There was some contracting work being done on a gas line in apartment 14J,'' said Robert Murphy, a spokesman for Brooklyn Union Gas. The utility supplies gas for heating and cooking to the building, but the Housing Authority is responsible for maintaining lines. One person was admitted to the Cornell Medical Center Burn Unit and the other injured were treated at local hospitals.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Devalues Currency in Economy Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to RECAST and RESTORE dropped language on devaluation. Picks up 6th graf, `Markovic said...'
DOC.TEXT: The government announced a deep devaluation of the currency on Friday as part of a package of economic reforms that it urged Parliament to pass to keep the fractious federation from falling apart. Premier Ante Markovic announced the measures in an address to both chambers of the federal parliament. He said Yugoslavia's survival depended on the successful redirection of the nation's economy along free-market lines. ``We are at a crucial juncture. Shall we permit this country to be faced with inevitable violence or will we ensure a peaceful, legal and democratic solution to the crisis by continuing our reforms?'' he asked. Markovic asked for a wage freeze in most sectors to help keep inflation down, and for ceilings on public spending by the federation and Yugoslavia's six republics. Under the devaluation, the dinar's value against the German mark would fall 22 percent, from seven dinars to the mark to nine. The dollar would be worth 13.5 dinars after the devaluation. Markovic said the International Monetary Fund had approved his program and IMF officials had assured him they stood ready to approve a $1 billion standby agreement for Yugoslavia in January. Yugoslavia could lose access to Western credit if it doesn't stick to his program, he said. Since coming to power almost two years ago, Markovic has slowed inflation, which hit 2,500 percent in 1989, and introduced major pro-capitalist reforms. Inflation has crept up again to an estimated 120 percent annual rate, but Markovic predicted it would drop to 40 percent in 1991. The economy was hit hard by loss of $1.3 billion in contracts due to the Persian Gulf crisis, and $1.7 billion from a long drought, Markovic said. But Yugoslavia succeeded this year in repaying $3.8 billion of its hard currency-denominated foreign debt, which now stands at $16.5 billion. The governments of Yugoslavia's six republics - whose members range from former Communists to free-market conservatives - have hurt the country's economy by expanding public spending and granting pay raises in state-run companies, Markovic said. Each republic has wide control over its own economic and financial policies under Yugoslavia's federal system, and the central government often cannot intervene. Center-right or nationalist parties triumphed in elections this year in four republics. Communists remained in power in Serbia and Montenegro. Slovenia and Croatia want the patchwork federation of often hostile ethnic groups transformed into a loose association of independent states. Serbia favors keeping power centralized in Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital. Serbia imposed 50 percent taxes on goods from Slovenia and Croatia this year, torpedoing Markovic's plans to keep a unified internal Yugoslav market. The Serbian government opposes his plans for privatization and other market reforms and has launched a media campaign demanding the premier resign. The eight-member federal presidency met with all six state presidents Thursday and Friday for negotiations aimed at concerting the country's future.

DOC.HEAD: Government Signs Peace Treaty With Rebel Band
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with accord signed; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A small band of leftist rebels signed a peace treaty with the government Friday and pledged to throw its weapons into the Caribbean Sea. The agreement represents another important step in the government's effort to disarm a variety of guerrilla groups behind a three-decade-old insurgency. The peace accord is the second to be signed with Colombian guerrillas this year. The new agreement, which ended eight years of fighting, was signed by government officials and rebels of the Revolutionary Workers' Party, know by its Spanish acronym, PRT, presidential press spokeswoman Amparo Trujillo told The Associated Press. The document was signed in the northern Colombian town of Don Gabriel, where PRT guerrillas assembled after declaring a cease-fire and entering peace talks with the government on Oct. 23. Under the accord, the Revolutionary Workers' estimated 100 rebels will throw their weapons into the Caribbean and join the political process within a month, officials said. A more extensive accord with additional details on the guerrillas' demobilization will be signed in January, Trujillo said. During the past eight years, the Revolutionary Workers have fought the army and police in the northern coastal province of Sucre. In March, the much larger M-19 rebel group signed a treaty with the government in exchange for amnesty. The M-19's success in transforming itself into an influential political party has been seen as key in convincing other rebel groups to give up armed struggle. Two other groups are reported near an agreement with government, although the country's major guerrilla movement has kept on fighting. Two other guerrilla outfits, the Maoist-inspired Peoples' Liberation Army and Quintin Lame, a small but fierce band of indigenous rebels, are expected to sign treaties within weeks. However, Colombia's oldest and biggest rebel group, the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia, is still fighting the army in the countryside. About 160 troops and guerrillas have died this month in fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Infant Exhumed After Mother Confesses To Killing Three
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the body of an infant exhumed after her mother confessed to killing her in 1983 and later suffocating two other children. From Michigan, Diane L. Spencer wrote to Pennsylvania authorities to protest the exhumation of her daughter, Joyce A. Donochick, who died at age 6 weeks. Parts of the letter were read aloud in court Thursday, but Clearfield County Judge John Reilly Jr. ruled Joyce's body should be examined by forensic pathologists. Spencer is held in the Allegan County Jail in Michigan, where she is charged with first-degree murder in the September death of her 6-month-old son, Aaron A. Spencer. Another of her children, Autumn Dawn Spencer, died in 1987 at 17 days old. Dan Miller, police chief in Wayland, said Ms. Spencer confessed to suffocating all three children. Authorities had believed they died of sudden infant death syndrome. Clearfield County Coroner R. Joel Heath said Joyce's body would be exhumed within two weeks. Pennsylvania authorities have not filed charges in the deaths of the two girls.

DOC.HEAD: East Gets First Snow of the Winter; Northwest Pounded Again
LaserPhoto PX2; LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Utilities reported ...' to UPDATE with latest power outage estimate in Washington state.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Storm-Drought
DOC.TEXT: A double-barreled blast of winter Friday hit the Pacific Northwest and the East, knocking out power to thousands, disrupting flights, delaying or detouring commuters and bringing more worries to farmers. Hundreds of fender-benders - and numerous traffic accidents - were reported in the East as motorists adjusted to snow for the first time this winter. ``The first storm is always a little confusing. It takes everyone a little bit of time to get acclimated,'' observed William F. Palmer, operations manager of the airport in Windsor Locks, Conn. The storm led to one person's death in New York City when smoke filled a subway tunnel after melting snow shorted out electrical cables. About 150 subway passengers were injured when smoke spread through the East River tunnel connecting Manhattan and Brooklyn. At least three deaths in Connecticut were described by authorities Friday as weather-related. Two men over age 60 suffered fatal heart attacks while shoveling snow, and a 17-year-old died when the car he was traveling in slid off the road and overturned. In Ohio, a 7-year-old Springfield boy died Friday when a mound of snow fell on him as he played with a friend. In Washington state, a 47-year-old Vashon Island woman was killed when a tree fell on the car she was in. Cold and stormy weather have been blamed for about 90 deaths nationwide since Dec. 18. Seven inches of wet snow fell in New York City's Central Park just a few days after temperatures in the 60s made the record books. In the Northwest, the brunt of the storm that arrived late Thursday for the most part bypassed Seattle and other major cities in western Washington. But chilling winds whipped the region from the Canadian border south to Puget Sound. Utilities reported about 94,000 customers in Washington state were without power by late Friday after winds knocked trees and branches onto power lines. In California, temperatures plunging into the teens and 20s have wiped out 80 percent of the navel orange crop for a loss of nearly $288 million in farming revenues, the state Department of Food and Agriculture reported. Navel oranges make up about half of the state's total orange crop. ``People in the industry say they've never seen anything like this,'' said Tom McNair, agricultural statistician for the California Agricultural Statistics Service. ``In future years, freezes will be compared to this one. They will say, `It's not as bad as 1990.''' And things could get worse before they get better: Another crop-killing freeze was expected overnight. In New Mexico, snow covered Albuquerque, Santa Fe, Los Alamos and Gallup. The National Weather Service said 3 inches of snow fell Friday in Albuquerque's far Northeast Heights, and 1 to 2 inches at the airport. In the East, New York City's three regional airports reported delays of 45 minutes to an hour. And New York's Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Commuter Railroad reported scattered weather-related train delays and cancellations. Virtually all of Pennsylvania was blanketed with snow overnight. The south-central mountain counties got 10 to 16 inches. In Wilson borough, near Allentown, 30 families were forced to evacuate their homes after a snowplow ruptured a gas line. They were allowed to return after the minor leak was repaired. Martinsburg, W.Va., was buried under at least 10 inches of snow and freezing rain turned West Virginia's highways into skating rinks, authorities said. ``We don't have any roads shut down per se. But they're bad, real bad,'' Berkeley County emergency services dispatcher Robin Taylor said. ``They're just full of snow.'' ``The cars are all over the place. They're a mess.'' On Friday, rescuers in Hedgesville, W.Va., again searched for two boys missing since their car plunged off a bridge into a creek Wednesday. Four family members died in the accident. Dense fog in much of Indiana created dangerous driving conditions for motorists Friday, a day after up to 10 inches of snow fell in parts of the state. Some welcomed the wintry conditions. In particular, ski resort operators found the snow to be a belated Christmas gift. At Vernon Valley-Great Gorge ski area in northwestern New Jersey, four extra staffers were called in to sell tickets, said Lori Vovchansky, who works the courtesy desk there. ``Business is very busy today,'' she said. ``We've had a lot of calls this morning. The switchboard is going off the wall.''

DOC.HEAD: Old Ski-Nose Back From Another Tour for the Troops
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope, who only seems to have been visiting the troops at Christmas since the Civil War, on Friday night pronounced morale of American forces in Saudi Arabia ``just sensational.'' The 87-year-old entertainer told reporters on his return from Saudi Arabia: ``My opening line in the last week has been, `Are you ready?' ``And man, they all stood up with a fist and said, `We're ready.''' Hope was asked how morale of today's forces compared with those he entertained in the Vietnam war. ``They know more what they're doing,'' he replied. Hope's Christmas appearances, in the past noted for scantily clad young women and off-color jokes, were drastically toned down this year for fear of offending the strict Saudi hosts. Except for his wife, Dolores, women on the tour were based in Bahrain and appeared only on U.S. ships in the Persian Gulf. Reporters were not permitted to attend the shows. Appearances from camps in Saudi Arabia and from the ships will be spliced together in a single television special next month. Hope's first overseas tour was in World War II, almost 50 years ago, and he recalled servicemen in 1983 telling him their grandfathers had seen him. He added, ``So if anybody tells you I was in the Civil War, I'm denying that.'' Hope has said recent trips, such as his 1989 Christmas appearances in Europe, were his last. He repeated that again Friday night: ``Honest, this is my last trip.''

An ultra-Orthodox rabbi considered to be a political kingmaker has enraged religious and secular Israelis by claiming the Holocaust was God's punishment for sins such as violating the Jewish Sabbath and eating pork. ``Not for a long time has any single remark caused such an emotional reaction,'' said Razi Barkai, host of a radio talk show that was flooded with hundreds of calls Thursday over the remarks of Rabbi Eliezer Schach. Barkai said calls ran about 3-2 against the 97-year-old rabbi, who also predicted another disaster may befall Jews for violating traditional religious tenets. ``The last time he brought destruction, it was the Holocaust ... Because of the sins, the Almighty may bring another Holocaust upon us, and it may already be tomorrow,'' Schach told Jewish seminary students earlier this week. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Navel orange prices could double nationwide because of the deep freeze that devastated much of California's citrus crop, an industry official says. Farmers, meanwhile, braced for a second arctic blast that threatened to destroy surviving crops and the trees themselves. The navel orange crop in the San Joaquin Valley, the state's main growing region, was virtually wiped out in the siege of freezing temperatures that started Dec. 21. A number of vegetable crops were also damaged, including artichokes, avocados, broccoli, cauliflower and celery. And the cold affected the state's flower crop, forcing people working on the Tournament of Roses parade in Pasadena to use substitute decorations. ``Prices could double because of the severe damage,'' said Claire Peters, spokeswoman for Sunkist Growers Inc., a marketing cooperative of about 6,000 California and Arizona growers. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The ink was barely dry on the first official 1990 census results when the numbers came under attack from state and local officials fearful of losing political clout and federal dollars. ``I think this thing was destined to fail from day one,'' said Mayor Jimmy Kemp of Meridian, Miss., a longtime critic of how the headcount was run. He was far from the only mayor to complain that the census overlooks many of the nation's poor living in big cities. The census numbers determine how many representatives each state sends to Congress and how many federal aid dollars states and localities receive. New Orleans Mayor Sidney Barthelemy, president of the National League of Cities, said the numbers seemed ``to confirm the fears of many city officials that significant numbers of people in their communities were uncounted.'' Michael Darby, undersecretary of commerce for economic affairs, said Thursday he was confident the count was ``full, fair and accurate.'' He said an analysis due next summer is designed to check the accuracy. ---= OLYMPIA, Wash. (AP) - Subscribers to a nationwide computer network contend the owners are taking a byte out of the First Amendment by censoring the network's electronic bulletin board messages. But officials for the Prodigy network, which provides consumer and information services to several hundred thousand subscribers, maintain they have the same right as newspaper and broadcast executives to ``set boundaries'' on the exercise of free expression. An electronic communications law expert agreed, saying the challenge for Prodigy is enforcing standards tough enough to avoid lawsuits sparked by bulletin board content. ``They should be able to forbid ... whatever they forbade in their subscriber agreement,'' Dallas attorney Benjamin Wright said Thursday.

For release Monday PMs, Dec. 31, and thereafter
With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: It is nice to be 82 and still a working journalist. But Alistair Cooke, who is both, reports one problem when young reporters arrive to interview him: ``I am at the stage where I ask, `Does the name Adolf Hitler mean anything to you?''' Despite this gentle reminder that those who forget history are doomed to see it repeated on cable, Cooke has prevailed in broadcasting and will take due note of it early in the new year - on Jan. 13, to be precise. He'll celebrate his 20th anniversary then as host of PBS' ``Masterpiece Theatre,'' commencing a nine-week retrospective of some of its better-known dramatic bundles from Britain. But of course they include ``Upstairs, Downstairs,'' ``I, Claudius,'' and ``The Jewel in the Crown.'' If that's not enough, PBS will offer a Jan. 24 parody of the series, ``Masterpiece Tonight,'' concocted by Gerard Alessandrini, whose ``Forbidden Broadway'' here regularly applies the needle to Broadway musicals. A transplanted Englishman who gives urbane a good name, Cooke has been the only host of ``Masterpiece Theatre'' since it began on Jan. 10, 1971 with ``The First Churchills'' - one of his least-favorite shows, incidentally. An elegant man, he favors blue blazers, gray slacks, and the graceful turn of phrase. Also jazz piano. Born in Manchester, and a U.S. citizen since 1941, he first came here as a student in 1932. He returned as a man of print and broadcast who since 1938 has tried to explain America to the British, no mean feat. In 1970, he embarked upon an even more difficult feat - explaining America to the Americans - in his acclaimed ``America'' series, a BBC co-production that NBC aired in prime time in 1972-73. The show won four Emmies. But it also almost prevented him from signing up for ``Masterpiece Theatre.'' He was in Boston, filming the third ``America'' episode, when accosted by a young British producer, Christopher Sarson. The ``Masterpiece'' idea - hosting a weekly series of British dramas adapted from famous novels - was explained. Cooke begged off, saying he'd be tied up on ``America'' for two years and constantly travelling. But Sarson ``was a deadpan scoundrel - and terrifically persuasive,'' he said. A veteran America-watcher whose dossier of pals and influences includes H.L. Mencken, Cooke will celebrate another milestone in March. That will be his 45th anniversary of commenting on his adopted country's wild and sometimes disturbing ways in ``Letter From America,'' a 14-minute weekly report he delivers on radio for the BBC. Heard via short-wave in 52 countries, including this one, he likens what he calls ``my talks'' to ``a diary, in a way, written for a friend.'' He comments on whatever strikes his fancy, sad or funny, minute or of great import and consequence (he does admit, gently laughing, that he has yet to give the once-over to Madonna and her amazing mondo video). It's his proud semiboast that in all the years of ``Letter'' he hasn't missed a week, although ``we came damn close a few months ago'' when he had to go to a hospital here for a prostate operation. Arrangements were made for him to tape that week's show in the hospital's boardroom. They rolled him there in a wheelchair, accompanied by two public relations officials, ``both stunning,'' from the hospital. He recalls telling them, ``What a pity we didn't have a photographer with us. It's the first time in 44 years that I've broadcast with a catheter bag.'' As befits a man of his years and travels, he occasionally is asked to compare the America of, say, 1940, with the America of today. Given the chance to go cosmic, he instead offers a refreshing, unexpected answer. ``I couldn't do it,'' he says. ``The standard thing is to talk about the loss of innocence. Every generation thinks it was innocent when it was young. It wasn't innocent. It was young.'' He smiles when asked when, if ever, he'll sign off the air and retire. ``Oh, it may happen tomorrow. I live from day to day, and it's not for me to decide that. But I don't have any intention of doing that. I think when you retire, you keel over.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... SHOULD AULD ACQUAINTANCE BE FORGOT, IT'S FOR A DARN GOOD REASON: The usual New Year's shows are loose on the networks starting at 11:30 p.m. EST tonight. CBS has ``Happy New Year America, 1991,'' hosted by Melissa Manchester and featuring Terry Bradshaw in Times Square. That's where NBC's Jane Pauley also will be as part of a live ``Tonight'' guest-hosted by Jay Leno. Yet another star, Dick Clark, is checking in from Times Square for ``Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve '91.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, Dec 31

DOC.HEAD: With PM-AP Arts: Depp
Friends, Family and Lots of Caffeine
DOC.TEXT: --- EDITOR'S NOTE: One of the most popular working actresses today is a 19-year-old named after a Minnesota town: Wynona Ryder. She has appeared in three movies this year: ``Edward Scissorhands,'' ``Mermaids'' and ``Welcome Home, Roxie Carmichael.'' She is engaged to actor Johnny Depp, her co-star in ``Edwawrd Scissorhands.'' ---

Winona Ryder laughed, as she started to drink a well-earned cup of coffee. ``It's all kind of meshed together but it's all very clear,'' she says, sounding a lot like her godfather, Timothy Leary. The world's most exhausted 19-year-old makes herself comfortable on the couch of her hotel suite, sitting Indian style and letting her hands hang over her legs.Ryder's face is small, almost elfin, with pale skin, pouty lips and eyes that stand out like dark brown dots. Few people can look back on a year and say they starred in three films and got engaged to actor Johnny Depp. Friends, family and lots of caffeine have been the secrets, helping her through a time highlighted by the movies she made (``Mermaids'' and ``Edward Scissorhands''), one she didn't make (``The Godfather, Part III)'' and a tattoo on Depp's right arm that reads ``Winona Forever.'' ``When I started out working I made a point of doing one movie a year,'' Ryder said. ``I was going to have a lot of free time, but all of a sudden, I fell into these movies that I wanted to do. I went from one character to another without having time to think about it. You kind of lose identity. ``It's important to surround yourself with people who have the best intentions for you and want the best things for you. I have a family who are my best friends in the world. I have two other close friends and I have a boyfriend who is great.'' Hard as she tries for a normal life, without maids and servants and limousines, most people her age don't have careers, don't own homes and don't dodge photographers. But her great appeal as an actress is how easy she is to relate to, the look of permanent adolescent boredom in ``Beetlejuice'' or the mixture of fear and desire as she comes to terms with sexuality in ``Great Balls of Fire'' and ``Mermaids.'' Actors seek a childlike frame of mind, an openness to emotions that allows them to react spontaneously. It's easier for Ryder; she has fewer years to lose. ``I love movies about children, like `To Kill a Mockingbird.' I loved it because it was told in this voice of innocence, of purity. It was so incredibly powerful to me because of that. It wasn't just an adult trying to write in the eyes of a child. I liked `My Life as a Dog' for the same reason. ``Most of the fan mail I receive is thanking me for `Heathers,' '' Ryder says of the hit black comedy about the gruesome revenge of teen outsiders. ``I think `Heathers' was the first movie that didn't completely patronize teen-agers. I think they were sick of what John Hughes was cramming down their throats.'' ``Heathers'' is her favorite film, but Ryder also loved ``Edward Scissorhands,'' the romantic fable directed by close friend Tom Burton, and ``Mermaids,'' the quirky comedy co-starring Cher and Bob Hoskins. More disappointing was ``Welcome Home, Roxy Carmichael,'' a critical and commercial flop that Ryder insists was ``turned into something I couldn't relate to,'' and ``The Godfather, Part III,'' which the overworked actress dropped out of because of exhaustion. Her role of Michael Corleone's daughter went to Sofia Coppola, who has been panned by critics. ``I don't regret doing any movie I have ever done,'' she says. ``Whether or not it was any good or not I got something out of it. From `Roxy Carmichael' I made a really good friend. Also I learn things, standing up for yourself, lessons in terms of direction.'' Ryder's first name came from a town in her home state of Minnesota. She grew up in San Francisco and enjoyed a world of bohemian poets, communes and old movies. Her father owns a bookstore and served as archivist to Leary, the merry LSD guru of the 1960s. Her mother makes educational films. Ryder took up acting. ``I started at 10 or 11,'' she said. ``I went to a theater school (American Conservatory Theater) in San Francisco and I was just taking classes there. It was something I was doing as a hobby because I was having trouble in regular school. I couldn't make any friends so I thought I could meet people more like me.'' Early roles included ``Lucas,'' ``1969'' and ``Square Dance.'' In ``Beetlejuice,'' she played the most alienated of teen-agers, decked out in black robes pulled from the actress' own closet, and was the child bride of Dennis Quaid in ``Great Balls of Fire,'' based on the life of rock 'n' roller Jerry Lee Lewis. Ryder swears ``Edward Scissorhands'' represents her graduation from high school films and she is scheduled to appear as a taxi driver in a new movie by ``Mystery Train'' director Jim Jarmusch.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-AP Arts: Ryder
Actor Earning New Respect With Haunting Portrayal
DOC.TEXT: --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Johnny Depp, a forgotten young TV star largely unknown by the movie-going public, has found new popularity thanks to his title role in ``Edward Scissorhands.'' His co-star is also his fiance, actress Winona Ryder. ---
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Once dismissed as a television star with a teen following, Johnny Depp is earning new respect this season as the cutlery-equipped creation of scientist Vincent Price in ``Edward Scissorhands.'' With his weapon-like hands and scarred, pallid face, Depp has been drawing critical praise for his haunting portrayal in Tim Burton's hit fantasy. It's a far cry from the undercover cop Tom Hanson he played during four seasons of the Fox network's ``21 Jump Street.'' The real Johnny Depp is a handsome 27-year-old with a faint stubble of black beard and spiky hair reminiscent of Edward's. He recalls being overwhelmed upon reading the ``Edward Scissorhands'' script by Caroline Thompson. ``I had a feeling about the story and the character that I can't describe,'' he recalled. ``I knew I had to do it. ``I started thinking about the character right away. I kept thinking of the faces of dogs I had owned. The eyes of new-born babies. Pinocchio. All the great classics like `The Hunchback of Notre Dame' started coming to me, and they all compiled in this big mass. ``When I first met with Tim, we talked for two or three hours - me and Tim and Denise Di Novi, the producer. I think we had similar images of the character. I saw Tim's drawings, and everything just clicked.'' Burton, a former animator for the Walt Disney Co., brought his unique vision to ``Pee-wee's Big Adventure,'' ``Beetlejuice'' and ``Batman.'' His drawings helped convey the physical appearance of Edward, but Depp had to build a character out of someone who had no past: He was simply an (unfinished) creation of Vincent Price. ``I kept thinking of a dog,'' Depp theorized. ``Dogs have that unconditional love. If you scold a dog, he cowers in a corner. As soon as you call him back, he's there, and all is forgotten. ``A lot of the things that Tim and I talked about was just to maintain the purity of the character. Edward has lived in the attic of this mansion for seven years, and when he comes into suburbia, everything was beautiful and fascinating to him. ``I got the (scissor) hands a few months before we started shooting. I just tried to function normally with these long shears. Normal things like working remote control on the television set were just impossible. Trying to work the TV set manually or turn on the cassette player was tough. Going to the bathroom is something I don't want to talk about. ``I went to sleep with the hands on. Woke up and one of them had been thrown across the room. I nicked myself a few times. After a while it became second nature. ``Because Edward doesn't say a lot, I knew early on that (the character) would rely on gestures. When I was finally put into the costume and bound up, that escalated the ideas I had. The feeling of being bound up and completely restricted, not able to move with full capacity. The wardrobe, the hands and the costume helped a lot.'' Depp's love interest in ``Edward Scissorhands'' is Winona Ryder, his off-screen sweetheart. ``We had been together for six months before we started the movie,'' he said. ``It was kind of a lucky coincidence. She had already been attached to the project. Then I read it and thought that Tim would never want me. I was pleasantly surprised when he did.'' Johnny Depp was born in Owenboro, Ky., and moved to Miramar, Fla., when he was 6. He came to Hollywood in 1983, intending to be a rock musician. A friend introduced him to an agent, and Depp was cast in ``A Nightmare on Elm Street.'' He played one of the soldiers in ``Platoon,'' then began his four-year, sometimes stormy association with ``21 Jump Street.'' ``There's nothing bad I can say about the series,'' he said. ``On one level it definitely put me on the map. There's not a better way to learn than to just do it every day on camera, five days a week. ``I've had no trouble with being typed. When you meet me, you realize I'm an entirely different person from the character I played on television.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Thurs. Jan. 3

DOC.HEAD: Academy Awards Could Be Race Between a Western and Two Gangster Movies
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The candidates all have appeared, and now the movie world looks forward to a shootout between a Western pioneer and two bands of modern-day gangsters for the Academy Awards. Will Kevin Costner's ``Dances With Wolves'' be the winner? Consensus thinking favors the epic of a cavalry officer who is adopted by an Indian tribe. Hollywood admires Costner's courage to fight for his film against heavy odds: Westerns are out of fashion, one-third of the dialogue is subtitled, the film runs three hours. However, strong competition comes from ``GoodFellas,'' which traces the rise and fall of a Brooklyn wiseguy. The Martin Scorsese drama has been scoring with critics' circles awards in New York and Los Angeles, less so with the ticket-buying public. After 98 days in release, ``GoodFellas'' has collected a respectable but unsensational $40 million. Paramount Picture's Christmas gift to Corleone fans, ``The Godfather Part III,'' may also prove a strong contender. A victory as best picture would provide an unbreakable record; the first two ``Godfathers'' won Hollywood's top prize. But more recent history seems to favor ``Dances With Wolves'' to win as best picture of 1990. Academy voters have opted for broadscale movies of courage and adventure: ``Ghandi,'' ``Chariots of Fire,'' ``Out of Africa,'' ``Platoon,'' ``The Last Emperor.'' Money alone doesn't sway the voters. There is little chance for important awards for the $100 million-plus moneymakers of the year: ``The Hunt for Red October,'' ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Ghost,'' ``Pretty Woman,'' ``Die Hard 2,'' ``Total Recall,'' ``Home Alone,'' not to mention ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' Here's how the nominees for the 1990 Oscar race appear to this observer: - Best Picture: ``Dances With Wolves,'' ``GoodFellas'' and ``The Godfather Part III'' could be joined by a classic, ``Hamlet'' or ``Cyrano de Bergerac.'' Penny Marshall's ``Awakenings'' has a strong chance. On a more frivolous note, ``Postcards From the Edge'' is a possibility. Longshots include ``Avalon,'' ``The Grifters,'' ``The Sheltering Sky,'' ``Reversal of Fortune.'' - Best Actor: Kevin Costner's valiant Westerner seems a certain nominee, along with Al Pacino's aging Michael Corleone of ``The Godfather Part III.'' Robin Williams as the warm-hearted doctor in ``Awakenings'' and Jeremy Irons' cold-blooded Claus von Bulow of ``Reversal of Fortune'' also are likely. Robert De Niro could be nominated for either ``GoodFellas'' or ``Awakenings.'' Longshots: Danny Glover, ``To Sleep With Anger''; Gerard Depardieu, ``Cyrano de Bergerac'' or ``Green Card''; Armin Mueller-Stahl, ``Avalon''; Richard Harris, ``The Field''; Sean Connery, ``The Hunt for Red October'' or ``The Russia House.'' Best Actress: Two past winners figure strongly, Joanne Woodward for ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' and Anjelica Huston for ``The Grifters'' or ``Witches.'' Susan Sarandon also seems likely for ``White Palace.'' Kathy Bates of ``Misery'' could be nominated in this category or as supporting actress. Others: Meryl Streep and Shirley MacLaine, ``Postcards From the Edge''; Mia Farrow, ``Alice''; Julia Roberts, ``Pretty Woman''; Michelle Pfeiffer, ``The Russia House.'' Best Supporting Actor: Joe Pesci, ``GoodFellas''; Bruce Davison, ``Longtime Companion''; Andy Garcia, ``The Godfather Part III''; Marlon Brando, ``The Freshman''; Graham Greene, ``Dances With Wolves''; Hector Elizondo, ``Pretty Woman''; Al Pacino, ``Dick Tracy''; Alan Arkin, ``Edward Scissorhands.'' Best Supporting Actress: Dianne Wiest, ``Edward Scissorhands''; Whoopi Goldberg, ``Ghost'' or ``The Long Walk Home''; Mary McDonnell, ``Dances With Wolves''; Diane Ladd, ``Wild at Heart''; Lorraine Bracco, ``GoodFellas''; Joan Plowright, ``Avalon.'' Best Director: Kevin Costner, ``Dances With Wolves''; Martin Scorsese, ``GoodFellas''; Francis Ford Coppola, ``The Godfather Part III''; Penny Marshall, ``Awakenings''; Mike Nichols, ``Postcards From the Edge''; Barbet Schroeder, ``Reversal of Fortune''; Franco Zeffirelli, ``Hamlet''; Peter Weir, ``Green Card.'' The above hopefuls will be culled when the Academy Award nominations are announced in pre-dawn ceremonies on Feb. 13 in Beverly Hills. The awards will be presented on March 25 at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwanese Rock Group Sings With a Rebellious Voice
DOC.TEXT: A rock group that sings in Taiwan's native language has taken this island nation by storm, becoming the first music group to criticize the Nationalist government in another sign of Taiwan's increasing freedom. Blacklist, a trio of two Taiwanese and one American, mouths its dissent with bold lyrics and a musical style that blends rock 'n' roll with the exotic strains of traditional Chinese music. Nobody is safe from the band's sarcastic lyrics, which mock pro-democracy protesters and conservative Nationalist politicians alike. Even Taiwan's middle-class lifestyle comes in for a beating in a song that goes: ``Heh, heh Taxi, where are you going?'' One song called ``Democracy Bumpkin'' from the band's new LP makes fun of both the government and demonstrators. The tune begins with trumpets feebly playing Taiwan's national anthem. An electric guitar cuts in. The groups sings: ``I stroll in downtown Taipei - Riot police block the street ... Suddenly my heart feels a chill - Tell me please, Mr. Policeman - Are we preparing a war to regain mainland China?'' As the music blares, shouts of ``I want to protest'' fill the air - a reflection of the pent-up frustration in Taiwan's highly regulated society. The song criticizes elderly lawmakers who have occupied about half of the seats in the legislature since 1949, when the Nationalist government lost a war to communist forces on mainland China and fled to Taiwan. The legislators have been frozen in office to support the Nationalists' claim to represent all China. ``They are so old that they can hardly breathe - The government fears they may die anytime - So our tax money pays for their intravenous drips,'' the song goes. Government censors tolerated the band's first album, ``Songs of Madness,'' released in November 1989. But Taiwan's government-controlled radio and television stations have never broadcast their tunes. The unofficial ban has hurt the band. Nevertheless, the album has so far sold more than 100,000 copies to students and intellectuals, an impressive figure for the group. ``These are Taiwan's most rebellious songs in 40 years. They are candid eyewitnesses of our time,'' said Jack Liu, chief editor of the Audio Art monthly. Joe Wang, founder of the Blacklist, does not seem to worry about the broadcast ban. ``We know some Nationalist authorities hate these songs. But we have to send out the message that people here are not happy with Taiwan's politics and society,'' he said in a recent interview at Blacklist's studio. ``It is encouraging that our album is still well-received,'' added Keith Stuart, studio engineer of the group. ``It means this society is open enough to accept new concepts.'' Wang, 36, formed the Blacklist two years ago with friend Io Chen, a 29-year-old cellist. They were joined by Stuart, 34, of Little Rock, Ark., who specializes in synthesizing and composition. Taiwan has undergone great change since 1987 when the government ended the 38 years of martial law that had cemented the Nationalists in power. Opposition parties were legalized shortly thereafter, restrictions on the press were relaxed and free elections were held. Still, large-scale resentment continues. While most artists here refrain from offending authorities, Blacklist participated in Taiwan's largest student protest in March to demand that the elderly lawmakers step down. During the week-long sit-in at a Taipei park, thousands of college students, outraged by the government's slow pace of political reforms, sang aloud, ``We won't wait any more,'' an impromptu song dedicated to the protesters by Blacklist. The government later agreed to retire all the aging lawmakers, mostly in their 80s or older, by the end of 1991. ``Those old deputies are the most ridiculous phenomenon in the world,'' Wang said. ``But they are not to blame. The Nationalists made them absurd.'' Another thing that makes the group unique in Taiwan is their use of the local Taiwanese dialect, instead of official Mandarin Chinese. When the Nationalists took power in Taiwan, they imposed the culture of the mainland on this island. Taiwanese comprise of about 85 percent of Taiwan's population of 20 million, but Mandarin Chinese replaced the Taiwanese dialect in the classroom and students were penalized if they spoke the local patois. Wang, a native Taiwanese, started writing songs in Taiwanese about five years ago when his grandmother complained she could not understand him over the telephone. ``I didn't know I was a Taiwanese when I was young. I even took pride in my fluent Mandarin,'' he said. The band has met with much critical acclaim even from intellectuals. ``The music is very good with its originality,'' said Hsiao Yeh, a prominent writer. ``The songs grow from this land and show their concerns for the people.'' Wang might disagree. ``In some ways,'' he said, ``we are aliens in Taiwan's pop music.''

DOC.HEAD: Foxy Legacy: The Lingering Impact of Jimi Hendrix
DOC.TEXT: Jimi Hendrix is dead and selling jeans in Britain. Still selling records, too, 20 years after his death; still unmatched by all would-be imitators of his furious, blazing mastery of the electric guitar. ``The Hendrix phenomenon has never really gone away,'' says George McManus, marketing executive at Polydor Records. Two decades gone, Hendrix is a briskly moving product. Polydor's ``Cornerstones'' album hit the top five and will shortly go platinum in Britain. Wrangler adopted ``Crosstown Traffic'' for a jeans commercial. Bass player Noel Redding and drummer Mitch Mitchell, the survivors of the Jimi Hendrix Experience, each published books this year. ``Jimi's death was the most lucrative act of his sad career,'' according to Redding, whose book is partly a diatribe against the Hendrix estate. The U.S. Army, which counts Hendrix as an alumnus, kicked off the year by including his ``Voodoo Chile'' as part of its amplified get-out-of-that-refuge concert in Panama for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The anniversary may be a melancholy event for anyone who remembers the first ear-boggling encounter with ``Foxy Lady,'' ``Manic Depression'' or ``Purple Haze'' - ``'Scuse me, while I kiss the sky'' - from the ``Are You Experienced?'' LP in 1967. Serious craziness was the Hendrix experience: a stoned banshee swathed in psychedelic foppery, caressing and bullying and battering his guitar; bending ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' into weird shapes at Woodstock; amazing the plaster casters; fleeing a concert in Denver in a cloud of tear gas; taking too many downers and choking to death on his own vomit. Born in Seattle in 1942, Hendrix found fame in Britain, and Britain is where he died, in his London apartment on Sept. 18, 1970. His records have always sold well, but his impact wasn't widely recognized until the Wrangler jeans company commissioned a survey into British teen-age musical tastes. Hendrix's name ranked high alongside living rock stars. Wrangler decided to feature Hendrix's ``Crosstown Traffic'' in what became a highly effective TV commercial. Filmed in New York, it showed a handsome young taxi driver who dumps his cab in the middle of Manhattan and takes off to Miami. Wrangler followed up with another commercial including footage of Hendrix in concert. ``His appeal is partly his rebel image and partly his short life, the James Dean factor,'' Polydor's McManus said. ``But deeper than that, I believe it is because he is the source of so much of today's music. People like Bon Jovi and Def Leppard will readily admit to the debt they owe him. You can hear 20 seconds of a guitar and know it is Jimi Hendrix. Very few people had that ability.'' One of the most successful new British bands to cite Hendrix as an influence is The Stone Roses from the thriving Manchester scene, whose ``indie dance'' music combines psychedelia with disco-derived ``house'' music. Hendrix's influence can be detected on their two recent Top 10 singles, ``One Love'' and ``Fools Gold'' ``Hendrix is top for me,'' says Stone Roses guitarist John Squire. ``He was trying to expand peoples' minds in the '60s and we're trying to do the same thing for the '90s. He had an extrovert approach which we share. He is one of the few people we can relate to.'' The two men most closely related to Hendrix have contrasting stories to tell. Redding, who was sacked from the band, emphasizes financial matters. His book, ``Are You Experienced?'' is about the millions of dollars worth of royalties he claims to be owed. Mitchell's book, ``The Hendrix Experience,'' is full of pictures and generally happier. Hendrix, according to Mitchell, ``was far from a tragic character. For one thing, he had a wicked sense of humor. That's why the women, in particular, really liked him, because we're talking about a man who was funny.'' One of Hendrix's secrets as a guitar technician, Mitchell writes, were his thumbs, ``nearly as long as his fingers.'' Mitchell also complains about his treatment by the estate, but he had one lucrative gift from Hendrix: a Fender Stratocaster that sold for $350,000 at auction in April. One important figure who has not written his memoirs is Chas Chandler, former bass player of The Animals who saw Hendrix in a Greenwich Village club, brought him to England and formed The Jimi Hendrix Experience. ``I considered writing a book now and again, but I never had the time, and anyway I enjoy books too much,'' Chandler said in a rare interview. He has returned to his roots in a coastal village in the northeast of England where he lives with his family and manages a local rock outfit, The Steve Graham Band. Chandler produced the first two Hendrix albums, ``Are You Experienced?'' and ``Axis: Bold as Love,'' but quit halfway through ``Electric Ladyland,'' frustrated with the hangers-on and endless rerecording of tracks. ``My only obvious regret is I wonder if I didn't walk out maybe he would still be alive. He is a loss; he was a good friend. Otherwise, I certainly have no regrets,'' Chandler said. ``I do think there is a death cult around Jimi. There is something black about all this brooding over his death. He is typified as some sort of brooding genius. But when he was alive he was a very funny guy, full of laughter. He was quite a gentle lad, quiet but witty and a good mimic. ``You would have thought he went everywhere and burned his guitar. But he only did it twice.'' Chandler said that when he met him, Hendrix hadn't written a song. ``But I knew there was a place in England for him through the sheer potential of his guitar. The music audiences in England had become quite sophisticated. ... The Beatles were pushing the boundaries of what was acceptable and audiences were quite willing to grasp something that was experimental.'' Chandler also believes Hendrix's appeal endures because of his imitators. ``Most of the riffs played by a lot of guitar bands have their origins in Hendrix. He was an originator of sounds, the greatest guitar player to have lived,'' Chandler said.

DOC.HEAD: From Seedy to Thriving: Kansas City's River Quay
DOC.TEXT: In its brief heyday, it was a place where people would go to browse for antiques or enjoy a night on the town. But for the last 13 years, ever since a series of mob bombings and gangland slayings closed taverns and scared customers away, Kansas City's River Quay area has sat deserted. Transients slept beside empty buildings and an X-rated movie theater. The only sign of a former era came on Saturday mornings, when produce companies sold vegetables and fruit out of dilapidated stalls. Now, with $40 million in public and private investment and a new name, the city's River Market area hopes to draw people back with a renovated produce market, upscale loft apartments, quaint restaurants, shops and a riverboat museum. It's the kind of restoration that has led to a business and economic surge for historic commercial areas in many cities, from Boston's Faneuil Hall Marketplace to Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. ``We're trying to create a neighborhood - to have people living down here and shopping down here. And we're finally starting to show some results,'' said Bette Guarino, president of a non-profit group that struggled for years to find a private company to develop the area. People with organized crime connections no longer own property in the area, which lies just north of downtown and south of the Missouri River, Ms. Guarino said. The mob can't move in this time because of tighter city zoning controls, she said. Developers are focusing on restaurants and apartments, not bars. But others say the River Quay's legacy lingers. ``When it's finished, it'll be the greatest thing that ever happened to this city,'' said Mary Jane Orlando, the owner of Mama Orlando's restaurant, one of the few eateries open in the area. More are scheduled to open soon. ``But it's not finished yet,'' Mrs. Orlando said. ``People are watching what's going on down here. They're aware of the progress, but they're still scared.'' Mrs. Orlando said she got a typical reaction during a recent trip to a dentist in a northern Kansas City suburb. ``When I gave the address of my place of business, the receptionist, who I'd never met, looked at me and said, `Aren't you scared to be down there with the Mafia?'' Mrs. Orlando said. ``So a lot of people are still thinking about that.'' In the last year, the area has regained some of its former charm. The private development company that bought many of the area's old buildings has leased more than 70 loft apartments to young professionals and couples, many of whom work downtown. Another developer owns two buildings full of loft apartments where poets hold public readings on weekend nights. The city has repaved streets and put in new lights, brick sidewalks and trees. This spring, a museum housing a restored paddlewheel from a riverboat that sank in 1856 is scheduled to open. ``The physical renovation is going really great,'' said Brian Collins, president of the Economic Development Corp. ``We have a lot of hopes for it. In other cities, this kind of market area has really sparked revivals.'' The area evolved slowly from a stretch of river shorline into a a business district and farmer's market. The brother of Tom Pendergast, a famous political boss, once owned a tavern there. But it was mostly warehouses by the time a local developer got the idea to attract artists and restaurants in 1972. A year after the first shops and artists' lofts opened, 60 businesses were operating. But a surprisingly high number were bars. As the area prospered, the mob mucled in, attempting to transform it into a red-light district. Then arson fires started. The father of one bar owner who resisted mob intimidation was found slain in a car trunk. Other slayings followed. Artists moved away and customers stopped coming. ``There was a time when I had to defend this project everywhere I went and everyone I talked to because of all that history,'' Ms. Guarino said. ``I still run across that a little, but not nearly as much. Now people want to know what's happening.''

DOC.HEAD: Memory of Folk Singer Phil Ochs Kept Alive
DOC.TEXT: With America facing the possibility of another war and the unbound optimism of the 1980s becoming threadbare, the late Phil Ochs' songs carry the same bite today as they did two decades ago. And they're getting wider play again, at least in the East. Verses such as ``So young so strong so ready for the war, so willing to go and die upon a foreign shore,'' from ``One More Parade,'' could just as easily be a lament about soldiers marching off to the Persian Gulf as Southeast Asia. And, ``If you can't afford your bill don't tell me that you're ill, 'cause that's the free enterprise way,'' from the sarcastic ``AMA Song,'' rings a chord for people hit by the spiraling cost of health care. Ochs - sounds like ``oaks'' - wrote those songs in the '60s, when his gift for composing tuneful poison-pen letters to the establishment placed him near the top of the heap of popular folk singers. ``I think everybody in the field at the time felt he had a great influence and was a great writer,'' said Dick Cerri, president of the World Folk Music Association. ``As a songwriter ... he was second to only (Bob) Dylan in the late '60s,'' said Ochs' brother and former manager, Michael Ochs. But when the peace and love spirit of the Woodstock generation withered in the early '70s, so too did Ochs' spirit. Feeling he lost touch with his audience and his abilities, he killed himself in 1976 at the age of 36. But this is a case where the old cliche is true: the death silenced Ochs, but not his music. Old Ochs songs have been ringing out with regularity the last eight years in clubs from Massachusetts to the Mason-Dixon line. Keeping the spirit of her younger brother alive, Sonny Ochs has been organizing ``Phil Ochs Song Nights,'' during which old folkies and younger performers highlight Ochs' extensive song catalog. A typical performance recently in Albany, less than 40 miles from her rural Middleburgh home, featured national folk stars Nancy Tucker and Magpie sharing a club stage with local acts. ``I get all these people together through Phil's music,'' Ochs said. She has been organizing the concerts since 1982, when choosing the line-up for a planned memorial show at the now-defunct Speakeasy in Manhattan inadvertently fell in her lap. ``I picked up the ball and ran with it and I've been running ever since,'' she said. Ochs has since put on shows all over the East. ``I just did not want the songs to die. What would have been the point of his life if no one listened to them anymore?'' she asked. Born Dec. 19, 1940, in El Paso, Texas, Phil Ochs was mostly raised in the East. Following an in-and-out college career, he headed to where every aspiring folkie headed in the early '60s - Greenwich Village. ``I was very arrogant at the time, and I thought I'd be the best songwriter in the world,'' he said. ``But then I immediately met Dylan and decided that I'd be the second-best songwriter in the world.'' Ochs built a following on the strength of songs like ``I Ain't Marchin' Any More'' and ``When I'm Gone.'' A keen observer and sharp wit in the tradition of Woody Guthrie, Ochs fired lyrical salvos at everyone from the Nixon administration to fellow liberals. His acid tongue attracted listeners, but also scared a lot of people off. ``Everyone just assumed he was a raving commie, but he wasn't,'' said Michael Ochs. Not as lovable as Peter, Paul & Mary or as drop-dead cool as his estranged friend Dylan, Ochs was mostly ignored by the mass media. ``He was censored when he was alive,'' Sonny Ochs said. ``He couldn't get on national TV or radio.'' Even without media attention, Ochs could sell out a hall, including Carnegie Hall three times, and he relied on album sales. He also maintained a high profile in the civil rights and anti-war movements. But he grew disillusioned when the anti-establishment fervor faded after the '60s. He moved on to more introspective songs, and he became depressed. ``He felt he didn't fit in anymore,'' Michael Ochs said. His sister said Phil felt he lost his gift for writing songs. He began avoiding live appearances and stopped writing songs. ``He refused to even try,'' she said. ``The last three years were the worst.'' On April 9, 1976, he hanged himself in his sister's bathroom in New York City.

DOC.HEAD: A Hawk on the Gulf with a Friend in the White House
DOC.TEXT: Early in the Persian Gulf crisis, Sen. Richard Lugar was invited for a private dinner with the president and a few advisers in the living quarters upstairs at the White House. For an hour and a half, they talked about Lugar's public assertion earlier in the day that Saddam Hussein must either leave power ``or be removed.'' President Bush ``heard very well everything I had said,'' the Indiana Republican later recalled in an interview. When Lugar told him he planned to repeat the same ideas in a speech the next day in Indiana, Bush did not try to dissuade him, even though the thought of removing Saddam went well beyond any public administration position. Asked whether he was pushing Bush to go farther, or giving voice to things the president couldn't say himself, Lugar paused, then smiled and said: ``Maybe both.'' After five months of dealing with the crisis, it is clear that some of the administration's toughest messages have been delivered through Lugar, the most respected foreign policy voice in the Senate. Lugar is sure to play a big role in the new session of Congress, likely to be dominated by the gulf crisis. After reassembling Wednesday, the nation's lawmakers will have to decide whether the president can send American forces into an offensive war without first obtaining congressional consent. To its own surprise, Congress also must look for a way to pad the impact of the economic downturn at a time when the deficit is growing beyond all expectations. And it confronts the possibility that the nation's banks will need a shoring up - if not a full-scale bailout. On the gulf issue, Lugar is sure to be heard. He pressed - unsuccessfully - for an emergency congressional session to vote on a resolution endorsing Bush's gulf policy. He has aligned himself with a new group of congressional hawks formed to support a hard-line approach. ``In general, he is the point man for the administration on the Foreign Relations Committee,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., a member. ``My assumption is that whatever he says, he is also speaking for the administration or with their approval.'' The crisis is giving still more prominence to Lugar. At 58, he is graying but trim, a jogger, a Senate workhorse. He was elected mayor of Indianapolis when he was 35 and he remains loyal to Bush even though it must have been painful when Bush reached over him to select his junior partner in the Senate, Dan Quayle, as his running mate in 1988. Not that everything Lugar says on the gulf pleases Bush. Lugar has been the nagging voice asking some unpopular questions: -What does the United States do if Saddam Hussein withdraws from Kuwait but remains in power in his own country with a million-man army and nuclear ambitions? -Who starves first if the international food supply to Iraq is cut off - soldiers, or children? -Why should Congress be allowed to criticize the U.S. military buildup and snipe at the administration's policy without a formal vote on whether it is willing to use military force to remove Iraq from Kuwait? ``Somebody in the public dialogue has to raise these questions,'' Lugar said. He denied that he was the launcher of White House trial balloons, but added, ``My thinking is a fairly careful fit with the way they see the world.'' That has not always been the case. He earned his foreign policy credentials during the Reagan administration, most often by pushing the administration to do things it resisted. Lugar was the key to a policy shift that gave up on keeping Ferdinand Marcos in power in the Philippines and he was a decisive vote when Congress forced Reagan to accept economic sanctions against South Africa. He also has been active in other arenas from Central America to Southeast Asia. And the only foreign aid authorization bill to be passed by Congress during the past decade came during Lugar's brief tenure as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee in 1985-86, when the GOP controlled the Senate. These days, he's not even the senior Republican on the committee. That job belongs to Jesse Helms of North Carolina, who pulled seniority to beat Lugar out of the post four years ago. The bitterness lingers, and the two senators barely speak to each other. But Lugar's credibility on foreign policy comes not from his standing on the committee but his personal contacts and study around the globe. ``He reads and studies issues, visits with a number of specialists, and travels a fair amount,'' said colleague Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., who added that Lugar's game plan in foreign affairs isn't always clear. ``He tends to keep his cards very close to his vest,'' she said. Some have suspected that his toughness on the gulf issue might be a form of political inoculation against a pre-invasion stand opposing sanctions on Iraq for using poison gas against its own citizens. Sanctions would have hurt American farmers, an important constituency for the Indiana senator, and would have damaged administration efforts at the time to strengthen Iraq as a counterweight to Islamic fundamentalism in neighboring Iran. But Lugar denies that he's bending over backwards to make up for that stand, saying he still opposes the use of food embargoes as a foreign policy tool because it starves the innocent. Instead, he says, he wants to help shape what Bush has called ``one of the defining moments in history.'' ``We are really coming to a crucial point as to whether there is the potential for the world's people to unite in a crisis,'' he said. ``That seems to be a ... pretty sober responsibility. Things are going to happen, and the consequences are going to be very substantial. ... I just see this as an amazing opportunity.''

DOC.HEAD: Medical Stocks Thrive in Ailing Market
DOC.TEXT: In the anemic environment that prevailed on Wall Street in 1990, medical and drug stocks proved to be the best prescription for financial health. At the same time, shares of bank and savings and loan holding companies dominated the market's sick list as the year drew to a close. Most broad-based indicators of stock-price trends showed double-digit percentage losses for 1990 as of late December, turning in their poorest performances since the bear market of 1981-82. Just 11 of 82 stock groups tracked by Dow Jones & Co.'s industry-group indexes posted gains for the year through the close of trading on Dec. 21. Among the gainers, the medical and biotechnology group led the pack with an advance of better than 20 percent, followed by medical supplies, pharmaceutical manufacturers, health-care providers and retail drug chains. The performance of these stocks testifies that health care remains a booming, though by no means trouble-free, business in the early 1990s. While the nation debates what to do about soaring health costs and uneven distribution of medical services, many companies in the field continue to thrive as the population ages and seeks longer, healthier lives. Technology and other innovation add an extra measure of opportunity, however risky in business terms, for venturesome health-care enterprises both large and small. A just-published quarterly report by the Value Line Investment Survey on the medical supplies industry cites ``growing demand for health care, a decent pricing environment, and the entry of more high-margined products'' as major reasons for recent enthusiasm over stocks of this kind. Even the gloomy outlook for the economy has worked in favor of health-care stocks, by encouraging investors to look for ``defensive'' issues that are insulated from the effects of a business slump. As Value Line observed in its latest evaluation of the drug stocks, ``pharmaceutical manufacturers have always been known for their defensive characteristics. ``They look particularly recession-resistant this time around, due to the elimination of many low-margined non-health care product lines over the course of the last several years.'' A standout example of a winning health-care stock in 1990: U.S. Surgical, producer of a line of products used in surgical stapling, which soared from 24[ in January to a recent high just under 70. Turn U.S. Surgical's stock chart upside down, and you would have a pretty fair representation of what happened to many bank and savings and loan issues over the past year. Dow Jones's S&L index fell nearly 60 percent; its gauge of money-center banks dropped 37 percent, and its composite of regional banks from the various corners of the country lost 40 percent. The story gets even more somber when you look at the behavior of many individual issues from the banking and S&L sector - for example, Bank of New England, which fell from above 9 to less than 1, for a drop of about 93 percent. First City Bancorp, Crossland Savings, Unionfed Financial, Citytrust Bancorp and HomeFed all suffered declines of more than 80 percent. In the last few weeks of 1990, many depressed financial issues have rallied a bit on buy orders from investors attracted by distress merchandise. If the upswing in bank stocks were to continue, analysts say, it might start shaping up as a signal that the worst of the nation's spell of debt retrenchment and credit crunch were past. But whether any such hopes are warranted now remains to be determined in 1991.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon Dec 31

DOC.HEAD: Women Rappers: ``Wreckin' Rhymes and Taking Names''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 26th graf: Though women
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Not long ago, Yolanda Whitaker was just another kid growing up among gangs and drugs in south-central Los Angeles. When she walked home from school, Crips gang members threw rocks at her because she lived in a Bloods neighborhood. Fast forward five years. Yolanda is now known as Yo-Yo, one of the leading female rappers to emerge from the decade-long, male-dominated rap revolution. She's only 19 and she has just one album to her name. But she's made enough money to buy her own apartment in Hawthorne, a quiet Los Angeles suburb light years away from Watts. She also gives women a voice in the macho, often misogynistic rap industry. With such songs as ``Put a Lid on It,'' she sends a message to the kind of teen-age girls she grew up with, urging them not to have sex and babies so freely. Or, as she might say onstage, she's ``wreckin' rhymes and taking names.'' ``I address most of my rhymes to the ladies,'' she said during a recent interview while on tour in New York. ``The ladies are struggling. I try to inspire them to go after what they want and work on their self-esteem.'' Yo-Yo, a protege of former NWA member Ice Cube, is one of about a dozen leading female rappers to break out in the last few years. Their journey from anonymity to fame and fortune - they can make up to $30,000 and more per week on tour - came astonishingly fast for most of them. In an industry in which rap superstar MC Hammer, whose age varies from 27 to 35 in published reports, might be considered almost ancient, leading women rappers such as Yo-Yo, Queen Latifah, M.C. Lyte, Salt 'n' Pepa, Monie Love, Nikki D, Shelly Thunder, Oaktown 3-5-7, Tarrie B., Shazzy and Ms. Melodie are between the ages of 18 and 25. Despite their youth, many are preternaturally wise and self-confident. Yo-Yo, Queen Latifah and Nikki D are all barely out of high school but hold forth in interviews and on stage like wizened street sages. ``You have to be tough,'' said Nikki D. ``People will pull you back in a heartbeat.'' Nikki D, 22, sports a gold front tooth and grew up as Nichele Strong in a middle-class Los Angeles neighborhood. But she went to school ``with all the rough guys from the projects.'' She began small-time rapping in roller rinks and small clubs. She met rapper Ice-T at a Culver City, Calif., mall and he asked her to perform with him. When she was 18, she and a friend took a bus to New York City, arriving with only 35 cents. A year later, Nikki D was the first female rapper signed to Def Jam Records. But some of the swagger of female rappers is as much part of the act as the attire. Many female rappers wear what they call ``b-girl'' (for ``beat'') clothes, baggy sweatshirts, jeans, high-tops and baseball caps. Queen Latifah has made regal Afrocentric clothing her trademark. They are the descendants of the few women such as Funky Four Plus One More who began in the early days of rap in the late 1970s, and others like Roxanne Shante and Salt 'n' Pepa who rode the wave of the first commercially successful female rappers beginning in 1985. Some, such as Yo-Yo, grew up on mean streets with the ``gangstas'' that have become part of rap legend. Others lived near the fringe of tough neighborhoods in New York City and North Jersey, or from gang-ridden areas like Compton and Watts in Los Angeles. Most write their own rhymes. They include 20-year-old Queen Latifah, the pre-eminent female rapper, who was raised in Nwark and East Orange, N.J., and led the Irvington (N.J.) High School women's basketball team to two consecutive championships before abandoning sports for the mike. ``I think rap brings reality to people who aren't from the inner city,'' said Latifah during a break from recording her next album. ``Whether you consider it positive or negative, we're teaching reality.'' Latifah, nee Dana Owens, began rapping in high school where she started as a human beat box for two girlfriends known as Ladies Fresh. She started making demos with the help of friends she met in the rap industry and finally scored with ``Princess of the Posse,'' which was shown on ``Yo! MTV Raps'' and led to a contract with Tommy Boy Records. Her debut was titled ``All Hail the Queen.'' Members of her posse usually wear jackets labeled ``The Queen's Army.'' More than any of her peers, Latifah epitomizes the proud, regal, take-no-prisoners attitude of female rappers. In stark contrast to the lyrics of male rap groups - 2 Live Crew, NWA, Public Enemy and others - many female rappers write rhymes to raise the consciousness and self-esteem of women. Yo-Yo recently started the I.B.W.C (Intelligent Black Women's Coalition) which she said is aimed at increasing the status and self-esteem of all women. Though women are often referred to as ``bitches'' and ``hos'' (whores) and portrayed negatively by male rappers, the majority of women rappers say they do not take offense. ``None of it bothers me,'' said Nikki D. ``I wouldn't down any rap. It's like our own language and not everyone understands that. And the thing is, there are a lot of women like that.'' Nikki D's lyrics are more macho than some, including the singles ``Lettin' Off Steam,'' and ``Up the Ante for the Panties.'' The women said that they believe many male rappers put down women because of the number of groupies who surround rap stars. ``There are a set of women who are golddiggers who will do anything for a guy, sleep with him one night and never see him again and that's OK,'' said Nikki D, whose own boyfriend, fellow rapper Apache, accompanies her on tour. Latifah concurred. ``The girls they talk about have no respect for themselves and they're materialistic,'' she said. ``I'm not like that.'' Latifah wants her music, such songs as the anthem ``Ladies First'' and ``Latifah's Law,'' to uplift women. ``You've got to be positive and strong and respect yourself,'' she said. Rap would seem to be a tough field to break into, but many female rappers said they were encouraged by their male counterparts. ``They were very cool with me,'' said Latifah. ``I had no problem with the guys. I didn't get putdowns.'' Nikki D still remembers the day in May 1987 when she came back to a friend's apartment in New York and heard the voice of rap impresario Russell Simmons on the answering machine. Simmons had just listened to her demo and liked what he heard. ``He was yellin', `she's dope!, she's dope! Where is she? I want her?''' she recalled. ``I was like, ecstatic!''

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street's New Year Blues
DOC.TEXT: The closer 1991 gets the dicier it looks to Wall Street analysts trying to sort out prospects for the economy and corporate profits. The news on business activity has grown gloomier and gloomier in the waning weeks of 1990, challenging widespread hopes in the financial world that the economy might face nothing worse than a short and shallow recession. The portents for the near future don't offer much consolation. On Friday, the Commerce Department reported a fifth consecutive monthly decline in the index of leading economic indicators. Many forecasters also lament that the special characteristics of the current slump make its dangers hard to gauge. In most downturns of the past few decades, recessions ran their course as businesses were able to work down inventories that had built up in booming, inflationary periods. Now, most observers agree, the prime source of trouble lies not in production and distribution, but rather in finance - specifically, the accumulated debts of the past decade or more. In the absence of much recent precedent, analysts say it is tough to calculate how long it might take or how much pain will be required to complete the process of debt retrenchment. ``The need to reliquify after a decade of debt accumulation should be the overriding force in the years ahead,'' said Jack Lavery, director of global research at Merrill Lynch. ``The economy will likely remain in recession until the second half of 1991. The recession is likely to be about average in length and severity, with direction of risk on the weaker and more protracted side.'' ``We hate to be skeptical,'' adds Robert Nurock, a Paoli, Pa., investment advisor. ``However, we see little evidence that the economy is close to bottoming. In fact, we believe that most of the recently released data implies that the decline is accelerating.'' Amid such misgivings, stock prices drifted lower in the past week in extremely light activity surrounding the Christmas holiday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 4.45 to 2,629.21. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.22 to 179.65; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 2.41 to 371.20, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 1.55 at 304.65. Volume on the Big Board averaged only 87.47 million shares a day, down from 176.70 million the week before. Even if the recession, as it is ultimately defined by economists, turns out to be relatively mild, many analysts worry that the ensuing recovery could be slow and painful. ``Once the U.S. economy emerges from the recession or near-recession, we expect sluggish growth for years to come,'' Gerald Rothstein at Oppenheimer & Co. told the firm's clients. ``Overall growth will be hampered by the hangover from private-sector leverage and the need for private funds to be used to fund the federal deficit and the savings and loan (and perhaps banking) crisis.'' Or, as analysts at the firm of Griggs & Santow put it: ``This slowdown has its origins in the excesses of the 1980s - specifically the decision by all sectors of the economy to greatly expand their debts and to take greater risks. ``All these activities were largely financed by institutions that now find themselves the not-so-proud owners of real estate and securities that are under water.'' The real estate and junk-bond markets face problems now that go well beyond any questions of Federal Reserve policy or the level of interest rates, the firm asserts. ``Thus, look for the Fed, recognizing the nature of this downturn, to move cautiously, despite its recent aggressiveness, and for the economy to recover from this downturn very slowly.''

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Lost Job Means New Career for Joe Diffie
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It took the closing of an Oklahoma foundry to get singer Joe Diffie into the country music business. He had long dreamed of having a career in music, and when he was laid off in 1986, he decided to move to Nashville and pursue one. The twist of fate paid off. Diffie's first record, ``Home,'' was a No. 1 hit in November. ``Seeing it come to fruition is very gratifying,'' the 31-year-old performer said in an interview during his third day back in Nashville after a whirlwind, five-week tour of one-nighters. Diffie had been working at the foundry in Duncan, Okla., running a core machine, when he lost his job and his $1,700-a-month salary. ``I never had any hair left on my arms; it was always singed off,'' he recalled about the job. ``I always had burns all over me. I detested every second of the job. I didn't like any aspect of it except the people there. ``It was a blessing in disguise when it shut down. If it hadn't, I'd probably still be there or some place like it.'' After reaching Nashville, he took a job for 1{ years in the shipping and receiving department at the Gibson Guitar factory. ``Home'' spent six weeks in the Top 10 on the country music popularity charts, faring better than tunes by more estalished singers such as Anne Murray and Eddie Rabbitt. The wistful song is about the values of home life: ``A swimming hole and fishing pole and the feel of the muddy road between my toes ... ``A back yard swing where I would sit and mom would sing `Amazing Grace' while she hung out the clothes ... ``An easy chair with my daddy there and the smell of Sunday supper on the stove ...'' Diffie said the song stirred strong emotions. ``I think everybody related to it, regardless of whether they were raised in the country or city, because everybody has a home in their memory. When I first heard it, I got a lump in my throat. It brings back a feeling of when you were younger, safe and secure without any worries and no problems. ``It was a sweet song but not too syrupy.'' The tune is on his first album, ``A Thousand Winding Roads,'' on Epic Records. The LP is a mixture of ballads and up-tempo songs performed in a style described by Billboard Magazine as ``Randy Travis with a Merle Haggard catch to his voice.'' His second single released from the album is ``If You Want Me To,'' a traditional country weeper about a man offering to leave his lover if that's what she wants. Another cut on the LP, ``There Goes the Neighborhood,'' is a ballad about marriages dissolving. The cut ``Almost Home'' is about the decline of an aging parent. Diffie, who co-wrote four of the songs on the album, says he's taken advantage of a new era in country music. ``There's been a changing of the guard in country music: the listeners, the artists, the radio stations and the people producing the records,'' he said. ``The songs are getting better and better with the new songwriters coming in. That's not to say the old ones are bad. But it's almost like country music has got a little edge to it now. ``Some of the more sensitive matters are being touched upon.'' Diffie is a native of the Duncan area and spent much of his life there. His father had a huge collection of country music and his parents instilled in him a love of the music. He remembers singing ``Amazing Grace,'' ``You Are My Sunshine'' and ``Peace in the Valley'' with his two sisters while they traveled in the family pickup truck. He briefly attended Cameron University in Oklahoma and eyed a career as a heart surgeon or chiropractor, but he was more interested in music. He has a six-piece band and a fan club with the catchy name ``Diffie Cult.'' Keeping things in the family, his mother is its president.
