DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Mayor Signs Landmark VDT Ordinance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead and SUBS 2 grafs for 7th graf pvs, `The legislation...,' to CORRECT that ordinance isn't nation's first because a similar was approved in New York county but overturned by court. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Hsei said...; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's only law regulating video display terminal use was signed Thursday by Mayor Art Agnos, who touted the ordinance as being ``on the cutting edge of social change.'' The law covers city workers and businesses with 15 or more employees. It requires employers to provide adjustable work stations, regular breaks and training on safe use of VDTs. The law also recommends that pregnant VDT users be shifted to other work if they request it. Employers would have been given two years to make the changes, but a compromise worked out last weekend between Agnos and business and labor leaders gives employers four years to comply. ``This legislation ... will ensure San Francisco workers are protected from dangerous injury, without driving away businesses,'' Agnos said. ``It's legislation on the cutting edge of social change.'' One voice raised against the measure is that of Tom Hsieh, a member of the Board of Supervisors who contends it violates the city charter. Legal authorities in City Hall say he's wrong. A similar ordinance, passed in 1988 in Suffolk County on New York's Long Island and bitterly opposed by business owners, was overturned a year later by a state court on the grounds the local government lacked authority to make such rules. That decision is under appeal. The San Francisco legislation was pushed by a coalition of activists who cited potential risks to VDT operators, including repetitive strain injury, back and neck pain, deteriorating vision and miscarriage. Hsieh said the city charter prohibits supervisors from changing working conditions for city employees without studies by the Civil Service Commission. Jonathan Holtzman, special assistant in the city attorney's office, said the provision only applies to changes in pay, not safety measures. The law will affect an estimated 56,000 workers. In its first 30 months it will cost businesses about $14 million, said Paul Varacalli, executive director of Service Employees International Union Local 590, which backed the measure. He estimated the cost of bringing the city into compliance at $231,552. The 11-member Board of Supervisors is to vote next month on the compromise program of compliance. Under the program, new equipment would have to meet standards set in the ordinance after one year. For existing work stations, retrofitting costing less than $250 would have to be completed within 30 months. Retrofitting costing more than $250 would have to be completed within four years. The compromise was reached after business and labor officials said time constraints in the ordinance were unacceptable. ``We hope that careful administration of this ordinance provides something we all can live with,'' said Gwen Kaplan, president of the San Francisco Small Business Association. ``At best, it's a first step toward long-range solutions.'' Varacalli said the push to provide legal guarantees for VDT safety won't end in San Francisco. ``We know it cannot stop here. This is the beginning. We had to have a beginning,'' he said.

A transformer explosion and fire in Lower Manhattan delayed stock trading nationwide for 90 minutes, a reminder that Wall Street's sophisticated computer systems are vulnerable to unforeseen calamities. The trading halt on Thursday marked the third such disruption this year, but stock exchange representatives emphasized that none of the problems centered on their own computer operations. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Orders to manufacturers for ``big ticket'' durable goods plummeted 10.5 percent in November, the government said. The report likely signals more layoffs in the factory sector, which lost 200,000 jobs last month and more than 800,000 in the last two years. The drop in orders matched the post-1958 record falloff for one month, set in January of this year and reduced orders to a seasonally adjusted $115.9 billion, the lowest level since May 1988, the Commerce Department said. Also Thursday, the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., predicted that nationwide unemployment could hit 8 percent in the current downturn. The jobless rate rose to 5.9 percent last month. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Gasoline at the pumps has fallen nearly 9 cents a gallon since the week before Christmas, the biggest weekly drop in prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the American Automobile Association said. Self-serve unleaded cost $1.282 a gallon this week, according to an AAA survey of stations nationwide released Thursday. That's 8.9 cents lower than the price on Dec. 18, and the lowest since a gallon of gas cost $1.273 on Sept. 5. --- TOKYO (AP) - Eighteen directors of Mazda Motor Corp. are voluntarily taking temporary pay cuts to impress upon employees the seriousness of a government warning to pay stricter attention to car safety, the company said. ``In Japan, there is an old saying that superiors must suffer first in order to motivate workers,'' said Maza spokesman Tetsuo Nagase on Thursday. The pay cuts were decided after the Transport Ministry, investigating charges that Mazda has been replacing defective parts during routine maintenance, warned the company to pay stricter attention to safety. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The labor market continues to weaken, judged by the volume of help-wanted advertisements in newspapers around the country, the Conference Board reported. The Board on Thursday said ad volume declined last month in all nine major regions, with the Pacific, East North Central and Middle Atlantic regions posting the steepest drops. --- CHARLESTON, W.Va. (AP) - Coal is still king in West Virginia, but it's a monarchy where more and more subjects are opting for a new realm. West Virginia lost a higher percentage of residents than any other state, according to U.S. Census Bureau figures. A dip in the market in the mid-1980s, as well as the automation of the industry, were among factors in a mass exodus in the 1980s. According to U.S. Census Bureau figures released Wednesday, West Virginia's population was 1,801,625 this year, a 7.6 percent decline from the 1,949,644 counted in 1980. --- PHOENIX (AP) - Southwest Airlines is cutting fares between Phoenix and seven other cities to $20, during what is traditionally a slow time of year for the airline industry. The $20 fares are good for one-way tickets purchased before Jan. 21 for travel from Jan. 3 through April 5. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Food and Drug Administration says it will test raw milk weekly around the nation to determine if it contains certain antibiotics. The agency said on Thursday 250 locations across the country will be chosen for testing and raw milk samples will be collected each week from five of these sites, selected randomly. The samples will be tested for the presence of eight sulfa drugs and three tetracycline drugs. The FDA said that when residues are found, the states will be told and the agency will help track down the source. --- TOKYO (AP) - A legislator has been charged with evading more than $12 million in taxes on stock profits, prosecutors announced, a day after he resigned from the governing party. The case represents a new blow to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democrats party, which was discredited last year by a separate political scandal. Toshiyuki Inamura, 55, who served as a Liberal Democrat in the House of Representatives, was charged on Thursday with evading $12.7 million in taxes on profits of $20.8 million from stock dealings from 1986 to 1988, according to the Tokyo Public Prosecutors Office. ---

The stock market posted a moderate loss Thursday in a session shortened by problems that resulted from an overnight transformer explosion. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.63 points to 2,625.50. Bonds were moderately higher. The dollar settled lower as gold prices eased. Crude oil futures fell slightly, unleaded gasoline prices rallied, grain and soybean futures prices retreated, wheat futures fell, orange juice futures slipped and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda Says Pay Cut for Executives Shows Seriousness of Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen directors of Mazda Motor Corp. are voluntarily taking temporary pay cuts to impress upon employees the seriousness of a government warning to pay stricter attention to car safety. ``In Japan, there is an old saying that superiors must suffer first in order to motivate workers,'' Mazda spokesman Tetsuo Nagase said Thursday, explaining the action announced a day earlier. Mazda said Wednesday that Chairman Kenichi Yamamoto and 17 other directors would take a pay cut of 5 percent to 10 percent in the first three months of 1991 in connection with a recall of nearly 3,500 cars. The pay cuts were decided after the Transport Ministry, investigating charges that Mazda has been replacing defective parts during routine maintenance without recalling the cars or notifying the government, warned the company to pay stricter attention to safety. After the warning, Mazda notified the ministry Tuesday it would recall 3,498 Luce model passenger cars produced between Aug. 8, 1986, and Jan. 31, 1987, because of switch defects in their stop lights and cruise control mechanisms. Nagase said the directors' pay cut ``has a very symbolic meaning and employees will realize it. ... We believe cutting directors' salaries is a more effective way of having workers realize the importance of the matter than cutting workers' pay.'' He also said it would have been ``very un-Japanese'' to try to pinpoint an individual or department for blame. ``Pinpointing who is responsible and firing him would not solve the problem,'' Nagase said. Hajime Karatsu, a professor at the Research and Development Institute of Tokai University, said that whenever something goes wrong for Japanese corporations, the first move is for directors to take salary cuts. In extreme cases, business and political leaders offer their resignations. In a recent example, the chairman of Sumitomo Bank stepped down to take responsibility for illegal loans allegedly arranged by a branch manager for stock manipulation. ``All the responsibility should be placed with managers, that's the way of thinking in Japan,'' Karatsu said. He said actions such as executive pay cuts were a modern form of ``hara-kiri,'' the ritual suicide by disembowelment practiced by high-ranking Japanese to avoid disgrace. But spokesman Nagase said Mazda did not view the government warning as a matter for which the company needed to take responsibility. He said Mazda broke no laws and violated no regulations. ``We and our president have acknowledged that our judgment was a bit shortsighted,'' he said. He said company officials told the ministry that Mazda will try to streamline its quality check systems.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Ends Year With Unusual Drop
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today as share prices finished lower on the year's final trading day at the stock exchange. The Tokyo stock market has customarily ended the year on a rally, said Keiji Arai of Sanyo Securities. ``We are closing the year still suffering from the aftereffects of the big stock market plunge this year,'' he said. The dollar closed at 136.05 yen, down 0.60 yen from Thursday's close of 136.65 yen. After opening at 136.35 yen, it ranged from 135.80 yen to 136.63 yen. Spot trading totaled $5.5 billion, down from the preceding day's $6.019 billion. The Tokyo foreign exchange will close next Monday for the New Year holiday and reopen Jan. 4. Dealers said trading was sluggish with no new market-affecting factors. Importers finished buying the dollar for year-end settlements, which had helped push the dollar up recently, said Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer at the Bank of Tokyo. The dollar had also strengthened on news of political instability in the Soviet Union and continuing conflict in the Middle East, rising 3.62 yen in the previous six trading days. On the stock market, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,848.71 points, down 91.99 points or 0.38 percent from Thursday's finish at 23,940.70 points. Volume on the first section was estimated at a thin 180 million shares. Investors were reluctant to take risks before the exchange closes for a six-day holiday, while international conditions remained unstable, Arai said. After today's half-day session, the exchange will be closed until Jan. 4 for the year-end and New Year holiday. The Nikkei index dipped nearly 50 percent over the summer months, since closing at 38,915.87 points Dec. 29, the final trading day of 1989. Trading for 1990 started Jan. 4 with the index closing at 38,712.88 points, and the Nikkei never closed higher. The index hit the year's record-low close of 20,221.86 points on Oct. 1. Traders said the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait set the stock index tumbling, as investors became nervous about the Japanese economy. Japan is heavily dependent on imported oil, most of which comes from the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Indicators Drop 1.2 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 9 grafs new with market reaction, additional comment, picking up 7th pvs, bgng: Pulling the; CORRECTS 9th graf pvs, bgng: The various, to make it worst series of declines since 1981, sted 1980
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge dropped for the fifth consecutive month in November, the government said today in a report that offered little hope the slumping economy would recover soon. The 1.2 percent plunge in the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators followed an even worse 1.3 percent drop in October. That decline, revised from a previous estimate of 1.2 percent, was the worst since November 1987. The latest steep drop follows a spate of gloomy economic news for the month, including a jump in the unemployment rate and plunging orders for ``big ticket'' durable goods such as automobiles and appliances. It was seen as a sign the economy would continue to deteriorate. ``I think it's consistent with the other evidence that the recession is clearly in place and clearly has further to go,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. Stock prices slipped this morning in early trading following the release of the report. ``The November indicators leave no doubt that a serious and lengthy recession is under way,'' said economist William K. MacReynolds of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``The only remaining questions are just how far the economy will plummet and how long it will stay there.'' Three consecutive declines in the index - designed to predict economic activity six to nine months in advance - are considered a fairly good, but not infallible, sign a recession is approaching. The index rose slightly as recently as June, but most private economists believe the nation has already toppled into a recession. In November, eight of the 11 forward-looking components of the index fell. Pulling the index down, in order of importance, were: a decline in new orders to factories for consumer goods, a drop in prices of raw materials, a decline in the backlog of unfilled orders at factories, a fall in new orders for business investment equipment, a jump in new claims for unemployment benefits, a decline in the average workweek, a contraction in the inflation-adjusted money supply and a drop in building permits. The only positive contributors were an increase in stock prices, a slowing in business delivery times and a slight improvement in consumer confidence following a plunge after Iraq's August invasion of Kuwait. The various changes left the index at 139.7 percent of its 1982 base of 100, down 4.4 percent from its 146.2 peak in June. It has been the worst multiple-month retreat by the index since 1981, at the start of the last recession. The consensus of most analysts so far is that the current economic contraction will be a relatively mild one, shorter and less harsh than the 16-month 1981-82 recession, which was the worst since the Great Depression. An outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf could change that by sending oil prices soaring again, thus squelching any tendency for the economy to start growing again. The Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a consensus forecast of 52 top economists, says the economy already is in a recession. On average, it expects th gross national product to decline 1.3 percent in the September-December quarter and an additional 0.9 percent during the first three months of 1991. A recession is usually defined as at least two consecutive quarters of contraction. The forecasters predict the economy will begin growing again in the second quarter next year. However, a significant minority of analysts say the nation is heading for a protracted and deep recession. They were further discouraged Thursday when the Commerce Department reported new orders for durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in November. That matched the sharpest decline on record, set last January, and depressed orders to the lowest level in 2{ years. ``I'm in the pessimistic camp. I think this recession will be one of the longer ones in the post-World War II period,'' said economist Sung Won Sohn of Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis. Sohn said the drop in orders means that factory payrolls, which have declined by 800,000 jobs since January 1989 - 200,000 in November alone - will shrink further. Rep. Lee Hamilton, chairman of the congressional Joint Economic Committee, predicted Thursday that the nation's unemployment rate could rise to nearly 8 percent from the current 5.9 percent. That's about 1.5 percentage points worse than most private analysts are expecting. ``We will, in fact, have a recession,'' Hamilton, D-Ind., said in his 1991 outlook. He based his jobless rate forecast on average increases in unemployment in downturns since World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Orion To Hand Over Profits From `Mermaids'
DOC.TEXT: Orion Pictures Corp. agreed to give its majority shareholder a cut of profits from the movie ``Mermaids'' in return for a $23 million investment. Shareholder John W. Kluge and his partner Stuart Subotnick, executive vice president of Kluge's Metromedia Co., will receive up to 64 percent of certain profits from the movie, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition, the filing indicates the pair may receive certain profits from Orion's next scheduled release, ``The Silence of the Lambs,'' should receipts from ``Mermaids'' prove disappointing. The romantic comedy starring Cher and Winona Ryder grossed $8.3 million over the Christmas holiday weekend. An Orion spokeswoman would not comment Thursday on the $23 million investment - in the form of a joint venture called MetMermaids - saying she could not reach top executives for an explanation. Kluge holds about 70 percent of Orion shares. Orion recently retained the New York investment banking firm Salomon Bros. to find new sources of money.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Extend Losses In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were modestly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the previous session's losses on reduced fears of frost damage to the winter wheat crop. Most areas of the Midwest where soft red winter wheat is grown had adequate snow and ice cover to protect the crop from recent, bitterly cold weather, analysts said. DOC.HEAD: Barclays to Acquire Europeenne de Banque
DOC.TEXT: The French government has approved plans by Barclays Bank of Britain to acquire Europeenne de Banque for 1.5 billion francs, or $300 million, bank officials said in a joint release Friday. The British banking group will acquire 51 percent of Europeenne de Banque initially and will purchase the remaining 49 percent early next year, the statement said. A protocol agreement was reached earlier this month between Europeenne de Banque, a unit of Credit Commercial de France, and the French subsidiary of the Barclays group. The acquisition will give Barclays some prestigious real estate in central Paris, 16 branch offices throughout France and a financial distribution network through Europeenne de Banque's subsidiary Lafitte Investissement, which has 24 offices and a direct sales force operating as financial consultants. Barclays already has a French presence through its French subsidiaries Barclays Bank SA, Cie Financiere Barclays and its stock brokerage Puget-Mahe SA. CCF put Europeenne de Banque up for sale at the beginning of 1990. It announced in May that it was negotiating with the National Westminster banking group of Britain, but negotiations broke off two months ago. Barclays, which has a weaker French presence than National Westminster, its main British competitor, then stepped in with its offer. Europeenne de Banque reported consolidated net profit of 25 million francs, about $5 million, for the first half of 1990, down slightly from 28 million francs a year earlier. It had total assets of 13.78 billion francs, about $2.75 billion, at the end of 1989. Net profit for all of 1989 was 61.7 million francs, or $12.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines: Pilots' Absences To Cause Schedule Reductions, Layoffs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The APA...', to fix subject-verb agreement; adds one graf on end that details on cancellations, layoffs not decided yet. Name Lise is cq in 6th graf. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines Inc. says its pilots' unreliable attendance will force the nation's second-largest carrier to reduce its schedule by about 4 percent and lay off some employees. Meanwhile, the pilots union has told members to obey a temporary restraining order against the tactics that management alleges have caused delays and flight cancellations. The Allied Pilots Association has denied American's charges that pilots have been staging sickouts, taxiing slowly to waste fuel and filing frivolous requests for equipment maintenance. But a taped message from APA president Fred Vogel on Thursday advised pilots not to employ ``supposedly contrived slowdown devices,'' or to call in sick if they are not ill, The Dallas Morning News reported. The APA, which represents the Fort Worth-based carrier's 8,700 pilots, has been in contract talks since October 1989. The old contract expired Jan. 1, 1990. American spokeswoman Lise Olson said typically 300 pilots will call in sick on a given day, but since Dec. 21 more than 500 a day have been out sick. Some 250 pilots are over in Saudi Arabia for Operation Desert Shield, and that compounds the problem, she added. The temporary restraining order came late Wednesday from U.S. District Judge John McBryde barring pilots from actions designed to influence contract negotiations. The union said it will challenge the ruling, which it called a ``rush to judgment.'' Vogel, an American pilot, raised concerns that management ``may use the order in a way that will impair safe operations.'' The message told union members: ``The responsibility for safe operation of the aircraft is yours, and neither the company nor the court will help you if there is an incident in which you say you were influenced by the court's order.'' American spokesman Tim Smith denied Thursday that pilots would be jeopardizing air safety by obeying the judge's order. ``Nobody is asking anyone to compromise safety, and I don't think anyone has compromised safety,'' Smith said. ``We're talking about unnecessary safety or mechanical write-ups that were not borne out in fact.'' McBryde set a Jan. 3 hearing date to determine whether the temporary injunction should be made permanent. By late Thursday, 24 flights were canceled, 13 of them crew-related, Smith said. Since Sunday, 352 flights have been canceled, including 78 that were crew-related. The airline handles about 2,300 flights per day. Smith said decisions on what flights would be reduced and who would be laid off will not be made until next month. The airline will seek to cut flights from areas with the least demand, he said, and passengers booked on those flights will be notified in advance.

DOC.HEAD: Bonds, the Glitzy Investment in a Recession
DOC.TEXT: With recession on most economists' calendars for the first half of 1991, the outlook for bonds is good. U.S. Treasury bonds, the safest investment available, historically do well in recessions as the stock market, real estate and other investments appear at their riskiest. Economists forecast rallying bond prices will push the yield for the 30-year Treasury bond down to around 7.5 percent in 1991. The benchmark bond has been yielding around 8.30 percent in recent days and was above 9 percent as recently as early October. The bond market has been rallying since the Federal Reserve early last month signaled it was ready to lower interest rates to increase economic activity. The Fed cut its target for the federal funds rate three times in December -in 0.25 percentage point increments - to 7 percent. The central bank also lowered the discount rate by 0.50 percentage point to 6.5 percent. The fed funds rate is the overnight loan rate between banks. The discount rate is the Fed's loan fee to banks. Two factors could strongly affect bond prices and their yields. The Persian Gulf crisis continues to be unpredictable and Federal Reserve policy as always will influence bond yields. There is strong pressure from Washington for the Fed to ease more aggressively. However, some on Wall Street are concerned that lowering interest rates too much would cause more inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities like bonds. ``If the Fed moves too quickly inflation expectations could rise,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Co. As it has thus far, the Fed should take its cue from the bond market and gold prices, according to Kudlow. Falling gold prices and rising bond prices should precede another Fed easing move, he said. Kudlow expects long-term bond yields to fall to 7.60 percent by mid-year and fluctuate around there for the rest of the year. John Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service Inc., expects long-term interest rates could fall to 7.35 percent if core inflation - excluding food and energy - is significantly reduced. ``Increased government borrowing will put pressure on bond yields, but cutbacks in private sector borrowing will ensure an adequate amount of funds,'' he said. Also, banks and others will put more money in Treasury securities. The safety of Treasury bills, notes and bonds historically attracts investors wary of the risks inherent to investing in a recession. Treasury securities are seen as extremely safe because they are backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government. If the federal government couldn't pay its debts, money wouldn't be of much use because the economy would be in shambles. Corporate bond prices are expected to follow Treasury bonds. The fortunes of corporate borrowers, and their ability to repay debt, will be helped if interest rates go lower. ``The corporate market is basically trying to determine the outlook for profits, cash flows and credit worthiness - there's nothing better than lower interest rates,'' Kudlow said. Junk bonds will probably still be in the dumper in the coming year. In 1990, $22 billion in corporate bonds - issued by 91 companies -defaulted, according to preliminary numbers compiled by the Bond Investors Association. In 1991, the non-profit group that tracks bond defaults expects $25 billion worth of corporate debt to default. The recession, combined with the absence of demand for new issues of junk bonds, is causing the spiraling default rates, said C. Richard Lehmann, BIA president. Before the collapse of the junk bond market, issuers could avoid default and restructure their debt by floating new bonds. Now that junk bond buyers have all but disappeared, that option has been removed. The trend lately has been for issuers to give up equity to bondholders to entice them to agree to a restructuring. Some investors, most notably TWA Chairman Carl C. Icahn, have been selectively buying junk bonds with hopes of picking up a profit in a debt-for-equity swap.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Denies Bail for Former Vernon Owner
DOC.TEXT: Former Vernon Savings Association owner Don R. Dixon will remain in jail until his February sentencing on bank fraud charges, a federal magistrate ruled Friday. Dixon has been jailed without bond since his conviction Dec. 20 on 23 bank fraud charges. Attorneys asked U.S. Magistrate John Tolle to release Dixon Friday pending sentencing on Feb. 19. Eighteen witnesses testified on Dixon's behalf, including his wife and former minister. But the judge said the testimony did not refute government evidence that the former Vernon owner was likely to flee. After Dixon's conviction, federal prosecutors asked that he be jailed without bail because FBI investigators suspect he has money stashed in foreign bank accounts and might flee the country. Dixon, dressed in an orange jail uniform, listened quietly during the ruling. In the court papers, Dixon said he is ``not, under any circumstances, likely to flee.'' Among the paperwork submitted on his behalf were 81 letters from relatives, friends and business associates. One of the letters was from Dixon's 6-year-old granddaughter. Written in her first-grade scrawl, it reads: ``Dear Judge. Can Big Daddy get out of jail. He will not leave town. Love, Candice.'' Deborah Goodall, an attorney for Dixon, said the defense sought to prove that Dixon is not a flight risk. She said the letters submitted to the court show that Dixon has ``a long, solid history of facing his problems rather than avoiding them.'' Dixon said he needs to be free until sentencing so he can ``implement a family survival plan based on the probability I will be incarcerated for some considerable time.'' Vernon Savings failed in 1987, and its bailout is expected to cost taxpayers more than $1.2 billion. Dixon and his wife, Dana, declared personal bankruptcy in 1987, and Dixon said he has no money or other financial resources of any consequence. He has supported his wife, three of his eight children and his mother-in-law for the past two years, he said, with about $9,000 a month that he has borrowed from relatives and other sources and earned as an independent financial consultant.

DOC.HEAD: Pam Am Awaits Icahn's Next Move
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped Pan Am said Friday it has had no word from TWA owner Carl Icahn on whether his takeover proposal still stands and whether the ouster of Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett was a condition for the deal. Officials at Trans World Airlines' suburban Mount Kisco, N.Y., offices did not return several phone calls seeking confirmation that Plaskett's removal was on a list of terms attached to a proposed merger of the two carriers. That caveat was cited by unidentified sources quoted in Friday's editions of the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times. Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said that while the proposal to remove Plaskett ``has not been forthcoming from Mr. Icahn, Mr. Plaskett will do whatever is in the best interest of Pan Am and its shareholders.'' That presumably does not preclude stepping down from the executive suite. The Journal said Icahn was understood to lack confidence in Plaskett's management abilities. Plaskett, who once led an investor group on an abortive attempt to acquire Northwest Airlines' parent NWA Inc., has been trying to sell off Pan Am assets to raise cash to keep the carrier alive. The marriage maneuvering between TWA and Pan Am is the latest sign of how a declining U.S. economy and a sharp rise in jet fuel prices since the Persian Gulf crisis last August have severely hurt the airline industry, especially financially weak carriers such as TWA and Pan Am. Both airlines pioneered overseas travel and were once leading international competitors but are now scrambling to retrench and shrink - to the benefit of healthier airlines. Pan Am already has sold some of its most attractive European routes to United Airlines, while TWA has done the same in a deal with American Airlines. Icahn earlier this month suggested he would be willing to acquire Pan Am for $225 million in cash and $150 million in debt securities. But he has yet to present Pan Am with a formal proposal. Apparently there was some confusion over when exactly Icahn would unveil his merger plan to Pan Am. Bickering erupted after Icahn claimed Pan Am canceled a meeting last Monday; Pan Am countered that no meeting had been scheduled. Part of Icahn's proposal is understood to require Pan Am to seek Chapter 11 protection from creditors in order to receive a large loan to carry it until the merger with TWA is consummated. Pan Am disagrees with that approach. ``The company is opposed to entering into an agreement with Mr. Icahn that has as a condition the company filing Chapter 11,'' Hanlon said. The newspaper reports said Icahn would replace Plaskett with Pan Am's chief financial officer, Richard Francis, who has been negotiating with the TWA chief. The carrier's general counsel, Roger Cooke, also would be retained, the published accounts said. Plaskett is not believed to have been directly involved in the talks with the Icahn team. While acquirers often replace managers once a deal is completed, it's less typical for personnel issues to surface so early in negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Fees for Underwriting Stocks and Bonds Hit Six-Year-Low
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Fees earned on Wall Street for underwriting corporate stocks and bonds plunged in 1990 to a six-year low, providing further statistical evidence that the booming 1980s have died. Combined with a sharp drop in other critical investment banking activity and thousands of layoffs, analysts said the figures released Friday signal losses at many securities firms for the year. ``It's definitely meaning weaker profitability for all the firms, even historically strong ones,'' said Mara Hilderman, a senior analyst with Moody's Investors Service. Investment banking fees from new issues of stocks and bonds plunged 38 percent to $1.93 billion from $3.09 billion in 1989, Securities Data Co. reported. The figure was the lowest since $1.41 billion in 1984, before Wall Street's three-year surge. Despite the decline, overall new issues reached a record $312 billion, up from $309 million last year, said Securities Data, a Newark, N.J.-based firm that compiles Wall Street statistics. But securities industry experts said the total masked a fundamental malaise in corporate America and on Wall Street. Other figures showed that a late-1990 decline had begun to set in, due to the slumping economy and Middle East crisis. IDD Information Services Inc., another Wall Street data firm, said total domestic underwriting volume in the fourth quarter of 1990 declined sharply from the same 1989 period. ``We're in a market that's in a doldrums,'' said Samuel B. Hayes III, an investment banking professor at the Harvard Business School. ``For corporations, the prospect of selling stock at this point looks as though it's very expensive money.'' Securities Data said the total volume of common stock issued fell 16 percent to $19.2 billion in 1990, while initial public offerings of stock tumbled 26 percent to $13.7 billion. Those figures reflect companies' diminished ability and desire to raise money by selling shares to the public. Hayes said that as stock prices dropped in 1990, corporations balked at selling what would have amounted to cheap shares. Wall Street firms serve as intermediaries for stock and bond offerings. They acquire the securities from companies and then resell them to the public, charging a fee for the service. Raising money by offering debt in the form of corporate bonds rose by 3.6 percent in 1990 to $282.5 billion, IDD reported, but several key component areas fell, including straight debt and junk bonds. The market for risky high-yield bonds dried up, with just 10 junk bond offerings totaling $1.3 billion in 1990, compared to 25 issues totaling $25.3 billion in 1989, IDD said. Despite the overall rise in total new issues, fees declined because of increased competition and the drop in common stock and junk bond underwriting, which historically has generated the largest fees, analysts said. More Japanese, German and Swiss investment firms are competing with domestic firms for U.S. deals. Also, the growth of practices such as ``shelf underwriting'' - in which a company opens the bidding among investment firms for a deal - have driven down fee commissions. ``There's just been an absolute compression on fees because of intense competition,'' Hilderman said. Not all of Wall Street's losses are due to the decline in underwriting fees. Other key areas for big investment banks also fell sharply in 1990, particularly mergers and acquisitions fees and takeover-stock speculation. Securities firms are cutting back to stanch losses. They are slashing payrolls, abandoning struggling business areas and focusing activities on money-producing areas, such as stock and bond trading. In the third quarter of 1990, New York Stock Exchange member firms lost $124 million. For the first nine months of the year, profits were just $22 million, compared with $1.28 billion the same year-ago period. Less than half of the 334 firms reporting were profitable, the NYSE said. Since peaking at 262,000 workers at the end of the September 1987, industrywide employment stood at 214,000 at the end of September this year, the Securities Industry Association said. Several thousand jobs in the last three months have pushed the employment decline over 5,000.
Stock prices were mixed today in a session dominated by talk of a worsening economic outlook. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 0.49 at 2,625.99.

DOC.HEAD: Some Seek Shiny Lining In Clouded Silver Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS December to January in 4th graf and CORRECTS week-earlier price to $4.038
DOC.TEXT: The lowest silver prices in nearly 15 years aren't stimulating much demand, but some analysts see modest gains for investors willing to wait. ``I'm not so sure we've seen the ultimate lows,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc. Nevertheless, investor buying during the last two weeks of 1990 helped lift the spot silver price on New York's Commodity Exchange back above $4 per troy ounce after it fell on Dec. 14 to $3.93, the lowest level since February 1976. Silver for January delivery settled Friday at $4.19 a troy ounce compared with $4.038 a week earlier. ``I think some large investors are taking a renewed look at silver at these low prices,'' said Research Analyst Joseph Rosta of CPM Group, a precious-metal research and consulting firm in New York. ``Silver prices are extremely low and I think that on the part of some major players in the market, there is a feeling that prices may be reaching a cyclical low,'' he said. Silver's value tumbled this year from more than $5 an ounce as the economy weakened. Sliding stock prices and slowing industrial output raised concerns about demand for silver from the electronics and jewelry industries, which together account for about 60 percent of silver consumption, and the photographic industry, which represents about 40 percent of silver demand. A general easing of inflation fears in the second half of the year prompted unloading of silver bullion by investors, who tend to buy precious metals as an inflation hedge. Domestic silver consumption in the coming year is generally expected to outpace the supply of newly mined and recycled silver but U.S. stockpiles are more than adequate to meet the demand. The Silver Institute, an industry trade group, estimates 1990 U.S. industrial consumption at 123 million troy ounces; the Commodity Exchange reported silver inventories of more than 265 million ounces as of Thursday. ``As long as we have Comex stocks representing well over two years of consumption, it is unlikely that we will have a sustainable rally in silver prices,'' said PaineWebber analyst Fred Demler. He said silver could test $3.80 an ounce in 1991 and he would not rule out the possibility of a slide to $3.50 ``on a very short-term basis.'' Rosta said he concurred with the Silver Institute's cautiously bullish long-range forecast for silver in the 1990s, which projects a 3 percent to 4 percent annual increase in silver demand versus a 2 percent rise in supply per annum. Demler agreed that silver has the potential to provide a decent return in the long run. ``For those looking to hold silver for five to 10 years, these are very attractive levels,'' he said. ``On the other hand, anyone who bought silver 10 or 15 years ago and held it has a loss on their hands at this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply on world currency markets Friday, with extremely thin trading accentuating the downward move. Gold prices staged a strong advance in domestic dealings, boosted by the weak dollar. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery jumped $8.60 to settle at $394 a troy ounce. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $393 an ounce, up $8.60. The dollar began declining in Asian trading and continued to fall when dealings shifted to Europe as investors took profits. Shortly before the U.S. market opened, ``the dollar fell hard across the board'' and was unable to stage a convincing recovery, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA. Traders received more negative news about the U.S. economy in a Commerce Department report showing that the Index of Leading Economic Indicators fell 1.2 percent in November, its fifth consecutive monthly decline. Normally three consecutive monthly declines indicate a recession is imminent. ``It was much below expectations,'' Chandler said of the figure. As the economy weakens, pressure builds on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to stimulate growth. But lower interest rates are bearish for the dollar because they erode the value of fixed-income investments like bonds. The sharp decline in the dollar came despite a political backdrop that would appear to support the currency. Tensions in the Persian Gulf as well as political strife in the Soviet Union might encourage investors to seek a safe haven in the dollar. Chandler maintained that the U.S. currency would trade still lower if not for these political developments. ``The full dimensions of the current economic contraction aren't being fully appreciated by the market,'' he said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 136.05 Japanese yen from 136.65 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it traded at 135.05 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 134.90 yen, down from 136.40 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9220 from $1.8870 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9282 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.8895. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4970 German marks, down from 1.5310; 1.2780 Swiss francs, down from 1.3090; 5.0930 French francs, down from 5.2050; 1.6890 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7292; 1,127.75 Italian lire, down from 1,152.75; and 1.1607 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1618. DOC.HEAD: Canadian Company Signs Contract for Nuclear Power Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT figure to $1 billion; SUBS lede, 5th grafs to note dollars are U.S.; SUBS 10th graf, The sale, to CORRECT 10 years to nine. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Canada's state-owned nuclear power company signed a $535 million (U.S.) contract Friday to build a nuclear power plant for Korea Electric Power Corp. The deal is a coup for the Canadian government and caps more than 10 years of sales efforts by its Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., or AECL. It will be the second Canadian reactor built in Korea. Officials said the 700,000-kilowatt power plant, estimated to cost a total of about $1 billion U.S., will be built in Wolsong, 160 miles southeast of Seoul. It will be built next to the first Canadian reactor, which has been operating since 1983. ``We're ecstatic,'' said William B. Schumacher, the Canadian ambassador to South Korea. ``A deal of this size has implications for bilateral relations. It opens up a basis for broadening even further the relationship.'' South Korea and Canada are each other's fifth-largest trading partners. Trade between the companies is expected to reach $4 billion (U.S.) in 1990. The Korean power company, or KEPCO, has nine nuclear power plants in operation and two more under construction. The government expects to have 50 nuclear plants in operation in the next 40 years. A nuclear reactor provides heat that converts water into steam. The steam is then fed from the reactor into a turbine system to convert into electricity. Schumacher said South Korea is the only country using two complementary kinds of nuclear reactors, a heavy-water reactor developed by Canada and the more commonly used pressure water reactors. The Canadian model uses natural uranium and heavy water. That means the so-called Candu reactor can use the spent fuel from pressure-water reactors, enabling Korea to reduce the amount of nuclear waste it generates, experts said. The sale should also prove beneficial to AECL. It is the company's first in nine years and could provide a boost to Canada's nuclear industry. A turbine generator for the new plant will be supplied by General Electric Co. along with Korea Heavy Industries and Construction Co. under a contract to be signed soon, officials said. AECL will receive about 60 percent of the total contract sum. Korean subcontractors will receive the other 40 percent for providing components and services, KEPCO said. Construction will begin next July and is scheduled to be completed by mid-1997. The contract was formally signed at a ceremony Friday by Ahn Byong-wha, president of KEPCO, and Dr. Stanley Hatcher of Toronto, president of AECL.

DOC.HEAD: The Bad News At-A-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief rundown of bad economic news over the past few weeks, which has contributed to the growing view that the economy is in recession:
DOC.HEAD: UNEMPLOYMENT
DOC.TEXT: The government reported Dec. 7 that joblessness, one of the most sensitive and widely followed measurements of economic health, surged to a three-year high of 5.9 percent in November, reflecting the worst stretch of layoffs since the 1981-82 recession. The areas hardest hit were in manufacturing but the cutbacks were spread throughout all segments of the economy.

The government reported Thursday that new orders for goods designed to last at least three years plunged 10.5 percent in November, equaling the record drop set last January. The drop in this key barometer intensified fears that thousands of additional workers will be laid off from manufacturing jobs.

The government reported Dec. 20 that consumer spending rose only 0.1 percent in November, historically one of the strongest months for spending as the Christmas holiday approaches. At the same time, the government said personal incomes increased only marginally, barely keeping pace with the inflation rate. Economists called the findings important evidence that the consumer is frightened and is clamping down on spending.

The government reported Dec. 19 that construction of single-family homes in November sank to its lowest level since 1982, reflecting a clampdown in mortgage lending by troubled banks fearful of getting stuck with more bad loans. The National Association of Realtors, a leading trade group, reported Dec. 26 that sales of existing homes rose 3 percent in November after two straight monthly declines, but economists said it was premature to draw any conclusions that the slump was easing.
DOC.HEAD: FAITH IN THE ECONOMY
DOC.TEXT: The Conference Board, a leading business research group, reported Thursday that its monthly survey of consumer confidence in the economy remained unchanged in December but still was much lower than a year earlier, hurt by fear of job security and the Persian Gulf crisis. At the same time, the board said its monthly survey of help-wanted advertising in newspapers plunged to a five-year low in November, suggesting that the demand for workers has fallen substantially.

The worst cold in decades froze much of the citrus and other crops in California, a critical supplier of the nation's fresh produce during the winter months. The devastation made it likely that consumers, already paying more for fuel because of the Persian Gulf crisis, would pay sharply higher prices for fruit and vegetables.

The government reported Friday its chief economic forecasting gauge plunged 1.2 percent in November, the fifth straight monthly drop, offering almost no hope the economy will revive soon. The Index of Leading Indicators, which measures the economic pulse in categories ranging from jobless claims to stock prices, is designed to predict the outlook six to nine months in advance.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Rises in Light, Rumor-Driven Trading
DOC.TEXT: Rumors of shots fired in the Middle East drove up the price of crude oil futures Friday in thin trading. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude for February delivery rose 56 cents to $27.57 per barrel. For the week, crude oil gained $1.65 a barrel. The Merc was closed on Monday and Tuesday for Christmas. Am abbreviated session is set for Monday and the market will be closed on New Year's Day. Traders said volume was light as many market participants refrained from trading at the end of the month and year, and because of an absence of significant news on the Persian Gulf crisis. Andrew Lebow, a senior broker with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said traders bought futures after a trading floor rumor that shots had been fired in the Iraq-U.S. standoff. Lebow said he believed the rumor resulted from confusion over reports that Iraq test fired a surface-to-surface missile for the second time this week. U.S. officials in Saudi Arabia said the missle was fired away from multinational forces and landed within Iraq. The approach of the United Nations' Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait has agitated the market. Oil prices are expected to surge if war breaks out because of reduced supplies from the Middle East. ``It's jittery,'' Lebow said. ``The closer we get (to Jan. 15) the more nervous people are going to get.'' In other developments Friday, a 17-ship carrier armada embarked to bring America's naval deployment in the region to a level unprecedented since the Vietnam war. Also, Saudi Arabia reportedly increased orders for jet fuel, interpreted by the oil market as a sign of war preparations. The first snowfall of the season in the Northeast failed to support the market for home heating oil, which has slumped because of recent warm weather. Home heating oil futures fell 1.10 cents to 79.79 cents per gallon on the Merc on contracts for January delivery after falling 0.38 cent on Thursday. Traders said forecasts of warm weather in the Northeast over the weekend pushed prices down. Later months were mostly higher. Unleaded regular gasoline for January delivery rose .92 cent to 69.56 cents a gallon after a 0.50-cent rise Thursday. Later months also were higher. Natural gas for February delivery was down 1.0 cent at $1.950 per 1,000 cubic feet. Later months were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Drop in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices staged a sharp retreat in light holiday trading Friday in response to war-like news about the Persian Gulf and a better-than-expected jobless report. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond dropped 21-32 point, or $6.56 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, rose to 8.30 percent from 8.24 percent late Thursday. The session was one of the most lightly traded of the holiday season, with many traders absent due to New York's first snowfall and to holiday vacations. Government securities markets closed at 3 p.m. instead of the usual 5:30 p.m. because of the inclement weather and the coming New Year's holiday. Market participants blamed much of the long bond's price drop on the release of a government report of better-than-expected unemployment figures. The Labor Department reported that claims for state unemployment insurance, on a seasonably adjusted basis, fell by 14,000 to 441,000 in the week ended Dec. 15 from 455,000 claims the week before. ``The figures were not as bad as had been the case,'' said Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Signs of economic upturn are generally viewed as negative by the government securities market because the Federal Reserve would be less likely to ease interest rates to stimulate the economy. Falling interest rates boost the value of existing bonds. However, the market was little moved by a Commerce Department report showing the Index of Leading Indicators fell 1.2 percent in November, the fifth consecutive monthly decline. Economists said many of the components of the index have already been reported. But the bond market was thrashed by several Persian Gulf developments that traders saw as heightening the prospects for war in the troubled region, thus raising fears of higher inflation. Analysts said the next important clue to how the economy was faring would come next Friday with the release of the government's monthly unemployment report. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were down 1-16 point to unchanged, intermediate maturities were down 5-32 point to 11-32 point, and long-term issues lost 19-32 point to 21-32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 2.59 to 1,180.74. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 6.62 percent as the discount dropped 5 basis points to 6.43 percent. Yields on six-month bills were down to 6.85 percent as the discount fell 4 basis points to 6.54 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 6.90 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points to 6.49 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 7{ percent, down from 10 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unchanged from late Thursday's 91\. The average yield to maturity also held steady at 7.47 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Consequences of GATT Breakup May Not Be Dire, Trade Specialists Say
DOC.TEXT: When talks at the world's major trade forum collapsed earlier this month, experts and headlines echoed each other in hand-wringing dismay over the loss of a chance to set visionary rules for the 21st century. But not all agree the consequences of a breakdown would be dire. A small but vocal group of experts argues that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is, at best, imbalanced. Further, some say, the world is becoming so economically interdependent that trade will increase exponentially in coming decades even without a broader agreement. ``We might end up having a thoroughly free trading world because it is imposed by economic realities rather than policy-makers and politicians,'' says world trade expert Dominick Salvatore of Fordham University in New York. Even without a GATT agreement, bilateral trade talks will continue. U.S. and Japanese negotiators, for example, have continued talks under the Structural Impediments Initiative, aimed at reducing internal barriers to trade in their countries. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter visited European Community counterpart Ray MacSharry a few weeks ago to discuss trade. The latest GATT talks, launched four years ago in Uruguay, were suspended Dec. 7 in Brussels after the United States and other agricultural exporters demanded deep cuts in agricultural subsidies - a politically explosive issue in the 12 EC nations and Japan, where farmers form strong political blocs. The talks aim to overhaul the world trade system by rewriting rules and lowering barriers in 15 areas, including textiles, agriculture, manufactured goods and services, such as banking, telecommunications and construction. U.S. negotiators hope that if developing nations gain markets for their food exports, they will in turn grant concessions in the newer areas the GATT doesn't cover: financial services, high technology and so-called ``intellectual property,'' such as patents and copyrights - all of which most analysts agree hold the highest potential for future growth in developed nations. When the 107-nation talks were halted, some feared the end of the pact credited with slashing barriers to trade. Since the GATT was signed in 1947, global trade has increased over five times in real terms to about $4 trillion in 1990. There is still hope for GATT. The talks could resume as early as January, and a deadline set by Congress of March 1, 1991, to vote on a world trade treaty can easily be extended two years at President Bush's request. ``The next two months will probably decide it,'' said Julius Katz, deputy United States Trade Representative. But Salvatore and others argue that the GATT is off-base, anyway. They say that the United States naively cajoles other nations to hold to fair trade principles, but those countries aren't even convinced laissez-faire capitalism is best for them. ``My concern is it's the wrong fight at the wrong place at the wrong time,'' Salvatore says. ``The future lies not in agriculture...It is in high technology.'' Even if GATT succeeds, it may not bring the huge trade flows negotiators are promising. Clyde V. Prestowitz and Robert W. Jerome, of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, disparage a U.S. estimate that a new GATT agreement could bring an extra $1 trillion in trade over the next decade. ``Bemoaning the fate of the Uruguay Round is kind of misplaced, because no matter what came out of that round, we (the United States) were going to have problems,'' says Prestowitz, president of E.S.I. Prestowitz and Jerome say that under the current system the more liberal trading nations lose. Under current ``national treatment'' and ``most-favored-nation'' rules, a GATT country must treat other members the same way it treats businesses at home. No matter how restrictive a country's home policies, it can take advantage of more liberal members' internal rules, say Jerome and Prestowitz. Prestowitz, a former U.S. Commerce Department official, cites European government backing for the Airbus airliner. ``The Europeans have been pursuing development of the Airbus for 20 years, subsidized to the tune of about $28 billion,'' he says. ``We're not losing market share because our planes are bad or our prices too high. ... We're losing it because we're being outsubsidized.''

DOC.HEAD: IBM Plans Australian Network Hub
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. announced plans Friday to establish a major telecommunications networking hub for the Asia-Pacific region in Australia. The move would see IBM double its existing Sydney-based networking capacity over the next two years. IBM's branch manager, Hilton McKeener, said the decision emphasized the computer company's confidence in Australia as a major regional center for investment. Regional hubs provide a secure and cost-effective way for international companies to channel their business data, computer communications and telephone traffic throughout a region and around the world. IBM's decision to place the hub in Australia has been claimed as a coup by Australia's government-owned worldwide communications company, OTC Limited. OTC has secured hub contracts for Australia with about 100 companies, including MasterCard and Bankers Trust.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Dec. 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported Friday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,323.4 billion from $3,318.8 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,093.2 billion from $4,088.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $823.9 billion from $820.7 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 3.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.6 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,318.8 billion, a 2.3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,087.2 billion, up 0.2 percent, while M1 rose 3.9 percent to an average of $821.8 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $830 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $133 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.2 billion in the two-week period ended Dec. 12, down from $319.9 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.TEXT: Some late buying of blue chips enabled the stock market to finish mixed Friday in a session dominated by worries about the prospective length and severity of the economic slump. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down more than 10 points in the early going, closed with a 3.71 gain at 2,629.21. That trimmed the average's loss for the holiday-shortened week to 4.45 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 712 up, 800 down and 511 unchanged. The government reported Friday morning that its chief gauge of future economic activity dropped for the fifth consecutive month in November. The 1.2 percent decline in the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators followed a 1.3 percent drop in October. Three or more consecutive declines in the index, which is designed to predict economic activity six to nine months in advance, are considered a strong sign of an impending recession. On Thursday, Commerce said new orders for durable goods tumbled 10.5 percent last month. Confronted with such data, many economists have lately been cutting their forecasts for growth and profits at least through the early stages of 1991. With one session left in 1990, the Dow Jones industrial average shows a net loss of 123.99 points, or 4.5 percent, since New Year's. Gainers among the blue chips included DuPont, up \ at 36}; General Motors, up [ at 34{; General Electric, up [ at 57], and McDonald's, up \ at 28}. But American Telephone & Telegraph dipped [ to 30 and International Business Machines was down \ at 113]. Bank stocks, one of 1990's poorest-performing groups, finished mostly lower. Citicorp dropped \ to 12}; J.P. Morgan \ to 43}; Manufacturers Hanover ~ to 21~, and BankAmerica { to 26. Precious-metals stocks rose, by contrast, as the gold market showed some yearend strength. Gold futures for January delivery climbed $8.60 an ounce to $394 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Homestake Mining added 1\ to 18|; Battle Mountain Gold { to 6~; ASA Ltd. 1~ to 45{, and Newmont Gold 2\ to 40|. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 111.04 million shares, against 102.90 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 145.77 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $3.06 billion, or 0.10 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .17 to 179.65. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.89 to 385.26, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 0.43 at 328.72. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market edged up .15 to 371.20. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 304.65, up .98.

For Release Monday Dec. 31
DOC.HEAD: After a Down Christmas, What's Ahead for Retailers?
DOC.TEXT: The difficult Christmas season has ended, but many of the nation's retailers are finding it hard to breathe a sigh of relief. With the outlook poor for consumer spending in the first half of 1991, many still have tough sledding ahead. As a result, retailers are retrenching, paring inventories and expenses and in some cases, closing stores. Others, in financial distress, are expected to seek refuge in bankruptcy courts. ``It's going to be terrible,'' was the way Daniel Barry, a Kidder, Peabody & Co. industry analyst, summed up the outlook. The Christmas season, when retailers hope to make half their annual profits, was disappointing as consumers put fears about the economy and the Middle East ahead of holiday sentimentality. The nation's biggest retailers will report sales for the month of December on Thursday, but several already have said it was a dismal or at best trying season. Many economists predict consumers will spend cautiously well into 1991 as the recession continues. That means Americans will limit what is called discretionary spending - outlays for non-essentials such as toys, furniture, appliances, even clothing. With retailers dependent on such expenditures, a further slowdown is expected to be devastating for 1991 earnings. Thomas J. Tashjian, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles, predicted overall industry profits would fall about 30 percent in the first quarter and 15 percent the second quarter. Even before Christmas, retailers were taking steps to reduce inventories, and many have said they are trying to keep merchandise levels tight going into the new year. ``We will continue to plan very conservatively,'' Kenneth Macke, chairman of Dayton Hudson Corp., said last week. Macke reported his Christmas sales were unchanged to 1 percent higher than a year earlier, a disappointing performance. Retailers, especially apparel merchants, will be taking fewer chances in 1991. ``They're going to choose very carefully things to sell,'' said Walter Loeb, a retail analyst and consultant. ``They're going to buy classic clothes which are safe.'' Some companies are taking more drastic steps. One retailer, Younkers Inc., which owns 34 department stores in five midwestern states, announced last week it was closing three small, marginally profitable stores in Nebraska. ``It's just a sound business decision,'' company president Thomas Gould said. Others, including such big names as R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. and Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., have already sold extra stock or some of their stores to try to reduce their debt loads. Macy got a $119 million cash infusin from a sale of stock earlier this month and has been buying back some of its junk bonds. Macy, which had a disastrous Christmas a year ago and has been under pressure to reduce its multi-billion-dollar liabilities, fared better this holiday season, according to a source familiar with the retailer's results. Macy's sales ``volume was not good in comparison to last year or to others in the recent past'' but because of lower inventories and reduced expenses, ``our margins this Christmas were well above a year ago,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Carter Hawley Hale, which operates department stores in California and the West, recently sold its Thalhimer Brothers division in the Southeast to reduce its debt. The company lost $14.9 million in its first quarter, which ended in November, after losing $26 million the previous fiscal year. For some retailers, the recession will mean more business. Storeowners who can offer consumers the lowest prices should do well, said Tashjian. Close-out retailers such as Pic 'N' Save Corp., who buy manufacturers' overstock and sell the goods at a steep discount, and discount retailers such as Wal-Mart Stores Inc. are likely to fare better than competitors, Tashjian said. Wal-Mart's sales gains consistently outpace those of other discounters because its distribution system is more modern and efficient, Tashjian said, adding, ``The company is in a position to have better pricing and still be profitable.'' Wal-Mart said last week it was pleased with Christmas results, but the company found it difficult to draw customers. Some retailers are beginning the new year in bankruptcy court. On Friday, Youthland Inc., a Columbus, Ohio-based chain of 26 children's clothing stores, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The retailer said it had lost money for seven consecutive quarters and blamed the losses on a heavy debt load, poor locations for its stores and the economy. Analysts expect other bankruptcies, largely among smaller, privately-held retailers and companies that are overburdened by debt. ``There'll be hundreds of little firms that go out of business that you'll never hear about,'' Barry said. Retail capital spending may also be a victim of the business slowdown. With less money available from banks, fewer shopping malls will be developed, Loeb predicted. But at Dayton Hudson, no major changes are planned in the company's capital spending plan, Macke said. Macke said he was looking pessimistically at business for the first part of 1991, noting that consumers traditionally spend more at Christmas than any other time of the year.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Report on 1989 Mini-Crash Calls for Tighter Specialist Standards
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a report on the October 1989 market drop, called on the nation's two major stock exchanges Friday to tighten performance standards for professionals who regulate trading flow. The SEC said the New York and American stock exchanges performed well overall during the 190-point tumble in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Oct. 13, 1989, and a subsequent sharp rise on Oct. 16. But the report cited several problems in the handling of trading on the exchanges and at the automated National Association of Securities Dealers system and called for several revisions in how trading is regulated. The SEC's division of market regulation said some exchange floor market makers, known in the industry as specialists, failed to perform adequately during the volatile trading, and said the exchanges should review performances and take ``appropriate remedial action.'' Specialists generally match up buyers and sellers of stock, but are required to correct imbalances by making purchases or sales from their own supplies when necessary to maintain fair and orderly markets. The SEC report said the exchanges should use their authority to reallocate stocks when they determine that specialists display a ``substantial or continued failure'' to maintain orderly markets during volatile times. It also said the NYSE, Amex and regional stock exchanges should consider developing capital levels for specialists based on individual stocks. Specialists are required to ``make markets'' for trading of particular stocks. The Amex said in a statement that it continually reviews specialists' performance, did so for the October 1989 market drop and ``has taken appropriate action where warranted.'' ``However, we believe that overall our specialists performed exceptionally well during this difficult period,'' the statement said. An NYSE spokesman could not be reached for comment. The exchange in the past has ardently defended its market-making system, saying specialists helped prevent financial catastrophe during the 1987 and 1989 market declines. With regard to the options markets, the SEC report recommended improving procedures for halting and reopening the trading of options contracts linked to indexes of stocks during times of extreme price movements. The report also was critical of the NASD's over-the-counter market, saying that some market makers withdrew from trading during the drop. But it said the over-the-counter market in general performed well. Overall, the SEC said the markets performed better during the October 1989 mini-crash than during the October 1987 crash, partly due to safeguards implemented after the 508-point drop in the Dow Jones average. The report was the second part of the SEC's analysis of the 1989 market slide. In June, the SEC concluded that the drop was accelerated by index arbitrage and other computerized program trading strategies. That report was criticized by other agencies and many Wall Street officials.

The government's chief economic forecasting gauge dropped again in November for the fifth consecutive monthly decline, the government said in a report that offered little hope the slumping economy would recover soon. The 1.2 percent plunge in the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, reported Friday, followed an even worse 1.3 percent drop in October. That decline was the worst since November 1987. The steep drop follows a spate of gloomy economic news for the month and was seen as a sign the economy would continue to deteriorate. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Cash-strapped Pan Am said it has had no word from TWA owner Carl Icahn on whether his takeover proposal still stands and whether the ouster of Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett was a condition for the deal. Unidentified sources quoted in Friday's editions of the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times said Plaskett's removal was on a list of terms attached to a proposed merger of the two carriers. Officials at Trans World Airlines' suburban Mount Kisco, N.Y., offices did not return several phone calls seeking confirmation of that caveat. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Fees earned on Wall Street for underwriting corporate stocks and bonds plunged in 1990 to a six-year low, providing further statistical evidence that the booming 1980s have died. Investment banking fees from new issues of stocks and bonds plunged 38 percent to $1.93 billion from $3.09 billion in 1989, Securities Data Co. reported Friday. Combined with a sharp drop in other critical investment banking activity and thousands of layoffs, analysts said the figures signal losses at many securities firms for the year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A Supreme Court justice refused to block the $7.4 billion purchase of movie-making MCA Inc. by Japan's largest electronics company. Justice Antonin Scalia on Friday rejected an emergency request by Go-Video Inc. to block consummation of the deal set for Saturday. Go-Video sought a postponement until a formal antitrust challenge could be mounted. The deal by giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. will be the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. company. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - ``Keating Five'' Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. is asking the Treasury Department to study the condition of the insurance industry, warning that the nation cannot afford to ignore the development of problems similar to the savings and loan debacle. Riegle, D-Mich., who chairs the Senate Banking Committee asked the Treasury Department to examine whether insurance companies have made too many risky investments and to estimate the risk to the economy of a major insurance company failure. Riegle made the requests in a letter dated Dec. 20 and released Thursday. --- PARIS (AP) - The French government has approved plans by Barclays Bank of Britain to acquire Europeenne de Banque for 1.5 billion francs, or $300 million, bank officials said in a joint release. The British banking group will acquire 51 percent of Europeenne de Banque initially and purchase the remaining 49 percent early next year, Friday's statement said. The acquisition will give Barclays some prestigious real estate in central Paris, 16 branch offices throughout France and a financial distribution network through Europeenne de Banque's subsidiary Lafitte Investissement. --- SEOUL, South Korea (AP) - Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a $535 million (U.S.) contract to build a nuclear power plant for Korea Electric Power Corp. Friday's deal is a coup for the Canadian government and caps more than 10 years of sales efforts by its Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., or AECL. It will be the second Canadian reactor built in Korea. --- WHEELING, W.Va. (AP) - Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. says it will take a $170 million one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings to adjust for retiree health benefits. DOC.HEAD: Wheeling-Pitt Announces Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs after 6th pvs, The change, to UPDATE with delay in bankruptcy proceedings; EDITS to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. on Friday said it would take a $170 million one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings to adjust for retiree health benefits. The charge includes $74 million in major medical insurance benefits for retirees granted in a labor contract signed Dec. 19, spokesman Ray Thompson said. It also includes $96 million for changes in retirees' medical and life insurance benefits to update previous estimates of health coveage, the company said in a news release. Wheeling-Pitt said the charge was required to show the company's expectations of medical costs and to reflect accounting changes. The Financial Accounting Standards Board recently approved a new rule, effective in 1993, that requires companies to subtract from earnings a portion of the costs of benefits they have promised to future retirees. The change is designed to give investors and others a more accurate picture of a company's health by better stating what its long-range obligations to retirees will be. Meanwhile Friday, the company said a federal judge in Pittsburgh had granted a temporary stay delaying the company's emergence from bankruptcy protection. The stay was requested by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, the Economic Development Administration and Farmers Home Administration. Wheeling-Pitt sought bankruptcy protection in 1985, and its reorganization plan had been approved Dec. 18 by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court. A hearing on the stay was scheduled for Jan. 3. Wheeling-Pitt, the nation's 10th-largest steel producer, employs about 7,100 workers at six plants in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia.
