DOC.HEAD: Western Union Says Its Debt Restructuring Appears Successful
DOC.TEXT: EWraps Up Recapitalization Offer

Western Union Corp., the communications pioneer that has foundered because of heavy debts, said Friday it was close to alleviating a substantial part of its obligations. The company said enough bondholders appeared to have accepted its offer to exchange high-yield ``junk bond'' debt securities for 50 cents on the dollar. The announcement suggested the company has avoided a cash crisis. There had been persistent speculation that Western Union could have been forced into bankruptcy-court refuge because of its debts. When the exchange offer expired midnight Thursday, preliminary figures indicated that $328.6 million of the debt securites, which paid 19\ percent interest, and $5.9 million of securities, which paid 16 percent interest, had been exchanged for the cash, company spokesman Warren Bechtel said. Western Union had offered to make the exchange for up to $350 million worth of these securities. A minimum of $250 million of the 19\ percent notes had to be tendered for the proposal to go through, Bechtel said. The apparent success of the offer would mark the end of a grueling five-month ordeal for Western Union, which has been struggling to satisfy bondholders afraid they wouldn't get repaid. The company, based in Saddle River, N.J. originally had proposed exchanging $530 million of high-yield notes for lower-yield notes plus stock. After numerous deadline extensions for acceptance of that offer, Western Union realized it wouldn't be accepted and offered the cash instead. ``I guess (the cash tender offer was successful) because a substantial percentage of noteholders concluded that it was prudent to accept 50 cents on the dollar now rather than taking their chances going forward on what they might get,'' Bechtel said. When the offer went into effect Nov. 29, C. Richard Lehmann of the Bond Investors Association advised bondholders to ``take the money and run.'' The exchange offer will erase $334 million from the liabilities side of Western Union's balance sheet, reducing the company's debt to about $311 million, Bechtel said. Completion of the cash tender hinges on the sale of most of Western Union's Business Services Unit to American Telegraph and Telephone Co., Bechtel said. That transaction, expected to go through Monday, will net Western Union $175 million, Bechtel said. Most of the money will be used to fund the cash tender offer; the rest will go to repay interest on an additional $196 million worth of junk bonds that has been due since June 15, he said. Western Union is one of the the country's oldest companies, known for its telegram and telex communications services. But the company has failed to keep pace with enormous leaps in communications and information technology dominated by rivals such as AT&T and regional Bell phone companies. Western Union hasn't made a profit in years.

DOC.HEAD: American, Pilots in War of Words Over Court Injunction
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines could be threatening passenger safety if pilots are discouraged from calling in sick or filing maintenance requests, union officials said Friday, but the carrier called that statement ``hogwash.'' The Allied Pilots Association, which represents American's 8,000 pilots, has told members to obey a temporary restraining order against the illegal tactics that management alleges have caused delays and flight cancellations. But pilots said the injunction, granted Wednesday by U.S. District Judge John McBryde, could jeopardize passenger safety if i is used to inhibit pilots from filing necessary maintenance requests and staying home when they are sick. The clash over the court ruling is the latest in an increasingly testy struggle between American and its pilots, who have been working without a contract for nearly a year. McBryde set a Jan. 3 hearing date to determine whether the temporary injunction should be made permanent. ``We pointed out to the court that there is a danger that the company may use the order in a way that will impair safe operations. We cannot permit that to happen,'' APA president Fred Vogel told pilots in a taped message on the union's telephone hotline. The union has denied American's charges that pilots have been staging sickouts, taxiing slowly to waste fuel and filing frivolous requests for equipment maintenance. American spokeswoman Lise Olson said typically 300 pilots will call in sick on a given day, but since Dec. 21 more than 500 a day have been out sick. She said 204 flights had been canceled as of Friday afternoon, 48 of which were crew-related. A snowstorm in the northeast caused most of the others, she said. Ms. Olson said the airline never would compromise passenger safety. ``That's hogwash. It's not our intention to endanger anyone,'' Olson said. ``We would expect all of our employees to act professionally.'' Vogel said sick pilots could fail FAA-administered drug tests if they are forced to work after taking certain over-the-counter cold remedies. He added that pilots will not be able to blame such an incident on the injunction. ``You can bet your bottom dollar it will be the pilots who bear the responsibility if there is an incident,'' Vogel said. The APA has been in contract talks since October 1989. The old contract expired Jan. 1, 1990. On Thursday, American said the pilots' unreliable attendance will force the nation's second-largest carrier to reduce its schedule by about 4 percent and lay off some employees.

DOC.HEAD: What's in a Name? S.N.L. Financial Would Rather Switch
DOC.TEXT: A victim of the savings and loan crisis - on the language front, anyway - has decided it's easier to switch than fight. S.N.L. Financial Corp. changed its name this week to Security National Financial Corp. to avoid confusion with the spoken shorthand for the industry known for multibillion-dollar losses and unscrupulous bankers. ``Over the past year, we've been concerned that many people have confused our business with the savings and loan business,'' said George Quist, president of the financial firm that no longer wants its name pronounced S&L. ``This name change to Security National Financial Corp. should resolve the confusion and more accurately reflect our activity,'' he said. The company markets insurance and annuity products in 17 western states and owns and operates cemeteries and mortuaries in Utah and Arizona. The change, approved by stockholders at a meeting Thursday, means the company's new stock symbol on the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation system, or NASDAQ, will be SNFCA.

Precious Metals Surge on Gulf Fears, Weak Dollar
DOC.TEXT: War fears and a weaker dollar helped push gold futures prices to their highest levels in nearly three months Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange. Other precious metals also rose sharply. On other commodity markets, crude oil rallied; copper futures surged; orange juice retreated; grains and soybeans were lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $8.60 to $9.10 higher with the contract for delivery in January at $394 a troy ounce, the highest settlement of a near-month gold contract since Oct. 8. Silver futures were 9 cents to 9.9 cents higher with January at $4.19 a troy ounce; platinum futures finished $4.50 to $7.20 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with January at $409.90 a troy ounce. Prices soared in thin trading conditions as the dollar weakened and tensions in the Middle East mounted. The rally strengthened as gold broke out of its recent trading range and the February contract burst through successive levels of resistance at $390, $391.50 and $394 an ounce. February gold settled near the day's high at $396.20, ``suggesting to me that the next stop will be somewhere in the low $400 area,'' said Peter Cardillo, commodities trading adviser with Jesup, Josephthal & Co. in New York. The Pentagon denied market rumors of a military clash in the Middle East but the talk underscored the anxiety that continues to build as the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait approaches. In developments Friday, the Pentagon announced plans to vaccinate troops against possible germ warfare attacks by Iraq, and a 17-ship carrier armada set sail to bring America's naval deployment in the region to a level unprecedented since the Vietnam war. Analysts said some buying also reflected position-squaring by traders ahead of the New Year's weekend. Most U.S. commodity markets will hold shortened sessions Monday and all will be closed on New Year's Day. War fears also supported petroleum futures on the New York Merc, although near-term heating oil futures weakened ahead of a National Weather Service forecast for above-normal temperatures late next week in the Northeast, the largest regional heating oil market. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 30 cents to 66 cents higher with February at $27.57 a barrel; heating oil was 1.1 cents lower to 1.27 cents higher with January at 79.78 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .92 cent to 1.27 cents higher with January at 69.56 cents a gallon; natural gas was 1.1 cent lower to 1.5 cents higher with February at $1.95 per 1,000 cubic feet. Copper futures rose sharply on the Commodity Exchange in response to both the weaker dollar and rumors of a strike at a large Chilean copper mine. Copper finished 1.8 cents to 3 cents higher with January at $1.158 a pound. Orange juice futures settled 2.25 cents to 3 cents lower on the New York Cotton Exchange with January at $1.135 a pound as the market continued to seek a more realistic level after last week's dramatic surge. Soybean futures prices fell moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting expectations for heavy deliveries Monday against the January contract. Grain futures finished mostly lower. Wheat settled { cent to 3\ cents lower with March at $2.61} a bushel; corn was unchanged to { cent lower with March at $2.32} a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $1.12} a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 6 cents lower with January at $5.58 a bushel. Cattle futures drifted lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures were boosted by higher cash hog prices and chart-inspired buying in pork bellies. Live cattle were .05 cent to .40 cent lower with February at 77.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .35 cent lower with January at 89.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 49.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent to .48 cent higher with February at 63.30 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Co-founder of Longs Drug Store Chain Dies
DOC.TEXT: Joseph M. Long, chairman and co-founder of Longs Drug Stores and a philanthropist who gave millions of dollars to educational and environmental causes, has died. He was 78. The California native, born in Covelo in Mendocino County, died Thursday night at a Walnut Creek hospital, the company announced on Friday. Long founded the retail drug store company in 1938 in Oakland with his brother Thomas, a director of the Walnut Creek-based company. Longs now has 14,000 employees working in 257 retail drug stores in six states - California, Nevada, Arizona, Colorado, Alaska and Hawaii. In recent years, Joseph Long wasn't involved in the day-to-day operations of the store chain. One of his four sons, Robert Long, s president and chief executive officer. Long donated millions of dollars to medical, education, environmental and wildlife causes. He helped established the Joseph M. Long Marine Laboratory at the University of California at Santa Cruz with an initial $1.5 million donation. He also gave $3.25 million to the University of California at San Francisco Medical Center which named a wing of its hospital after Long. Long also founded the California State Park Foundation, which contributed money to wildlife and waterfowl organizations.
